3.title: Nike shares drop as tariffs are expected to hit next quarter's results
3.snippet: Nike (NKE) beat modest earnings expectations with new CEO Elliott Hill, but investors remain jittery over the impact of Trump tariffs. Shares in Nike fell...
3.content:
Nike (NKE) beat modest earnings expectations under new CEO Elliott Hill, but investors remain jittery about the impact of Trump tariffs.

Nike stock fell nearly 8% at market open on Friday.

The footwear giant posted its fiscal third quarter earnings on Thursday after the market close. Its revenue of $11.27 billion surpassed estimates of $11.03 billion, though it marked a drop compared to the $12.43 billion from a year ago.

Adjusted earnings per share came in at $0.54 compared to estimates of $0.30, but also under last year's $0.98.

The earnings report is the second under Hill, a company veteran who took the helm on Oct. 14. Shares initially popped, then dropped roughly 5% in after-hours trading as the company shared its fourth quarter guidance.

CFO Matthew Friend warned of the impact of Trump's tariffs, including a 20% duty on all goods from China.

"We expect fourth quarter gross margins to be down approximately 400 to 500 basis points, including restructuring charges during the same period last year. We have included the estimated impact from newly implemented tariffs on imports from China and Mexico," Friend said on the earnings call.

Nike reported a gross margin of 44.8% in Q3 last fiscal year. In this third quarter, gross margins dropped year over year to 41.5%, missing estimates of 43%.

Friend said the team is "navigating through several external factors that create uncertainty in the current operating environment, including geopolitical dynamics, new tariffs, volatile for rates and tax regulations as well as the impact of this uncertainty and other macro factors on consumer confidence."

Q4 revenue is expected to be "down in the mid-teens range, albeit at the low end," per Friend. Last fiscal year's fourth quarter revenue came in at $12.61 billion.

Here's what Nike posted in the fiscal third quarter versus Bloomberg consensus estimates:

Adjusted earnings per share: $0.54 versus $0.30

Revenue: $11.27 billion compared to $11.03 billion

Nike brand revenue: $10.89 billion compared to $10.6 billion

"We've been through a lot of change, but what's encouraging is that in the 150 days since I've been back, we've reclaimed our identity. We know who we are. Nike, Inc. is a sports company," Hill said on the earnings call.

The road ahead will not be easy. In recent years, competitors' sneakers from On (ONON), Skechers (SKX), and Hoka (DECK) have taken market share. Meanwhile, a slew of tariff news has reignited inflation fears and shaken consumer confidence, which dropped sharply in February.

5.title: Nike Faces Biggest Sales Drop: What is the Turnaround Plan?
5.snippet: Nike's sales saw a huge drop as takers are dwindling. Nike is going to report its steepest revenue slump in nearly 5 years.
5.content:
Nike’s sales it seems is sinking and there is a huge drop as takers are dwindling. Nike is going to report its steepest revenue slump in nearly five years on Thursday when will announce its Q3 earnings result. Nike’s new product line of sporting good and clothing were unable to impress buyers. The sneaker giant, Nike is struggling as customers are few and far fetched, adding to the woes is new tariffs and slower than expected turnaround.

The recent indicators demonstrates a long road ahead for Nike and its new CEO Elliott Hill, who took over in October 2024. Nike’s stock has fallen by 19% since September 20, following Hill’s appointment. Meanwhile, Adidas its biggest rival has seen its stock tick up slightly over the same period.

Nike’s sales drop

Global sales for Nike saw a drop of about 9% last quarter, including a 17% in China. Nike’s biggest market, North America saw a demand slowdown resulting in sales dropping by 9%.

Sales for Nike dropped to $11.27B from $12.4B a year earlier. While Nike delivered a strong earnings beat, expectations were low, heading into the release and profits fell 32% from the year-ago period.

As per report, the sales for Nike in China it’s key region was $1.73B, falling short of expectations of $1.84B.

Nike worst sales in years

The iconic shoemaker in the world is facing a demand slowdown and the upstart brands like Hoka and On are taking over. Customers are less spendy, not ready to shell out on expensive sneakers and clothing. The Nike earning guidance suggest it is going to have worst sales in recent years.

Nike earning report

Consensus estimates from LSEG show that the Wall Street had expected Nike sales to be down 11.4% in current quarter. Beyond guidance, Nike beat Wall Street’s earnings expectations in its fiscal Q3.

Here’s how Nike performed during the quarter, compared with estimates from analysts polled by LSEG:

Nike’s earnings per share: 54 cents vs. 29 cents estimated

Nike’s revenue: $11.27 billion vs. $11.01 billion estimated

The sneaker company, Nike’s net income for the quarter ending on Feb. 28 was $794M, or 54 cents per share, compared with $1.17B, or 77 cents per share, a year earlier, which is much less.

Nike’s poor financial report

CEO Elliott Hill said, “I spent some time over there in December. I had not been over there in a while. The competition is a bit more aggressive than what I remembered,” He added, “So we’ve just got to accelerate our pace.”

Hill since his return has been working to get back Nike to growth by focusing on winning back wholesale partners, innovative products and wooing athletes who moved out. The Nike’s Q3 earnings report on Thursday depicts the work has not yet yielded results.

Nike’s stock performance

Nike shares fell more than 4% in extended trading and are down more than 5% year to date, as of Thursday’s close. Nike’s stock has dropped around 30% over the last year.

Nike banking on innovation

Nike’s biggest turnaround plan is its ability to reignite innovation and create shoes and apparel that reinforces it’s position as market leader. Nike’s new Pegasus Premium “nearly sold out” across North America and is expected to scale through fall 2025 as per Hill. So is the case with Nike’s Romero 18.

Can a Skims partnership help Nike?

Nike efforts to grow its female consumer base a key component to boosting revenue and apparel sales can be seen with its new brand teaming with Kim Kardashian’s Skim. This new line dubbed NikeSKIMS will include apparel, footwear and accessories. With this partnership, Nike expects an improved inroad with women and be a strong competition to brands more popular with women like Lululemon, Vuori, amongst others than Nike currently does.

The planned women’s line with Kim Kardashian-owned Skims “would be pretty good for the business,” said John Nagle, chief investment officer of Kavar Capital Partners LLC. He added, “if they can even just step into that market and be a significant player alongside the Lululemons and Vuoris.”

Also during the Super Bowl Nike debuted a new ad campaign geared toward female athletes, its first big game advertisement in decades is a good strategy.

With continued innovative product line, fostering new partnership and trying to keep itself relevant it can just regain it’s status as the undisputed king.

6.title: Nike’s Revenue Dropped By 9% Since CEO Elliott Hill’s Return
6.snippet: $11.3 billion — Nike's Q3 2025 year revenue, down 9% year-over-year. Revenues for the flagship Nike brand were down 9% to $10.9 billion.
6.content:
Social media is evolving. Are you adapting? Connect with a community of brand pros and content creators at Social Media Week , May 12–14 in NYC, to learn how to keep pace with new trends and technology. Register now to save 20% on your pass .

The numbers

$11.3 billion — Nike’s Q3 2025 year revenue, down 9% year-over-year. Revenues for the flagship Nike brand were down 9% to $10.9 billion.

$6.2 billion — The sneaker giant’s wholesale revenue, which decreased 7% year-over-year.

$4.7 billion — Direct sales. These were down 12% year-over-year primarily due to a 15% decrease in Nike DTC revenues and a 2% decrease dollars derived from its stores.

$405 million — Converse’s revenue for the quarter. This declined 18% year-over-year.

Watercooler talk

This was Nike’s first full quarter under chief executive (CEO) Elliott Hill, who returned to the brand to take on the top role in October 2024.

Hill has orchestrated a turnaround plan, “Win Now,” to return Nike to growth amid stiff competition from newer competitors such as On and Hoka, as well as declining sales in North America and China.

Since joining he’s been focused on rebuilding relationships with Nike’s wholesale partners, debuted a highly-lauded return to the Super Bowl with an ad squared towards women, and announced a buzzy partnership with Kim Kardashian’s Skims brand.

Nike’s wholesale strategy was frequently brought up during its Q3 2025 investors call, with Hill saying that while Nike’s direct and wholesale businesses have been siloed, he is focused on bringing them together in an “integrated consumer-led marketplace.”

On the marketing front, Hill pointed to Super Bowl 59 and NBA All-Star Weekend as having boosting product visibility across Nike’s brand portfolio.

Nike ran its first Big Game spot in 27 years, expanding its “Win Now” marketing strategy, while Jordan Brand ran a Super Bowl ad victory ad, “Love Hurts,” celebrating ambassador and Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Jalen Hurts.

“That is how we create impact, and that is Nike Beyond Nike. We transitioned from one amazing weekend right into another for the NBA All-Star Weekend in the Bay Area. Our brands, in one word, dominated,” Hill claimed.

The CEO also shared that while sales were down generally, he remained confident in Nike’s performance wear. He said revenues from running products grew mid-single digits, but didn’t disclose a figure.

Chief financial officer (CFO) Matthew Friend said he expected fourth-quarter revenue to decline in the mid-teens percentage range, predicting a steeper fall than analysts had anticipated for the remainder of the fiscal year.

However, Hill was optimistic about the long-term vision.

“The progress we made against the ‘Win Now’ strategic priorities we committed to 90 days ago reinforces my confidence that we are on the right path,” he said. “What’s encouraging is Nike made an impact this quarter leading with sport – through athlete storytelling, performance products and big sport moments.”

The brand’s latest results followed two big leadership exits revealed this week. First was chief strategy and transformation officer Daniel Heaf, whose role was eliminated. Elsewhere, 20-year Nike veteran and chief communications officer (CCO) KeJuan Wilkins, who was promoted to that role in 2023 under former CEO John Donahoe, also left.

Key quote

“We’re working closely with the leaders of each of the geos and countries to implement the ‘Win Now’ strategy because, again, the strategy works. No matter if you’re in the United States or in Japan, it all goes back to putting the consumer at the center [of our] products, storytelling, and marketplace,” said Hill.

8.title: Nike Turnaround: Marathon, Not a Sprint, as Tariffs Weigh and Digital Sales Dip 15%
8.snippet: Nike's sales declined across all regions, digital operations showed double-digit declines and tariffs will take a bite out of margins.
8.content:
Nike’s fiscal 2025 third quarter results offered up a snapshot of just how biting the trade war and tariffs may be. They offered a snapshot of waning consumer demand.

And above all else the numbers — though not as bad as Wall Street might have feared — show that Nike’s turnaround will take time, a marathon and not a sprint.

As for those numbers released after the markets closed on Thursday (March 20), for the quarter that ended last month: Revenues were down 9% year over year to $11.3 billion, while the Street had expected a double digit-drop to the $11 billion level.

But looking forward, and as noted by CFO Matthew Friend, tariffs on imports from China and Mexico will hit margins by 4% to 5%. And revenues will decline in the midteens range, as management said on the call.

The stock slumped 4% in after-hours trading.

Full-Price Digital Model

Within the consolidated top line, Nike Brand revenues were $10.9 billion, down 9% on a reported basis, amid declines seen across all geographies. Nike Direct revenues were $4.7 billion, down 12%, and driven by a 15% decline in Nike digital sales, and a 2% dip at the companies stores.

Said Friend on the call, with discussion of the digital sales: “We are repositioning Nike Digital within an integrated marketplace. To do this, we are reducing promotional days, reducing markdown rates and shifting closeout liquidation to our Nike factory stores.”

Digital traffic is expected to be down “double digits in fiscal 2026,” he said, adding that “gradually, we expect organic traffic to stabilize and grow with new product launches and our increased brand marketing investments. … For Nike Digital, we are tightening our buys to support a full-price business model. For Nike factory stores, we are increasing markdowns to drive velocity of higher volumes of closeout inventory.”

During the call with analysts, CEO Elliott Hill, discussing the second quarter of his relatively new tenure at the helm of the company, said, “While we met the expectations we set, we’re not satisfied with our overall results. We can and will be better.

“For the quarter, the big takeaway for me was clear. When we lead with sport, we create impact for Nike. … We’re beginning to drive a more diversified portfolio. It will take time to reach the volume to replace the handful of classic franchises we over-indexed on.”

Those actions will include diversifying sportwear apparel, he said. And across the brand, “We’re already reducing the promotional days and discounting at lower rates. In fact, comparing last year’s January and February to this year’s Nike Digital and North America [sales] went from over 30 promotional days to zero,” Hill said.

CFO Friend’s commentary on product lines and consumer demand were marked by declines in Nike sportswear and the Jordan brand, “led by a double-digit decline in our classic footwear franchises. These franchises again decelerated faster than the overall business with a more pronounced impact on Nike Digital.”

North America revenues slipped by 4%; in the EMEA region, revenues slipped 6%, and in that segment Nike Direct was off 12% and digital sales declined 25%. China sales plummeted 15%, as Nike Digital sales there were off 29% and Nike store sales slumped 6% as traffic declined double digits.

Navigating Uncertainty

“The market continues to be promotional especially in consumer … and in the digital channel,” Friend said of the China market.

Overall, he said, “We are also navigating through several external factors that create uncertainty in the current operating environment, including geopolitical dynamics, new tariffs, volatile foreign exchange rates and tax regulations, as well as the impact of this uncertainty and other macro factors on consumer confidence.”

Moving through those headwinds, Hill said, “We are going to run a balanced and complete portfolio. That’s why I want to make sure everybody on the call hears that. We’re going to run that through all three brand — Nike, Jordan, Converse — across performance, sportswear, men’s, women’s, kids, footwear, pro accessories, and up and down price points.”

Elsewhere, as Hill said, “We’ve been through a lot of change, but what’s encouraging is that in the 150 days since I’ve been back, we’ve reclaimed our identity. We know who we are. … Nike Inc. is a sports company.”

9.title: Nike's Q3 Earnings: A Spoonful Of Sugar Is Not Enough (NYSE:NKE)
9.snippet: Nike's declining sales, especially in China, and strategic shift to D2C sales have led to significant market share loss and profit margin compression.
9.content:
A few years ago, I identified Nike (NYSE: NKE ) as one of the stocks that could be part of my portfolio . After all, it sported a sound balance sheet, on top of which a thriving and growing

I focus on long term growth and dividend growth investing. I follow both the US and the European stock markets, looking for undervalued stock and/or for high quality dividend growing companies that provide me with cash to reinvest. Over time, I have come to realize that profitability is a much safer driver of gains than low valuation. As a result, I give utmost importance to margins, free cash flow stability and growth, and returns on invested capital. I research stocks within my areas of competence and whenever I find a high-quality company, I usually never get bored in researching it more and more.

1.title: This “Wolf Grey” Nike Air Force 1 Low Comes With Rope Laces
1.snippet: The Nike Air Force 1 Low has surfaced in a "Wolf Grey" colorway featuring rope laces. Tap to see official images.
1.content:
This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. The opinions and information provided on this site are original editorial content of Sneaker News.

Intentional or not, this upcoming Nike Air Force 1 has Jordan Brand’s fingerprints all over it. While anchored by a “Wolf Grey” titular hue, two key design choices produce a not-so-subtle allusion to the iconic “Cool Grey” Jordan 11.

For one, the shoe features “Wolf Grey” patent leather on the toe, eyelets, and heel, borrowing a headlining texture from Mike’s eleventh signature model. Additionally, and more importantly perhaps, Nike includes white rope laces akin to those utilized on the “Cool Grey” 11s. The toe box, quarter, and outsole appear in “Vast Grey,” complemented by white treatments on the Swoosh and midsole.

For what it’s worth, the “Cool Grey” Jordan 11 most recently returned in 2021 and is not among Jordan releases on our 2025 calendar. If anything, these AF1s are a solid consolidation prize for those who missed out on the recent “Cool Grey” Jordan 9 retro.

The “Wolf Grey” Air Force 1 retails for $125 and is expected to release Summer 2025 in men’s sizing. See official images below if you’re moved to cop a pair.

3.title: NIKE, Inc. Reports Fiscal 2025 Third Quarter Results
3.snippet: NIKE, Inc. (NYSE:NKE) today reported fiscal 2025 financial results for its third quarter ended February 28, 2025. Third quarter revenues were $11.3 billion,...
3.content:
BEAVERTON, Ore.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--NIKE, Inc. (NYSE:NKE) today reported fiscal 2025 financial results for its third quarter ended February 28, 2025.

Third quarter revenues were $11.3 billion, down 9 percent on a reported basis compared to the prior year and down 7 percent on a currency-neutral basis*

NIKE Direct revenues were $4.7 billion, down 12 percent on a reported basis and down 10 percent on a currency-neutral basis

Wholesale revenues were $6.2 billion, down 7 percent on a reported basis and down 4 percent on a currency-neutral basis

Gross margin decreased 330 basis points to 41.5 percent

Diluted earnings per share was $0.54

"The progress we made against the 'Win Now' strategic priorities we committed to 90 days ago reinforces my confidence that we are on the right path," said Elliott Hill, President and CEO, NIKE, Inc. "What's encouraging is NIKE made an impact this quarter leading with sport – through athlete storytelling, performance products and big sport moments."

"Our outlook for the second half of fiscal 2025 driven by our 'Win Now' actions remains consistent with what we communicated last quarter," said Matthew Friend, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, NIKE, Inc. "The operating environment is dynamic, but what matters most for NIKE is serving athletes with new product innovation and re-igniting brand momentum through sport."

Third Quarter Income Statement Review

Revenues for NIKE, Inc. were $11.3 billion, down 9 percent on a reported basis compared to the prior year and down 7 percent on a currency-neutral basis. NIKE Brand revenues were $10.9 billion, down 9 percent on a reported basis and down 6 percent on a currency-neutral basis, driven by declines across all geographies. NIKE Direct revenues were $4.7 billion, down 12 percent on a reported basis and down 10 percent on a currency-neutral basis, primarily due to a 15 percent decrease in NIKE Brand Digital and a 2 percent decrease in NIKE-owned stores. Wholesale revenues were $6.2 billion, down 7 percent on a reported basis and down 4 percent on a currency-neutral basis. Revenues for Converse were $405 million, down 18 percent on a reported basis and down 16 percent on a currency-neutral basis, due to declines across all territories.

for NIKE, Inc. were $11.3 billion, down 9 percent on a reported basis compared to the prior year and down 7 percent on a currency-neutral basis. Gross margin decreased 330 basis points to 41.5 percent, primarily due to higher discounts, higher inventory obsolescence reserves, higher product costs and changes in channel mix, partially offset by restructuring charges in the prior year.

decreased 330 basis points to 41.5 percent, primarily due to higher discounts, higher inventory obsolescence reserves, higher product costs and changes in channel mix, partially offset by restructuring charges in the prior year. Selling and administrative expense decreased 8 percent to $3.9 billion. Demand creation expense was $1.1 billion, up 8 percent, primarily due to an increase in brand marketing expense. Operating overhead expense decreased 13 percent to $2.8 billion, primarily due to the restructuring charges of $340 million in the prior year and lower wage-related expenses.

decreased 8 percent to $3.9 billion. The effective tax rate was 5.9 percent compared to 16.5 percent for the same period last year, primarily due to a one-time, non-cash deferred tax benefit provided by recently finalized US tax regulations related to foreign currency gains and losses.

was 5.9 percent compared to 16.5 percent for the same period last year, primarily due to a one-time, non-cash deferred tax benefit provided by recently finalized US tax regulations related to foreign currency gains and losses. Net income was $0.8 billion, down 32 percent, and Diluted earnings per share was $0.54, a decrease of 30 percent.

February 28, 2025 Balance Sheet Review

Inventories for NIKE, Inc. were $7.5 billion, down 2 percent compared to the prior year, reflecting product mix shifts, partially offset by an increase in units.

for NIKE, Inc. were $7.5 billion, down 2 percent compared to the prior year, reflecting product mix shifts, partially offset by an increase in units. Cash and equivalents and short-term investments were $10.4 billion, down approximately $0.2 billion from last year, as cash generated by operations was more than offset by share repurchases, cash dividends and capital expenditures.

Shareholder Returns

NIKE continues to have a strong track record of consistently increasing returns to shareholders, including 23 consecutive years of increasing dividend payouts.

In the third quarter, the Company returned approximately $1.1 billion to shareholders, including:

Dividends of $594 million, up 6 percent from the prior year.

of $594 million, up 6 percent from the prior year. Share repurchases of $499 million, reflecting 6.5 million shares retired as part of the Company’s four-year, $18 billion program approved by the Board of Directors in June 2022.

As of February 28, 2025, a total of 119.3 million shares have been repurchased under the program for a total of approximately $11.8 billion.

Conference Call

NIKE, Inc. management will host a conference call beginning at approximately 2:00 p.m. PT on March 20, 2025, to review fiscal third quarter results. The conference call will be broadcast live via the Internet and can be accessed at https://investors.nike.com. For those unable to listen to the live broadcast, an archived version will be available at the same location through approximately 9:00 p.m. PT, April 10, 2025.

About NIKE, Inc.

NIKE, Inc., based near Beaverton, Oregon, is the world's leading designer, marketer and distributor of authentic athletic footwear, apparel, equipment and accessories for a wide variety of sports and fitness activities. Converse, a wholly-owned NIKE, Inc. subsidiary brand, designs, markets and distributes athletic lifestyle footwear, apparel and accessories. For more information, NIKE, Inc.’s earnings releases and other financial information are available on the Internet at https://investors.nike.com. Individuals can also visit https://news.nike.com and follow @NIKE.

Forward-Looking Statements

This press release contains forward-looking statements, which involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially. These risks and uncertainties are detailed from time to time in reports filed by NIKE with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), including Forms 8-K, 10-Q and 10-K.

4.title: Nike Serves Up a Sweet New Air Force 1 in "Hemp/Soft Pink"
4.snippet: Nike is set to deliver a fresh, sweet take on the Air Force 1 for Spring 2025 with the upcoming "Hemp/Soft Pink" colorway. The latest iteration of the...
4.content:
Nike is set to deliver a fresh, sweet take on the Air Force 1 for Spring 2025 with the upcoming "Hemp/Soft Pink" colorway. The latest iteration of the classic silhouette blends neutral tones with playful accents, creating a look that feels straight out of an ice cream shop.

The sneaker features soft hemp suede paneling over a white leather mid-body, offering a textured contrast that enhances its premium appeal. A clean white midsole keeps things classic, while soft pink accents bring a bold yet delicate touch. The laces, Swoosh, heel tab, and outsole all arrive in this subtle pink hue, giving the shoe a strawberry and vanilla ice cream vibe atop a waffle cone-like base.

5.title: Nike Stock Falls After Warning Sales Could Take a Hit From Turnaround Plan, New Tariffs
5.snippet: Nike shares fell in extended trading Thursday after the athletic apparel giant warned sales could take a hit in the current quarter under the company's...
5.content:
Nike (NKE) shares fell in extended trading Thursday after the athletic apparel giant warned sales could take a hit in the current quarter under the company’s turnaround plan, with new tariffs adding to uncertainty.

Nike CFO Matt Friend told investors fiscal fourth-quarter sales are projected to fall by a percentage in the low end of the “mid-teens range" compared to the same period a year earlier, according transcript provided by AlphaSense. Consensus estimates from Visible Alpha show Wall Street analysts had expected sales to fall about 12%.

“We believe that the fourth quarter will reflect the largest impact from our win now actions,” Friend said, adding the company is also “navigating through several external factors that create uncertainty in the current operating environment, including geopolitical dynamics, new tariffs, volatile foreign exchange rates and tax regulations, as well as the impact of this uncertainty and other macro factors on consumer confidence.”

Nike shares initially ticked higher, before giving back gains to drop 5% in after-hours trading Thursday following the earnings call. They've lost more than one-quarter of their value over the past 12 months through the closing bell.

Sales Dropped in Q3, But Not as Much as Expected

The warning for the fourth quarter came as Nike reported third-quarter sales fell from a year ago, but not as much as analysts expected.

The athletic apparel giant saw its third-quarter revenue drop 9% year-over-year to $11.27 billion, though the figure topped the analyst consensus from Visible Alpha. Earnings of $794 million, or 54 cents per share, declined from $1.17 billion, or 77 cents per share, a year earlier, a narrower drop than Wall Street expected.

The better-than-expected quarter represents Nike's second under new CEO Elliott Hill, who took over in October. Earlier this month, Oppenheimer analysts suggested Hill’s efforts to revitalize Nike appear to be "taking shape," based on quarterly results from Foot Locker (FL), which sells Nike apparel.

During the company's earnings call Thursday, Friend suggested headwinds from Nike's efforts to shift its portfolio would likely start to ease after the fourth quarter.



UPDATE—March 20, 2025: This article has been updated since it was first published to include additional information and reflect more recent share price values.

6.title: Nike shares drop as tariffs are expected to hit next quarter's results
6.snippet: Nike (NKE) beat modest earnings expectations with new CEO Elliott Hill, but investors remain jittery over the impact of Trump tariffs.
6.content:
Nike (NKE) beat modest earnings expectations under new CEO Elliott Hill, but investors remain jittery about the impact of Trump tariffs.

Nike stock fell nearly 8% at market open on Friday.

The footwear giant posted its fiscal third quarter earnings on Thursday after the market close. Its revenue of $11.27 billion surpassed estimates of $11.03 billion, though it marked a drop compared to the $12.43 billion from a year ago.

Read more about Nike's stock moves and today's market action.

Adjusted earnings per share came in at $0.54 compared to estimates of $0.30, but also under last year's $0.98.

The earnings report is the second under Hill, a company veteran who took the helm on Oct. 14. Shares initially popped, then dropped roughly 5% in after-hours trading as the company shared its fourth quarter guidance.

CFO Matthew Friend warned of the impact of Trump's tariffs, including a 20% duty on all goods from China.

"We expect fourth quarter gross margins to be down approximately 400 to 500 basis points, including restructuring charges during the same period last year. We have included the estimated impact from newly implemented tariffs on imports from China and Mexico," Friend said on the earnings call.

Nike reported a gross margin of 44.8% in Q3 last fiscal year. In this third quarter, gross margins dropped year over year to 41.5%, missing estimates of 43%.

Friend said the team is "navigating through several external factors that create uncertainty in the current operating environment, including geopolitical dynamics, new tariffs, volatile for rates and tax regulations as well as the impact of this uncertainty and other macro factors on consumer confidence."

Read more: The latest news and updates on Trump's tariffs

Q4 revenue is expected to be "down in the mid-teens range, albeit at the low end," per Friend. Last fiscal year's fourth quarter revenue came in at $12.61 billion.

Here's what Nike posted in the fiscal third quarter versus Bloomberg consensus estimates:

Adjusted earnings per share: $0.54 versus $0.30

Revenue: $11.27 billion compared to $11.03 billion

Nike brand revenue: $10.89 billion compared to $10.6 billion

"We've been through a lot of change, but what's encouraging is that in the 150 days since I've been back, we've reclaimed our identity. We know who we are. Nike, Inc. is a sports company," Hill said on the earnings call.

The road ahead will not be easy. In recent years, competitors' sneakers from On (ONON), Skechers (SKX), and Hoka (DECK) have taken market share. Meanwhile, a slew of tariff news has reignited inflation fears and shaken consumer confidence, which dropped sharply in February.

7.title: Nike Sales Slump 9%, Execs Leave and New CEO Touts Turnaround Signs
7.snippet: Nike reported third-quarter revenue of $11.27 billion for the three months ending Feb. 28. It marked a 9% decline from the previous year's quarter,...
7.content:
Nike reported third-quarter revenue of $11.27 billion for the three months ending Feb. 28. It marked a 9% decline from the previous year’s quarter, but handily topped Wall Street’s already pessimistic expectation of $11.03 billion, per S&P Global Market Intelligence. Earnings per share of $0.54 nearly doubled the $0.29 estimate.

The market expected a lousy quarter from the sportswear giant as it works to clear inventory and increase engagement with its wholesale partners. But the third quarter results offer some green shoots that the turnaround plan under CEO Elliott Hill are bearing fruit. In October, Hill returned to Nike to replace John Donahoe as CEO.

“We’re beginning to drive a more diversified portfolio,” Hill said during the earnings call. “It will take time to reach the volume to replace the handful of classic franchises we over indexed, but our approach is simple, help consumers fall in love with something new from Nike.”

Nike did not address tariffs in its financial release or on the earnings call. Concerns might be overblown as they relate to Nike. In a recent investor note, Telsey Advisory Group expected a muted impact on Nike with the 15% of its products manufactured in China largely to serve the Chinese market and few imported to the U.S.

The earnings report comes a day after a Bloomberg reported Nike’s lead strategy and communications executives—Daniel Heaf and and KeJuan Wilkins—are both leaving the company. It adds to the list of senior leadership changes under Hill.

Greater China was the worst performing region for Nike with sales down 18%, while North America, which is the largest market at $4.9 billion, was down only 4%. The Nike and Jordan brands represent the bulk of the company’s revenue, but the firm also breaks out Converse revenue, which was $405 million, down 18% for the quarter with declines across all territories. NBA MVP candidate Shai Gilgeous-Alexander has helped raise the profile of that brand.

“Nike is getting back to being Nike again,” Jeffries analyst Randal Konik wrote in a quick reaction research note to the news. “We think this journey takes 2 years, but our call is for a V-shaped recovery in F27.”

Last month, Konik upgraded his rating from hold to buy and made Nike his current favorite pick. He sees an upside case for the stock at $140 based on 35x his 2027 fiscal year earnings per share estimate of $4.00. The base case has the stock at $115.

Nike’s stock was the second-worst performer among the 30 components of the Dow in 2024 with a 30% drop. Its 7.2% decline the prior year made it the third-worst stock in the Dow.

The stock closed Wednesday at $71.86 and was down 5% in after-hours trading.

9.title: Buying your Nike shoes online is getting a lot more expensive
9.snippet: Nike is shifting to a fuller-price online model for its online store, cutting discounts and promotions.
9.content:
Nike is shifting its online marketplace to a full-price model, reducing discounts.

Revenue for Nike Direct was down 10% on a currency-neutral basis in fiscal Q3.

CEO Elliott Hill had previously said the company planned to cut down on promotions.

Online shoppers are at the frontlines of Nike's battle against discounts.

The sportswear giant is working to reposition its online marketplace, Nike Digital, to a "full-price business," the company told investors on Thursday.

The move is in line with the promotional plans, or lack thereof, that CEO Elliott Hill has previously spoken about. Hill told investors on a Thursday earnings call that there were zero promotional days on Nike Digital in January and February for the North America region, compared to over 30 for the same period in 2024.

"We are reducing promotional days, reducing markdown rates and shifting closeout liquidation to our Nike factory stores," Matthew Friend, Nike CFO, said.

It's having an impact, though. The company said it expects digital traffic to be down double digits in fiscal 2026 as a result of the decision, though it will "gradually stabilize and grow with new product launches."

Nike reported $11.3 billion in Q3 revenue on Thursday, down 9% year-over-year. That was better than analysts' estimations for an 11% drop, Bloomberg reported. The period marked its first full quarter with Elliott Hill as CEO, who began his role in October.

While Nike has been investing in advertising and innovation, competitors like Adidas and Hoka are gaining mindshare and market share with consumers in the lifestyle and running categories.

The sportswear giant spent $1.1 billion on "demand creation," which includes brand marketing, in its most recent quarter, up 8% from this time last year. Nike aired its first Super Bowl ad in nearly 30 years during the big game on February 9.

Hill has previously spoken about Nike's plans to lean into its identity as a running brand and invest more in women’s sports. In February, it announced that it would partner with Kim Kardashian to launch NikeSkims, a new brand and a rare move for Nike to partner with an external existing company.

Nike shares were down after the bell during Thursday's investor call. The company expects Q4 gross margins to be down between 400 and 500 basis points, including restructuring charges last year, as well as the predicted impact of tariffs on China and Mexico this year.

2.title: Cherry Blossoms Sprout On The Nike Shox R4
2.snippet: The annual cherry blossom bloom is a telltale sign that spring has arrived, and so are Nike sneakers inspired by the pink floral motif.
2.content:
This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. The opinions and information provided on this site are original editorial content of Sneaker News.

The annual cherry blossom bloom is a telltale sign that spring has arrived, and so are Nike sneakers inspired by the pink floral motif. In adding to a canon that includes memorable SB Dunks and Nike Foamposites, Nike is bringing the tried-and-true “Cherry Blossoms” theme to the Shox R4 for Summer 2025.

The sidewalls feature a black-to-pink gradient, evoking the gradual floral bloom while setting the stage for special detailing. Pink cherry blossoms are stitched onto the front portions of the sidewalls, complemented by floral graphics atop pink Shox cushioning pillars. The Swoosh logos come in black stitching, matched by a continuous streak of black from the lining down to the toe.

The “Cherry Blossoms” Shox R4 will be available exclusively in women’s sizing for a shelf price of $150. No release date has been announced yet, but we’re expecting these to land sometime around the annual cherry blossom bloom in April. See official images below and tap our Sneaker Release Dates page to preview more upcoming Nikes.

3.title: Nike's Air Max Plus Appears with Colors from Jamaica's Flag ahead of Carnival Sunday
3.snippet: Nike's iconic Air Max Plus has recently appeared in a summer-friendly 'Varsity Maize/Pine Green/White/Black' color scheme reminiscent of Jamaica's flag.
3.content:
The Nike Air Max Plus debuted 27 years ago, but it continues to form part of the footwear design zeitgeist. Styles from the burgeoning Dn franchise, for example, reference Sean McDowell's design in a refreshing manner. And with the impending return of the Air Max Plus VII, Tuned Air aesthetics will only continue to steal the spotlight from modern proposals. Recently, the silhouette from 1998 emerged in a color scheme reminiscent of Jamaica's flag.

While unofficially linked to the Caribbean island nation, the newly-surfaced Air Max Plus features a Varsity Maize/Pine Green/White/Black' ensemble perfect for Kingston's Carnival Sunday (April 6). Palm tree-inspired TPU overlays across the upper opt for the darkest tone of the bunch, as do mudguards, leather heel panels, and sections of the tooling underfoot. The textile mesh base, however, harkens back to its original look via its bold gradient finish from forefoot to spine. What's particularly curious about the Jamaican flag-reminiscent makeover is that it features a spotted pattern from mid-foot to heel. The design detail evokes images of the Air Max Plus VII's signature rubber overlays.

Tn badges reprise their typical look, while the whale tail-shaped shank underfoot opts for a two-tone finish of the sneaker's titular yellow-and-green duo. Visible Air units also indulge in the island-appropriate update.

Enjoy official photos of the 'Varsity Maize/Pine Green'-accented Air Max Plus below. A firm Nike.com release date for the pair has yet to be disclosed by the brand, but that's expected to change before April ends. The shoe is priced at $180.

For more brightly-colored footwear from the Swoosh, check out the Air Jordan 1 'UNC Reimagined' retro set to land in May.

4.title: Where To Buy The Nike ReactX Rejuven8
4.snippet: Nike's viral ReactX Rejuven8 recovery shoe is selling out fast. Find where and how to buy the ReactX Rejuven8 here.
4.content:
Where To Buy The Nike ReactX Rejuven8

Nike ReactX Rejuven8 Every Colorway

Buy Here

Nike has captured lightning in a bottle with one of its most viral shoe designs in recent memory: the ReactX Rejuven8 recovery shoe. Drawing inspiration from popular slip-on designs like the Foam RNNR and Crocs Classic Clog, the ReactX Rejuven8 distinguishes itself from other slip-ons offered by Nike, such as the Calm Slide, as the model comes with a ReactX foam upper, one of their most comfortable and responsive foams.

Since its debut in January 2025, the ReactX Rejuven8 has taken the sneaker world by storm. Initial colorways, including Green Strike, Triple Black, Smoke Grey, Light Orewood Brown, and Team Orange, sold out within minutes of their release on Nike's website and at select retailers. This overwhelming demand has led to rapid sell-outs during each restock, which we monitor on the Sole Retriever mobile app in real-time.

The ReactX Rejuven8's virality extends beyond sales figures, as it’s almost impossible to scroll through feeds and not see a post or video about the model. TikTok creators have contributed to the buzz, sharing unboxing videos and styling tips that have garnered significant engagement. This widespread social media presence, alongside many dubbing it Nike’s version of Crocs, has undoubtedly fueled the shoe's desirability, making it a must-have item in contemporary fashion circles.

Where to Buy the Nike ReactX Rejuven8

Nike ReactX Rejuven8 Colorways

The Nike ReactX Rejuven8 is available to purchase through Nike and select retailers online and in-store and is priced at $70 for adult sizes and $60 for GS sizes. As we’ve stated multiple times at this point, the pair is consistently selling out. Occasionally, throughout the day and week, Nike and other retailers will load more stock onto their websites. However, it’s a race against time as thousands of others are also trying to purchase the ReactX Rejuven8 just like you.

The best way to ensure you’re in the loop for restocks is to download the Sole Retriever mobile app, as our monitors will pick up when Nike and other retailers load more pairs to their sites. Even with this, you have to be quick, as on the day of this writing, a new Black Volt colorway was released on nike.com, and sizes sold out within 10 minutes.

7.title: Devin Booker Shows Kentucky Pride With Nike Book 1 “Blue Blood”
7.snippet: The Nike Book 1 pours out a "Blue Blood" ode to Kentucky with denim uppers. Click in for detailed in-hand images and release details.
7.content:
This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. The opinions and information provided on this site are original editorial content of Sneaker News.

Never is NBA star’s collegiate pride on display more than once the calendar flips to March. That certainly goes for the rest of the country as well as the proverbial Madness takes hold, but year-in, year-out pro hoopers look back to their various alma maters, often in the realm of sneakers. With Devin Booker’s Kentucky tenure capturing a particular high-point in the school’s recent history (they haven’t reached the Final Four since he left Lexington), it’s a particular good omen that the Book 1 “Blue Blood” is beginning to emerge as the tourney looms.

After the school shared his Book 1 “Kentucky” PE, Devin himself promised a denim ode to the school coming to retail, something that the shoe at hand finally pays off. Atop a faux-vintage aged sole, the Suns SG blends between true collegiate style in the color choices with a more fashion-minded material choice. The allusions to the Wildcats are particularly undeniable down the throat of the shoe, both with the trademark blue hues coating the liner and laces as well as a throwback Cats logo on the tongue tag. Note too the exposed foam tongue, a first on the model.

The Nike Book 1 “Blue Blood” is listed on retailer calendars for an April 10th launch. Retail pricing will become firm as that date nears closer, but expect the typical $140 price tag for the time being. Get a closer look at this colorway with the shots included below and watch our Sneaker Release Dates page in the next few weeks for more updates.

8.title: Nike's Air Force 1 Low Welcomes Summer with Mesh Panels and 'Light British Brown' Swooshes
8.snippet: Nike Sportswear has recently outfitted the iconic Air Force 1 Low in a 'Coconut Milk/Canyon Gold/Light British Tan' color scheme that's more reminiscent of...
8.content:
Nike Sportswear and the rest of the Swoosh conglomerate continues to develop product for the year's warmest months. And while laceless slides and other slip-ons provide the ultimate on-foot experiences for summer, some folks exclusively rock sneakers between May and August. For them, it seems the brand has prepped an all-new Air Force 1 Low featuring mesh panels throughout the upper.

While not the first (nor last) time Bruce Kilgore's blueprint has been tweaked, the newly-surfaced style delivers one of the most curious updates in recent memory. A 'Coconut Milk' tone sets the stage across the top-half, covering the sneaker's traditional leather panels. A quick glance at the unreleased Nike Air Force 1, however, reveals porous mesh layers at the toe, mid-foot, and tongue. The breathable setup is reminiscent of the Air Jordan 4's signature sidewall details, which proved beneficial on the court in 1989.

Profile swooshes and Achilles' heel overlays revert to their typical material, but both components keep things interesting with their textured presentation. A 'Canyon Gold' hue animates stitching across both pieces, while the tooling underfoot keeps things on-brand with a one-two punch of the aforementioned colors.

Enjoy official photos of the reworked Air Force 1 Low ahead. Pairs of the 'Coconut Milk'-covered style are expected to hit Nike.com throughout April for around $135.

For more brown-colored footwear from the Swoosh, check out the Tom Sachs Mars Yard 3.0, the controversial artist's first collaboration with Nike in two years.

9.title: The Nike Pegasus Premium Greets Summer In All “Hyper Pink”
9.snippet: The Nike Pegasus Premium captures a hi-vis "Hyper Pink" and "Bright Crimson" palette. Click in for official images + more info.
9.content:
This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. The opinions and information provided on this site are original editorial content of Sneaker News.

Given that we’ve been tracking the Nike Pegasus Premium since it was unveiled as part of Nike’s Olympic-centric festivities, it’s almost surreal that the model is actually at hand. If nothing else, public reaction has bolstered our own confidence in our tastes: our personal excitement has been matched by sell-outs in each of the model’s debut looks. For the souped-up silo, linking back to the eye-catching palettes that’ve paced Nike’s running silhouettes for years, paid off with the Nike Pegasus Premium “Hyper Pink” featured here.

Even without seeing the shoe, you can capture the hi-vis variation just from the color codes: “Hyper Pink/Bright Crimson/Barely Volt/Sequoia.” Indeed, the all-pink profile of the shoe carries the visibility-minded atmosphere of running models past, carrying through the traffic light red and green insole. Notes of navy and black on the Swoosh and outsole ensure that there are at least some grounded tones on this shoe, but the point is made all the same. If you tend towards the louder side of the spectrum, this is an opportune time to get in on the cutting-edge of Nike’s tech: the combo of ZoomX, ReactX and Air Zoom cushioning remains in place.

The Nike Pegasus Premium “Hyper Pink” should hit Nike.com and retailers in the Summer 2025 window, which would place them in the April to June range. Whenever this pair materializes, be ready for the typical $210 retail price.

0.title: Will Nike Stock Continue its Tired Earnings Trend?
0.snippet: Nike stock finished seven of its last eight post-earnings sessions lower. The company's persistent turnaround initiatives could create short-term headwinds.

1.title: Say Hello to the Nike A.C.E., A New Women's Lifestyle Sneaker Inspired by Retro Tennis Shoes
1.snippet: Nike Tennis continues to innovate for some of the game's top athletes, developing apparel, accessories, and footwear for the biggest stages.
1.content:
Nike Tennis continues to innovate for some of the game's top athletes, developing apparel, accessories, and footwear for the biggest stages. And while the performance-oriented imprint hasn't been a go-to player for design inspiration, it seems the Swoosh empire recently took the team's archives for the A.C.E., a brand-new lifestyle sneaker for women.

Far more fashionable than the marquee Vapor 12 Hypersmash, the Nike A.C.E. is firmly rooted in the past. The busy, panel-laden upper and chunky sole unit harken back to retro performance product from the 1990s and early aughts, creating an aesthetic that exists between tennis and skateboarding. Design cues from the Air Monarch series also land across the new offering, suggesting the pair's comfort has been tuned for all-day reliability.

2.title: Nike Elevates This Dunk Low “Cool Grey” With A Gum Sole
2.snippet: The Nike Dunk Low takes on "Cool Grey" hues and a gum sole. Click in for official images of this Summer 2025 release.
2.content:
This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. The opinions and information provided on this site are original editorial content of Sneaker News.

Are we finally beginning to witness the long reported “slowdown” of Nike Dunks? Under the leadership of former CEO John Donahoe, word was that “staple models” like Peter Moore’s design and the Air Force 1 would begin to see lower production numbers in the near future. Business as usual throughout 2024 made us question when the effects of this report would take place, but a precipitous slowdown in new looks has taken over our coverage in the past few months.

The Nike Dunk Low “Light Bone” marks one of the fresh colorways to come about since mid-February, a real departure from the constant stream we usually see. Perhaps it’s an “absence makes the heart grow fonder” proposition, as the easily-worn, accessible palette here certainly hits a bit harder without having to share the spotlight. To that end, a mix of greyscale tones including the titular “Cool Grey” takes up the most real estate on this Dunk Low, with the ever-appealing gum sole underfoot lending a bit of skate validity to the look.

As a true GR, expect the Nike Dunk Low “Light Bone” to hit Nike.com without warning rather than on a pre-ordained date. Once available, prepare for a $125 retail price.

3.title: The Women’s Nike Dunk Low Mushroom Releases Summer 2025
3.snippet: The Nike Dunk Low enters a magical mushroom kingdom with its latest colorway. Find details and images for this mushroom-inspired Dunk Low.
3.content:
Published March 18, 2025

Although heritage models like the Nike Dunk Low will not be as prominent as they were in the past, we can still expect Nike to drop a series of classic colorways and thematic pairs throughout the year. After previews of a mushroom-themed Air Force 1 Low hit the ‘net, a new Nike Dunk Low Mushroom has emerged.

Like the magical mushroom and forest caricatures found on the AF1, the Dunk Low continues the theme here, featuring a pastel-shaded upper combining pink and light green hues. Along the pink perforated toebox of the left shoe sits an embroidered snail, joined by more nature-inspired depictions on the heel. This includes flowers, mushrooms, trees, and grassy fields, all spanning across the heel overlay.

Nike Dunk Low Mushroom (W)

Just above this embroidery is a pink suede heel tab featuring a trippy Nike font. More Nike branding is found on the hemp-constructed Swoosh and on the cork tongue tag, the latter featuring embroidered Nike text. Inside, the cork insole contains an anthropomorphized mushroom character, the same as the one found on the insole of the Air Force 1. Final details include a rope lace set, hemp tongue, and a tonal midsole and outsole.

The Nike Dunk Low Mushroom W will release in Summer 2025 through Nike and select retailers online and in-store. Available in women’s sizing, the retail price is set at $125. Download the Sole Retriever mobile app to stay updated on the latest releases, raffles, news, and more in the sneaker and streetwear world.

4.title: Nike Dunk Low “Mushroom” Releases Summer 2025
4.snippet: The Nike Dunk Low Mushroom adds playful floral embroidery and soft pastels to its design. Releasing in Spring/Summer 2025 in women's sizing.
4.content:
Nike continues to celebrate nature-inspired designs with the upcoming Nike Dunk Low “Mushroom.” This playful and fresh colorway is set to release as part of the Spring/Summer 2025 lineup.

- Advertisement -

The Nike Dunk Low “Mushroom” comes dressed in soft pastel hues of cream, blush pink, and light green. Adding to the charm are floral embroidery details on the toe box and around the heel, making the design pop with personality. The textured Swoosh and wooden-look tongue tags tie the natural theme together.

A cork-style insole features fun mushroom graphics, enhancing the whimsical feel of the shoe. The midsole remains clean in white, while a soft brown rubber outsole adds contrast and grip.

While mushroom-based leather isn’t used, the smooth leather overlays and textile details offer durability and style. This pair will be perfect for spring and summer, bringing fresh energy to casual outfits.

The Nike Dunk Low “Mushroom” will release in Spring/Summer 2025 at select Nike Sportswear retailers and on Nike.com. It will be available in women’s sizing with a retail price tag of $125 USD.

Stay up to date with all upcoming sneaker releases from our Sneaker Release Dates page. Be sure to follow us on Twitter and Instagram.

Release Date: 2025

5.title: Supreme and Nike’s Long-Awaited Air Max 1 Is Landing This Week
5.snippet: In the 23 years that Supreme and Nike have worked together, they've never collaborated on an Air Max 1. Yeah, you read that right. The AM1 is, no doubt,...
5.content:
In the 23 years that Supreme and Nike have worked together, they’ve never collaborated on an Air Max 1. Yeah, you read that right. The AM1 is, no doubt, one of the sportswear giant’s most iconic and popular silhouettes. But for some reason, it’s managed to slip through the cracks of this storied partnership time and time again. Until now, that is.

Supreme x Nike Air Max 1 ‘Black’ Supreme

Towards the end of last year, rumors began rumbling across the sneakerverse of a potential Supreme Air Max 1. While many heads took these early reports with a grain of salt, the power duo have just confirmed that it's actually happening—and it’s dropping so much sooner than we expected.

Releasing as part of the duo’s spring 2025 collection, the Supreme x Nike Air Max 1 has been revealed in four color combinations: black, white, yellow, and purple. Unlike most AM1s, this very special version replaces the usual mesh-and-suede construction with a premium all-leather build. Co-branded detailing is stitched on the tongue, while the big Swoosh across the sides is covered in faux croc for extra premium points.

6.title: The Apple Nike Sport Band is the best watch strap I’ve ever used, here’s why
6.snippet: The Apple Nike Sport Band is a workout-ready wrist strap that's built for the sporty type. At $49 / £49, this is by no means one of the cheaper Apple Watch...
6.content:
It’s certainly not the cheapest strap out there, but the Apple Nike Sport Band is still among the best. With supreme comfort, breathability and color options, there’s something to love about this Apple Watch band, no matter your style. It has fantastic build quality and is super easy to fasten too, meaning you get plenty of quality for the price you pay.

Why you can trust TechRadar We spend hours testing every product or service we review, so you can be sure you’re buying the best. Find out more about how we test.

Apple Nike Sport Band review

The Apple Nike Sport Band is a workout-ready wrist strap that’s built for the sporty type. At $49 / £49, this is by no means one of the cheaper Apple Watch bands available, but it does, admittedly, have a premium feel to it that takes your workout monitoring to the next level.

Specifically, this band is constructed of the sweat and waterproof material, fluoroelastomer. Apple says that each strap has at least 30% recycled fluoroelastomer and that the flakes littered across the strap are made from a minimum of 66% fluoroelastomer – pretty neat. Interestingly, these flakes are scattered in a randomized manner, ensuring that each Nike Sport Band is unique.

More generally, this is a very nice looking band. I tested the Midnight Sky variant, where the flakes created a starry sky impression against the gray-black strap. Other than Midnight Sky, you can choose from: Blue Flame (blue and orange); Cargo Khaki (green and blue); Desert Stone (a sandy color with orange and blue details); Magic Ember (pink); Pure Platinum (white with mulit-colored splodges); and Volt Splash (green). I was a big fan of the many color options available – whether you want a more muted, professional looking option like Midnight Sky or an in-your-face vibrant band like Magic Ember, there’s a style for anyone – something we always look for on our hunt for the best Apple Watch bands.

That’s not the only variability to mention, though, because there are also a number of size options. This strap is compatible with three different case sizes: 40, 42 and 46mm. You can also get it in either small-to-medium (140-190mm) or medium-to-large (160-210mm). I used the former and found it very easy to get a comfortable fit – just poke the aluminum pin through one of the many holes in the strap and you’re good to go.

Even when keeping this strap on for entire days at a time, I never felt any irritation or annoyance. The high density of holes means there’s plenty of room for your wrist to breathe and the material is inherently resistant against water and sweat, making this strap ideal for workouts, for instance. I went on a run and many a walk and never realized any strain or damage, so you can rest assured that there’s plenty of quality here.

And quality is exactly what you’d expect for an Apple Watch band of this price. At $49 / £49 this thing isn’t cheap. There are some third-party alternatives – like the CeMiKa Silicone Sport Straps or Yoohoo Adjustable Metal Strap – that can be yours for less than $15 / £15. But really, I think you’ll feel the difference. The quality of material, excellent color design and more premium look of the Nike Sport Band makes it a superior companion for your Apple Watch – especially if you’re someone that loves to get active.

(Image credit: Future)

Apple Nike Sport Band review: Price & specs

Swipe to scroll horizontally Price $49 / £49 Materials Fluoroelastomer (at least 30% recycled) Band size S/M (140-190mm); M/L (160-210mm) Compatible with 40, 42, 46mm Resistances Sweat and water

(Image credit: Future)

Should I buy the Apple Nike Sport Band?

Buy it if…

You’re the active type

If you’re someone that likes to stay in shape – whether that’s running, lifting weights, swimming (maybe all of the above?) – this is the ideal watch strap for you. It’s made from a water-resistant material and has holes to let your wrists breathe – it doesn’t get much better than that.

You want an easy-to-fasten strap

Something I love about the Apple Nike Sport Band is how easy it is to fasten to your wrist. Just poke the aluminum pin through one of the strap’s holes and it will lock into place. No more messing around with an awkward buckle.

Don't buy it if…

You’re on a tight budget

The only real issue I can take with this strap is its price. I don’t think it’s crazy expensive given the quality on offer, but it’s certainly not cheap. If you’re looking for a massively budget-friendly strap, this one is to be avoided, unless you find it at a significantly discounted price.

You want an ultra premium option

If you’re on the other end of the spectrum and want a top-tier premium watch strap, this might not be flashy enough for you. There are high-calibre metallic options like the Milanese Loop, for instance, but that will set you back almost $100 / £100.

Apple Nike Sport Band review: Also consider

7.title: How Will Nike Stock React To Its Upcoming Q3 Earnings?
7.snippet: Nike (NYSE: NKE) is set to report its fiscal third-quarter earnings on Thursday, March 20, 2025. Analysts predict the company will report earnings of $0.28...
7.content:
Nike (NYSE: NKE) is set to report its fiscal third-quarter earnings on Thursday, March 20, 2025. Analysts predict the company will report earnings of $0.28 per share on $11.02 billion in sales. This would represent a 64% decline in earnings and an 11% fall in sales compared to the previous year’s figures of $0.77 per share and $12.44 billion, respectively. Investors will closely watch the company’s performance amid ongoing challenges, including macro pressures, uneven consumer trends, and sluggish sales across various channels.

The company has $109 billion in current market capitalization. Revenue over the last twelve months was $49 billion, and it was operationally profitable with $5.5 billion in operating profits and a net income of $4.9 billion. While a lot will depend on how results stack up against consensus and expectations, understanding historical patterns might just turn the odds in your favor if you are an event-driven trader.

There are two ways to do that: understand the historical odds and position yourself before the earnings release, or look at the correlation between immediate and medium-term returns post-earnings and position yourself accordingly after the earnings are released. That said, if you seek upside with lower volatility than individual stocks, the Trefis High-Quality portfolio presents an alternative – having outperformed the S&P 500 and generated returns exceeding 91% since its inception. See earnings reaction history of all stocks.

Nike’s Historical Odds Of Positive Post-Earnings Return

Some observations on one-day (1D) post-earnings returns:

There are 20 earnings data points recorded over the last five years, with 8 positive and 12 negative one-day (1D) returns observed. In summary, positive 1D returns were seen about 40% of the time.

and one-day (1D) returns observed. In summary, positive 1D returns were seen about 40% of the time. However, this percentage decreases to 25% if we consider data for the last 3 years instead of 5.

Median of the 8 positive returns = 7.7%, and median of the 12 negative returns =-6.8%

Additional data for observed 5-Day (5D), and 21-Day (21D) returns post earnings are summarized along with the statistics in the table below.

Correlation Between 1D, 5D, and 21D Historical Returns

A relatively less risky strategy (though not useful if the correlation is low) is to understand the correlation between short-term and medium-term returns post earnings, find a pair that has the highest correlation, and execute the appropriate trade. For example, if 1D and 5D show the highest correlation, a trader can position themselves “long” for the next 5 days if 1D post-earnings return is positive. 9.title: Nike Dunk Low Bright Crimson / Dusty Cactus - Apr 2025 - HF5441-601
9.snippet: The Nike Dunk Low Bright Crimson / Dusty Cactus is a vibrant and eye-catching addition to the Dunk lineup, celebrating both retro aesthetics and modern...
9.content:
The Nike Dunk Low Bright Crimson / Dusty Cactus is a vibrant and eye-catching addition to the Dunk lineup, celebrating both retro aesthetics and modern style. This sneaker seamlessly fuses bold colorways, with the bright crimson creating a striking contrast against the subdued dusty cactus and neutral base tones. The shoe maintains the classic Dunk silhouette, featuring the traditional low-top design that has become synonymous with comfort and versatility. The use of premium materials adds a luxurious touch, ensuring that the sneaker not only stands out in terms of color but also in terms of quality and craftsmanship. This particular colorway is a testament to Nike's ability to blend daring color combinations with iconic sneaker design, appealing to both long-time Dunk enthusiasts and new fans alike.

In terms of performance, the Bright Crimson / Dusty Cactus iteration of the Nike Dunk Low maintains the functionality that has made the Dunk line popular among skateboarders and sneaker collectors. The shoe features a padded collar and tongue for added comfort, and its durable rubber sole provides excellent traction and support, making it suitable for both casual wear and active use. The color scheme is not only visually appealing but also strategically placed to emphasize the shoe's structure and design lines. This model embodies the blend of heritage and innovation that Nike consistently delivers, making it a must-have for those who appreciate a touch of nostalgia fused with contemporary flair. Whether worn as a statement piece in an ensemble or as part of a casual outfit, the Nike Dunk Low Bright Crimson / Dusty Cactus is sure to turn heads and offer unparalleled style.

0.title: The Nike Air Max 95 “Neon” Is Dropping In April
0.snippet: The Nike Air Max 95 Neon is scheduled to release April 2025 for $185. Tap in for full release details and info.
0.content:
This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. The opinions and information provided on this site are original editorial content of Sneaker News.

Nike has the Air Max DN8 and the Big Head Origins slated as their big Air Max Day drops, but many are looking beyond March for their must-have bubbled pick-ups of 2025. Read on to learn more about the upcoming Air Max 95 “Neon”.

The original colorway of the 1995 model created by Sergio Lozano may be the most iconic Air Max sneaker of all-time. More recognizable than any of its siblings, the 95s are easily in a metaphorical Mount Rushmore of Nike footwear history for its timeless design.

With Nike’s adherence to dropping shoes on milestone anniversary years, we foresaw the Air Max 95 “Neon” dropping in 2025 years ago. This year’s version brings a very welcome twist as it will ditch the “modern” Air units and revert back to the older construction that features the horizontal seam through the heel Air unit. This crucial detail was ditched way back in 2005/2006 as Nike re-engineered the cushion to be less prone to deflation; an unexpected byproduct was the disapproval by the public.

The Swoosh has taken serious efforts in restoring original shapes and constructions of its earliest Air Max models, and the 2025 version of the 95 is simply its best foot forward yet. It still falls short of the original via the smaller bag volume and the lack of psi markings, but that won’t hold anyone back from copping multiple pairs.

The Neon 95 did drop at select stores in Japan over the weekend, but Nike has a firm release scheduled for the month of April planned out. Select stores in NYC, LA, Chicago, and along the I-95 route will release the shoes on April 4th, with wider SNKRS and retailer drop penciled in for April 17th. MSRP is set at $185.

1.title: Scoured: The Best Nike ACG Gear for March 2025
1.snippet: When you need something to tackle any forecast in style, who can you trust more than Nike ACG? The Swoosh's adventure-ready sublabel is a go-to source for...
1.content:
When you need something to tackle any forecast in style, who can you trust more than Nike ACG? The Swoosh’s adventure-ready sublabel is a go-to source for some of the finest pieces and accessories to rock on your next outdoor trip. With spring right around the corner, there’s no better time to stock up on gear that’ll suit you well through sunny days, sudden showers, and swift breezes. That’s why we laid out some of our favorites the brand has to offer in this month’s Scoured guide.

Nike ACG Hiking Shorts

Photo: Nike

It’s almost time to put the sweats you’ve been wearing all winter to the side, and these hiking shorts are a perfect way to make that transition. With just the right amount of stretch, ACG emphasizes mobility and protection here, using a water-repellent woven fabric to prevent you from getting soaked, as well as a mobility gusset, so you have some extra breathing room when you sit down on a bench to rest or crouch down to look at a cool bug along the trails. It’s equipped with a webbing belt and zippered pockets to keep essential EDC accessories safe and sound.

Nike ACG Orb Weaver ADV UV LS Shirt

Photo: Nike

Technical button-ups are the best of both worlds, making the move from your office to the trails as seamless as possible. Fitted with pockets galore, the Beaverton brand’s Orb Weaver long-sleeve is perfect for storing small items like earbuds, keys, and anything else you have on hand throughout the day. This roomy top also has a mesh-lined vest for temperature regulation and offers dependable UV protection for sunnier days.

Nike ACG Wolf Tree Plus

Photo: Nike

This fleece’s roomy fit and Polartec construction make it one of the coziest pieces Nike ACG has in store – but it’s still exceptionally durable. Put to the test in Smith Rock, a historic hot spot for rock climbers, the jacket boasts reinforced water-resistant nylon panels to protect high-abrasion areas like the hood, shoulder, and chest when you’re out and about. It’s finished off with a set of zippered hand pockets that lock in warmth and protect loose equipment.

Nike CyGNal Shoes

Photo: Nike

The versatile Cygnal’s interior is padded to the nines, assuring all-day comfort in any environment – but it doesn’t stop there. With its waterproof leather upper and rugged rubber outsole, you can also bank on protection from top to bottom. And while they resemble a pair of Diemmes from a distance, the shoe-boot hybrid’s subtle Swoosh, chunky sole, and sleek colorways make it an affordable alternative.

Nike ACG Aysén Day Pack

Photo: Nike

Finding the perfect backpack for your daily commute is no easy task; in fact, it’s usually more challenging than the actual task you’re commuting to complete. Luckily, ACG simplifies your decision, all thanks to this rugged, Dyneema-crafted bag flooded with expandable storage, including an internal tech sleeve, adjustable side pockets that can fit larger water bottles, and front pockets for any items you need to grab in a cinch. A magnetic button closure secures the 32L Aysén’s roll top design, which is then finished with carabiner clips and a sternum strap for even weight distribution.

2.title: The Nike Book 1 Blue Blood Releases April 2025
2.snippet: Devin Booker's Nike Book 1 appears in a new colorway that honors the Kentucky Wildcats' iconic denim uniform from 1996. Find details here.
2.content:
Published March 17, 2025

Devin Booker’s affinity for retro and vintage anything is well documented. The 29-year-old showcases this love through his collection of clothing and cars and his signature sneaker with Nike, the Nike Book 1. While we’ve seen the model pay homage to vintage and retro designs from Nike, like the ACG Mowabb and Air Penny 5 colorways, the sneaker is now getting a makeover inspired by vintage Kentucky Wildcats uniforms.

The Book 1 previously emerged in an exclusive colorway for the University of Kentucky, paying homage to the school’s 1996 season when the school went 34-2 and won the national championship against Syracuse. However, this pair that will be released to the public harkens back to the team’s uniforms from that season, which featured denim construction alongside typical jersey materials. Most paneling comes in light blue denim to honor this iconic uniform design.

Nike Book 1 Blue Blood

Darker Kentucky blue hues land on the lace set, sockliner, mini Swoosh on the vamp, and the woven tongue label, the latter featuring an embroidered wildcat caricature that looks similar to the school’s logo from 1986 to 2005. Along the midfoot, the Swoosh comes in a light-washed blue denim, outlined in a sail white textile. Final details include a number one embroidered on the lateral heel and a sail midsole and outsole.

The Nike Book 1 Blue Blood will release on April 1, 2025, through Nike and select retailers online and in-store. Available in men’s sizing, the retail price is $140. Download the Sole Retriever mobile app to stay updated on the latest releases, raffles, news, and more in the sneaker and streetwear world.

3.snippet: While we've been covering the unreleased five-part Supreme x Nike SB Dunk Low campaign since last year, Supreme's long-rumored Air Max 1 '87 project was the one...
3.content:
Name: Supreme x Nike Air Max 1 ‘87

Colorways: White/White/White, Black/White/Black, Varsity Purple/White/Varsity Purple and Speed Yellow/White/Speed Yellow

SKUs: HF8813-100, HF8813-001, HF8813-500 and HF8813-700

MSRP: $170 USD

Release Date: March 26

Where to Buy: Supreme

Update: Supreme just announced its latest collaboration with Nike, presenting a wide range of sportswear apparel that includes nods to the Swoosh’s Air Max franchise. However, the duo’s forthcoming Air Max 1 ‘87 colorways were not featured in the collection, further backing the rumor that the four-shoe collection will drop next week on Air Max Day (March 26). A first look at the “Varsity Purple” pair popped up today as well, offering a look at previously unseen details at the rear. Supreme’s “World Famous” script appears in white at the heel counter, above what seems to be a “SUPREME” wordmark debossed at the heel of the midsole. From there, the shoe includes a “World Famous” callout at the aglets in white text. Stay tuned for the collaboration’s official announcement and review our previous coverage below for more info.

Update: Supreme dropped its Spring/Summer 2025 lookbook last month, teasing a new Nike collaboration featuring the Air Max 1 ‘87. The project was first rumored last year and was said to include four colorways, however, only the “Black” pair was highlighted in the brand’s seasonal preview. Now, with the new Supreme season well underway, a first look at the “White” version has surfaced. This take on the shoe sees it equipped with an all-white finish that hosts a red Supreme box logo at the tongue tag. We’re still waiting to see what the “Varsity Purple” and “Speed Yellow” iterations of the shoe look like, however, it’s likely that both will become visible very soon as reputable Supreme leaker DropsByJay has hinted at an Air Max Day — March 26 — launch date for this project. Look out for it to drop exclusively via Supreme at a starting price of $170 USD per pair.

First Look at the White Supreme/Nike Air Max 1 pic.twitter.com/lhrkLuCXbO — DropsByJay (@DropsByJay) March 14, 2025

Original Story: Supreme season is back. The iconic streetwear brand dropped its Spring/Summer 2025 teaser last week and followed up with its complete lookbook and range on Monday. On top of exciting new reveals featuring collaborations with artists like Damien Hirst and Aphex Twin, it revealed one of its upcoming Nike projects.

While we’ve been covering the unreleased five-part Supreme x Nike SB Dunk Low campaign since last year, Supreme’s long-rumored Air Max 1 ‘87 project was the one to make an appearance this week. While we lack a complete set of visuals featuring the shoe, two looks showcased the kicks in its “Black” colorway. This version of the shoe looks to be presented entirely in black, save for its silver dubrae and white lateral Swooshes that are visible here. According to SneakerMarketRO’s report last year, three other colorways of “White,” “Varsity Purple” and “Speed Yellow” will accompany this pair when it drops later this year.

At the time of writing, neither Supreme nor Nike have confirmed which colorways of their forthcoming Air Max 1 ‘87 will be dropping and when. Stay tuned for more info, including an official look at all of the retail pairs, as it is currently set to drop at some point during Supreme’s SS25 season via Supreme at a starting price of $170 USD each.
