2.content:
Nike Sportswear continues to reimagined the Shox R4 silhouette in refreshing styles for the fashionable. Ahead of spring, the design from the early 2000s has surfaced in a clean 'White/Phantom/Picante Red' trifecta.

The Swoosh has heavily marketed the retro performance model towards women. The latest ensemble to hit the Shox-assisted design delivers yet another compelling offering for the brand's women consumers. Perforated synthetic leather panels across the profiles opt for a "colorless" finish that allows for even the slightest contrast to steal the spotlight. Foamposite One-reminiscent panels deviate in an off-white tone that helps create another springtime look on the sneaker. Vibrant 'Picante Red' flair animates branding on the tongue, as well as the iconic piston-like components underneath the heel.

Underfoot, the sole unit maintains its original design intact, but its speckled finish suggests the style forms part of Nike's eco-friendly efforts.

Enjoy official photos of the 'White/Picante Red' Shox R4 below. A stateside Nike.com release date for the pair hasn't been confirmed yet, but the shoes are landing across China on Monday, March 31. The sneaker is priced at $150.

3.content: Nike Basketball announced the World Select women's roster for the 2025 Nike Hoop Summit, and Tennessee Lady Vol signee Deniya Prawl has been chosen to participate in the event.The world's top talent will join forces to face USA teams, which include several members who won gold medals last summer at the FIBA U17 World Cup and FIBA U18 AmeriCup and represent the high school graduating classes of 2025. The World team features elite talent with players ages 19 and younger across six continents.The event will be held on Saturday, April 12, 2025, at the Moda Center in Portland, Oregon, and will be televised live on USA Network and streamed on Peacock, beginning with the women's game at 7:30 p.m. ET. One of the top-rated players in the prep class of 2025, she is ranked No. 6 by 247Sports, No. 8 by World Exposure Report, No. 10 by ProspectsNation.com and On3, and No. 14 by ESPN.This won't be Prawl's first time competing in an international event. She played on the Canadian 2024 FIBA U17 World Cup team, averaging 11.9 points, 7.6 rebounds, 3.7 assists and 1.4 blocks in 27.2 minutes over seven games. She was a significant contributor as her nation took silver in that event, as she tallied 13 points, seven rebounds and three blocks in the gold medal game vs. United States.Prawl also played on the 2022 FIBA U17 World Cup team for Canada, contributing 5.2 rebounds, 2.8 points and 1.8 assists to that squad's fourth-place finish as one of its younger members.The Nike Hoop Summit has been held annually since 1995, except for 2001-03 and 2020-21, and it has been in Portland since 2008. 4.title: Nike, StockX counterfeit lawsuit will head to trial
4.snippet: The years-long legal battle between Nike and resale platform StockX over counterfeits will head to trial later this year, according to court documents filed...
4.content:
Listen to the article 3 min This audio is auto-generated. Please let us know if you have feedback

Dive Brief:

The years-long legal battle between Nike and resale platform StockX over counterfeits will head to trial later this year, according to court documents filed last week.

A federal judge granted part of Nike’s motion for a partial summary judgment in the lawsuit, which has been ongoing since 2022. The athleticwear giant accused the resale company of counterfeiting and insidious false advertising, but the judge dismissed allegations of false advertising , per a release from StockX.

The companies have until Friday to file a joint letter indicating how long they expect the trial to take and the companies’ availability between June 15 and November 15.

Dive Insight:

Nike initially called for a partial summary judgment in the case last year, meaning it asked the judge to rule on some of its claims before the trial. That request came after Nike said it discovered at least 77 pairs of counterfeit Nike shoes sold on StockX. In response to that motion, StockX said it stood by its authentication process and that Nike’s claims were misguided.

In last week’s filings, Nike’s request was granted in part as it looks to hold StockX liable for distributing four pairs of counterfeit shoes to Nike investigators and selling 33 pairs of counterfeit shoes to one individual named Roy Kim.

“Verification has been core to StockX since our inception — we’ve invested millions of dollars in technology, training, and tooling, and we stand behind every product sold on StockX with our Buyer Promise,” StockX said in its release on the judgment. “In this case and on an ongoing basis with all our customers, we offer refunds or replacements if someone receives an incorrect product.”

StockX said the products referenced in the request for partial summary judgment amounted to “0.0004% of the 17.8 million Nike sneakers reviewed while this litigation was ongoing.” Nike was the top-selling brand on StockX’s platform during the last three years.

“As we’ve said before, it’s a shame that rather than work with us to fight fakes, Nike has instead opted to use its resources to pursue meritless, expensive litigation,” StockX said in the release. “We look forward to the opportunity to tell our story to a jury at trial.”

The lawsuit has evolved since it was first filed.

Nike initially sued the resale platform for allegedly using Nike trademarks in non-fungible tokens (or NFTs). Counterfeiting and false advertising claims were added to the lawsuit a few months later, after Nike obtained the four pairs of counterfeit shoes referenced in last week’s filing.

Similar to another ongoing legal challenge between Chanel and What Goes Around Comes Around, the results of the Nike and StockX dispute could have implications for resellers that use and promote authentication systems.

7.title: DyeStat.com - News - Preview: 10 Storylines For Nike Indoor Nationals 2025
7.snippet: Intrigue Abounds With Loaded Distance Events At This Week's Nike Indoor NationalsBy Oliver Hinson for DyeStatJohn Nepolitan photosThe Armory in New York...
7.content:
Intrigue Abounds With Loaded Distance Events At This Week's Nike Indoor Nationals

By Oliver Hinson for DyeStat

John Nepolitan photos

The Armory in New York City will host many of the best track and field athletes in the country this weekend for Nike Indoor Nationals. Here are 10 storylines to watch at the meet:

WATCH THE FREE LIVE WEBCAST OF NIKE INDOOR NATIONALS ON RUNNERSPACE | LIVE RESULTS ON ATHLETICLIVE

McElhinney vs Moore In Girls 800

The girls 800-meter championshp includes 13 runners with sub-2:10 seed times, and up front, it’s a battle between youth and experience. Dylan McElhinney (Hunter College NY) is the veteran, a two-time Nike Indoor Nationals champion and a USATF U20 champion. She’s also a Manhattan native with plenty of experience at The Armory.

The challenger is Reagan Moore, a sophomore at Oak Knoll NJ. Moore has set personal bests in every event from the 200 to the mile this season, and she has proven that she’s at her best when the competition is high. Last year, she lowered her 800 PB from 2:09.43 to 2:07.72 at New Balance Nationals Outdoor, and this season, she took off another three seconds at the NJSIAA Meet of Champions with a 2:04.80 performance.

Moore has the fastest seed time in the field, and she clearly has a high ceiling. Can she beat the hometown veteran?

Hedengren Set To Dominate

Since last fall, Timpview UT’s Jane Hedengren has consistently delivered mind-blowing performances. First, she went nearly undefeated in the 2024 cross country season and won Nike Cross Nationals by over 40 seconds, throwing down a ridiculous 16:32 on a muddy Glendoveer course in Portland.

She’s only competed a few times this indoor season, but with a 9:37 performance in the 3,200 meters at the Simplot Games and a 4:36 in the 1600 at the REP Distance Challenge (both at altitude, no less), she clearly has the best resume of any distance runner competing at the Armory this weekend.

Last year, we saw a blowout in the girls 5,000 meter championship, as Elizabeth Leachman torched the national record with a 15:28 performance. Hedengren will likely have that mark in her sights, and it’s certainly within her capabilities. She may not deliver a 49-second margin of victory like Leachman — Zariel Macchia (William Floyd NY), Rylee Blade (Santiago CA) and Emily Wisniewski (Crescent Valley OR) are also in the field — but she’s the clear favorite, and most fans’ eyes will be on the clock.

Hedengren is also part of a stacked girls mile field that includes Macchia, McElhinney, Addison Ritzenhein (Niwot CO), and Ellery Lincoln (Lincoln OR), but she’s the clear favorite there, too, and the meet record of 4:36.61 could easily go down.

Highly Competitive Boys Distance Races

The boys mile and 2-mile fields feature a lot of the same names, and those names belong to some of the best distance runners in the country. NXN champion Charlie Vause (Rio Rancho NM) is in both, as well as Corbin Coombs (Organ Mountain NM), TJ Hansen (Freeland MI), Evan Noonan (Dana Hills CA), Jack Bowen (McCallie TN) and Luke Pash (Ridgewood NJ), among others.

Coombs has a lot of momentum heading into this weekend; on March 1, he threw down a 4:01.62 mile at the CIRCUIT Philly, giving him the fastest seed time in that event by two seconds. He has continued to progress as the season goes on, and like Hedengren in the women’s distance events, he has the advantage of training at altitude year-round.

Hansen is another name to look out for; he finished just behind Coombs at the CIRCUIT, and he’s run under 4:10 four times this winter. He was also second at NXN in the fall.

Vause, meanwhile, has only raced once this season, and Noonan hasn’t raced since finishing fifth at NXN. These races will serve as early tests of their fitness; if either of them can pull off a win, they’ll be sending a message that they are not to be ignored this outdoor season.

The 2-mile field has a high-caliber name that the mile doesn’t: Tommy Latham. The Marist GA senior has also raced just once this winter, but he made the most of his lone opportunity, winning the boys mile at the Millrose Games in 4:00.94. His indoor 2=mile PB is 9:19.85, and his outdoor 3,200 meter PB is 8:46.88.

Pole Vault Titans Go Head To Head

All eyes will be on Victor Olesen (St. Christopher’s VA) and Luke Beattie (Warwick Valley NY) in the boys pole vault. The two juniors are US#2 and US#3, respectively, and they both rank in the top 15 all-time indoors. They’re separated by only a half inch — Olesen sits at 17-7.50 and Beattie sits at 17-7 — and they set their current PBs on the same day just two weeks ago. Now, they’ll meet head-to-head for the first time this season.

It’s unlikely they’ll set a meet record, or any record, for that matter, as seemingly every pole vault record in existence belongs to Mondo Duplantis. However, their matchup is sure to bring fireworks.

Lutkenhaus Returns To The Armory

A month ago, Cooper Lutkenhaus broke the indoor high school national record in the 800 meters at the Millrose Games, clocking a 1:46.86 as Josh Hoey, the former record holder, broke the American record in the same race with 1:43.90.

Lutkenhaus, a sophomore at Northwest TX, has the best seed time in the boys 800 meters this weekend by over three seconds. The question isn’t whether he will win, or whether he will break the meet record of 1:49.46; it’s how much he will beat it by, and how many other runners he’ll drag under it. Wyland Obando (Long Beach Wilson CA) ran 1:50.26 at last year’s CIF State Championships, and although he hasn’t competed this winter inside, he may be able to tail behind Lutkenhaus for a lap or two and hang on for a sub-1:50. Obando is the only other competitor in the field with a sub-1:51 credential.

Texas Sprint Talent On Display

Sprinting is different in Texas. Almost every week, it seems, another boys team is dipping under 40 seconds in the 4x100 relay, or another athlete is nearing (or breaking) the 10-second barrier. This weekend, the Lone Star state is sending its best and brightest to the Big Apple.

Of the top five seeded athletes in the boys and girls 60, 200 and 400 (30 athletes total), 17 are from Texas. It’s not out of the realm of possibility that Texans could sweep every individual sprint championship.

Listing every Texas sprinter to look out for would take a decade, so here are the best of the best. Kendrick Jones Jr. (Lake Belton) is looking to defend his title in the boys 200 meters, and he’s also the top seed in the 400. In both of those races, he’ll be facing off against arguably the best sprinter in the Northeast, Philadelphia’s Jayden Horton-Mims (Imhotep Charter PA). Horton-Mims equaled the national record in the 300 meters at the Millrose Games.

Celeste Robinson (Cypress Ranch TX) is another name to watch. The Georgia commit hasn’t picked up any major wins this indoor season, but she comes in with the fastest seed time in the girls 200 meters (22.82), which she recorded in her win at last year’s Nike Outdoor Nationals. She’ll be facing off against some of the best talent in her state in the 200 meters and the 60 meters this weekend, including Skylar Brazzell (Northwest Nelson) and Mia Maxwell (Humble Atastocita).

Other top Texans include Jayden Finley (North Richland Hills), Ja’Shaun Lloyd (Corsicana), Jonathan Simms (Allen) and Tate Taylor (Harlan).

Seven Returning Champions Back For More

Seniors ruled the 2024 meet, and now they’re gone, leaving a massive hole to fill. The only returning champions are Horton-Mims (boys 400 meters), McElhinney (girls 800 meters and mile), Skyler Brazzell (girls 400 meters), Olesen (boys pole vault), Lauren Kirby (girls shot put showcase), Jones Jr. (boys 200 meters) and Cordial Vann (boys 60 meters).

This year, another dominant class of seniors, including Horton-Mims, McElhinney, Hedengren and several others, will be looking to write (or rewrite) their names in the history books, but they’ll be going up against some of the best young talent in the country. Lutkenhaus (Northwest TX), Moore (Oak Knoll NJ), Sophia Rodriguez (Mercer Island WA), and Olivia Harris (Buford GA) — all sophomores — are some of the biggest names in the meet, and they’ll be giving the veterans a run for their money.

Hannah Grace Raising The Bar In PV

If the idea of a two-horse race doesn’t entertain you (see: boys pole vault), watch the girls’ event instead. Hannah Grace (Coastal Christian NC) is the clear favorite, and unlike the top boys, she could easily break the meet record of 14-3.25. She comes in with the best mark in the field — and the country, for that matter — of 14-6. The next highest mark is 13-7.25 from Jaicee Jasmer (Sulphur Springs TX). It will be Grace against the bar.

Grace was last year’s USATF U20 champion, and she won the girls high school pole vault at the Millrose Games in February. She’s cleared 14 feet twice this season, and with an A+ day, she could begin to take aim at the national record of 15-1.5 set by Amanda Moll, who now holds the indoor collegiate record.

Boys 60-Meter Hurdles is STACKED

US#1. US#2. US#5. US#6. US#7. All of them will make their way to The Armory this weekend, making the 60 meters arguably the most competitive event of the meet.

Ja’Shaun Lloyd (Corsicana) and Jasiah Rivera (Kingsville), both from Texas, are neck-and-neck at the top of the list with marks of 7.59 and 7.60, respectively. They haven’t faced off this season yet, and they’ve only lined up in the same field a few times throughout their careers. In addition to sprinting, hurdling is a big deal in Texas, and aside from giving us a glimpse into the outdoor season, this race will decide some bragging rights in the Lone Star state.

Joshua Kai-Smith (Gar-Field VA), Tonovila Hicks (Springside Chestnut Hill PA), Le’Ezra Brown (Dudley NC), Isaiah Washington (Prince George VA) and Trevon Foster (The Hill School PA) are also names to watch; all of them have seed times under 7.80, putting the entire top seven within two tenths of a second.

Jessica Oji On Cusp Of History

All she needs is an inch. Oji’s PB in the shot put is 57-4.50, while the national record, held by Alyssa Wilson in 2017, is 57-5.50. The Livingston NJ senior and UPenn commit has thrown 52 feet or farther eight times this season, and she’s improved by nearly six feet from the 2024 outdoor season.

She’ll need a heave of 56-7.50 to break the meet record, which came from Olympian Raven Saunders in 2014.

8.title: Big Air Bubbles Return to the Nike Air Max 95
8.snippet: Big Air Bubbles Return to the Nike Air Max 95: In celebration of the silhouette's 30th anniversary.
8.content:
Name: Nike Air Max 95 Big Bubble “Triple Black”

Colorway: Black/Black

SKU: TBC

MSRP: $175 USD

Release Date: 2025

Where to Buy: Nike

It’s been 30 years since Nike first introduced us to the Air Max 95, a silhouette that has cemented itself in sneaker history as an icon. To celebrate this milestone, the Swoosh has prepared many exciting projects involving the sneaker. Not only is UNDEFEATED rumored to have five colorways on the way, A Ma Maniére and Corteiz are due to drop their latest takes on the model later this season.

Adding to the festivities, Nike is turning back time and revisiting the “Big Bubble” tooling of its original look — an approach the brand previously took with the Air Max 1 in 2023. Presented here in “Triple Black,” the shoe is absent of color, save for a blue tint present at the enlarged Air windows, highlighting its adjusted build that sees the Air bubbles bursting out of the shoe’s standard shape.

At the time of writing, Nike has not yet confirmed when its big bubble version of the Air Max 95 will be returning. Look out for this “Triple Black” colorway to launch later this year via Nike SNKRS and select retailers at a starting price of $175 USD and stay tuned for more updates regarding this throwback take on the model.

9.title: The Jakob A. Ingebrigtsen x Nike Running Collection Releases May 2025
9.snippet: Norwegian runner Jakob A. Ingebrigtsen is teaming up with Nike to launch a collection of colorways on different running sneakers. Find details here.
9.content:
Jakob A. Ingebrigtsen wearing the Nike Alphafly 3

Nike’s roots in performance running have always made it the premier destination for sports professionals, as many of the greatest runners have inked a deal with The Swoosh. For Jakob A. Ingebrigtsen, the Norwegian runner who has set numerous records over the years, including becoming the youngest person, at 16 years old, to run a sub-4-minute mile, the 2000 meter world record in 2023, and recently becoming the first man ever to run a sub-3:30 indoor 1500m race. To honor the young prodigy, who is only 24 years old, Nike will give Jakob a collection of Nike running sneakers.

Working on five different sneakers, including the Pegasus 41, Zoom Victory 2, Zoom Fly 6, Vaporfly 4, and Dragonfly 2 Elite, Jakob has applied a similar color palette that includes medium ash, metallic gold, summit white, light silver, and sail. As of this writing, no images of any of the sneakers exist. However, if history repeats itself, expect to see special logos for Jakob similar to how Nike released Eilud Kipchoge’s Collection of performance runners in 2024. Inspiration from the collection could come from various sources, such as his unique tattoos, his Norweign heritage, or something more personal to Ingebrigtsen that he wants to convey through footwear.

The The Jakob A. Ingebrigtsen x Nike Running Collection will release on May 15, 2025, through Nike and select retailers online and in-store. Available in men’s sizing, the retail price is $150 for the Peg 41, $190 for the Zoom Victory 2, $180 for the Zoom Fly 6, $270 for the Vaporfly 4, and $200 for the Dragonfly 2 Elite. Download the Sole Retriever mobile app to stay updated on the latest releases, raffles, news, and more in the sneaker and streetwear world.

1.title: Nike and Bode Are Dropping Some Sick New Sneakers This Week
1.snippet: Back in December, there wasn't a single “best sneakers of 2024” list that felt complete without Bode Rec. and Nike's collaboration on the Astrograbber...
1.content:
Back in December, there wasn’t a single “best sneakers of 2024” list that felt complete without Bode Rec. and Nike’s collaboration on the Astrograbber silhouette. One of the earliest Nike football shoes, the kicks debuted back in 1974 before disappearing into the Swoosh archives for decades, largely forgotten and lost to the sands of time.

That all changed when designer Emily Adams Bode Aujla decided to put her stamp on them, releasing two colorways in 2024—a creamy off-white knit and a sleek black leather rendition, both adorned with kitschy charms. The shoes made waves and sold out fast (anyone looking to cop a pair on the cheap may need to stick with the Nike Field General, a more accessible football trainer that also saw a re-release last year). But as with any successful sneaker collaboration, Nike and Bode weren’t stopping with just one drop.

Bode Rec. x Nike Astrograbber ‘Green’

In 2025, Bode and Nike are running it back with two brand-new takes on the Astrograbber. First unveiled in February at the inaugural GQ Bowl—Bode Rec.’s spring 2025 runway presentation, hosted by this very publication in New Orleans—the new installments get loud with one colorway and subtle with the other. First up, the ‘Black’ Astrograbber is exactly what it sounds like: all-black version of the shoe with a traditional mesh upper, offset by a gold football lace charm. For those hoping for more of a pop of color, the ‘Green’ spin departs from the neutral tones that have defined the collaboration thus far, opting for a sleek grass-hued leather with a black swoosh, laces, and sole.

2.title: BAIT And .SWOOSH Are Hosting A Live Raffle For The Air Max 1 “Big Head Origins”
2.snippet: Nike's .SWOOSH initiative entered the world of low poly gaming with the Air Max 1 “Big Head Origins”, a concept ostensibly inspired by Donkey Kong Country.
2.content:
This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. The opinions and information provided on this site are original editorial content of Sneaker News.

Nike’s .SWOOSH initiative entered the world of low poly gaming with the Air Max 1 “Big Head Origins”, a concept ostensibly inspired by Donkey Kong Country. Ahead of the much-anticipated launch, Nike has partnered with BAIT to host a special live raffle event for the shoes on March 15th ahead of the wider SNKRS release.

Featuring some key details and ephemera from the Donkey Kong Country game, this Air Max 1 Low Poly struck the perfect nostalgic chord for old school gaming enthusiasts. While there are no direct references to the game or the N64 console, the connections are abundantly clear and the demand has grown considerably since the shoes first revealed itself in mid-February. Retro gaming seems to be a larger focus for this variant of the Air Max 1 as Nike recently dropped an Air Max 1 Low Poly “Adventure”, itself inspired by Tomb Raider.

Those who attend the event at BAIT have a chance to secure a pair ahead of the wider SNKRS launch happening later this month. Doors open at 11 AM PT and winners of the shoe raffle will be announced around 2 PM. In addition to the shoes, BAIT will have a food truck, live music, and even a Nintendo 64 gaming tournament featuring Golden Eye and Mario Kart.

Sign up for the event at BAIT here.

3.title: Nike Air Max 180 “Doernbecher” by Ja’Kai Taylor Joins 20th Anniversary Collection
3.snippet: Designed by Ja'Kai Taylor, a young athlete and social media enthusiast, the sneaker combines bold aesthetics with personal storytelling. Ja'Kai, who has shared...
3.content:
For the first time in the Doernbecher Freestyle Collection’s storied history, the Nike Air Max 180 makes its debut.

Designed by Ja’Kai Taylor, a young athlete and social media enthusiast, the sneaker combines bold aesthetics with personal storytelling. Ja’Kai, who has shared his journey with Type 1 Diabetes through his mother’s TikTok account, channels his vibrant personality and love of sports into this striking design.

The sneaker features a sleek black suede overlay with electrifying lightning bolt graphics, embodying Ja’Kai’s energetic spirit. Beneath this, a gradient midsole fades from electric green to royal blue, adding a dynamic pop of color. Translucent icy outsoles elevate the design, paired with a Jewel Swoosh logo—a first for the Air Max 180.

Ja’Kai personalizes his creation with his name prominently displayed on the heel in the original Air Max 180 typeface, and a soccer crest-inspired hangtag adds an extra layer of uniqueness to the package. The thoughtful details and athletic touches reflect his passion for football, basketball, and soccer, while the bold colors and graphics mirror his journey and creativity.

The Nike Air Max 180 “Doernbecher” by Ja’Kai Taylor is set to release on January 25th, 2025, as part of the 20th annual Doernbecher Freestyle Collection.

Retailing for $160, proceeds from the collection will support the Doernbecher Children’s Hospital, continuing its mission to empower young patients through design and storytelling.

Pairs have restocked on Shoe Palace on March 10th, make sure to grab yours before they are gone again.

4.title: Three Special Nike Air Max 95/97 Hybrid Sneakers Release This Month
4.snippet: Three Special Nike Air Max 95/97 Hybrid Sneakers Release This Month: Presented by the University of Oregon's Ducks of a Feather program in looks of...
4.content:
Name: Ducks of a Feather x Nike Air Max 95/97

Colorways: “Lightning,” “Thunder” and “Storm”

SKUs: TBC

MSRP: TBC

Release Dates: March 21 through March 26

Where to Buy: Flight Club and GOAT

Division Street — the University of Oregon’s marketing program in support of its student-athletes — is responsible for producing many of the school’s special Nike collaborations. It most recently assembled the “What The Duck” Dunks late last year via its Ducks of a Feather brand and is now back with three Air Max 95/97 hybrid colorways.

The three Duck-themed takes pair the tooling of the Air Max 95 with the upper of the Air Max 97, adding to the list of mash-up takes found within the Air Max line. Presented in colorways of “Lightning,” “Thunder” and “Storm,” the first look features a reflective silver and rainbow upper with green glow-in-the-dark airbags. As for its “Thunder” counterpart, a green and gold color shift is accompanied by yellow glow-in-the-dark airbags. Lastly, the “Storm” take on the sneaker pairs gold and green/gold together for its color shifts. Each sneaker carries Ducks of a Feather branding at the heel and tongue, the University of Oregon’s “O” logo at the outsole and a hangtag featuring The Oregon Duck.

As with all of Division Street’s Ducks of a Feather campaigns, proceeds generated from the project will support University of Oregon student-athletes. Release begins with the “Lightning” pair dropping via an in-store raffle at Flight Club Tokyo that ends on March 21. It will later launch via GOAT on March 24 in the Asia-Pacific region. As for the “Thunder” look, it will hit the GOAT app on March 21 in Europe, the Middle East and Africa. Lastly, the “Storm” take will hit Flight Club’s Los Angeles, New York and Miami locations on March 22 before dropping globally via GOAT on March 26 for Air Max Day.

5.title: Deion Sanders’ and LeBron James’ Mashup Nike Sneaker Is Finally Releasing Soon
5.snippet: The Nike LeBron 21 Prime '93, a mashup of Deion Sanders' first signature sneaker and LeBron James' most recent, is set to release in May.
5.content:
All products and services featured are independently chosen by editors. However, Footwear News may receive a commission on orders placed through its retail links, and the retailer may receive certain auditable data for accounting purposes.

More than a year after LeBron James debuted his Nike LeBron 21 “Air DT Max ’96” at the 2024 NBA All-Star Game, a different mashup of a Deion Sanders sneaker will finally release to the public.

The Nike LeBron 21 “Prime ’93” is set to hit stores in May after word of the shoe’s production first surfaced last summer. Rather than his third sneaker, the Air DT Max ’96 featuring claw mark-like stripes, its Sanders’ first signature model, the Air Diamond Turf, that’s now replicated on the upper. It isn’t just a matter of putting the upper of one shoe atop the sole of another, however, as the upper does still maintain the shape of the LeBron 21.

Appearing in the Air Diamond Turf’s original “Atlanta Falcons” colorway, the sneaker comes with a lower cut than the older model and a greater application of black suede. The shape of the strap and mesh windows remain largely the same, with a leather Swoosh now added, and so too does the mustache. Sanders’ dual-sport “Primetime” logo also carries over to the tongue, and the LeBron 21 sole unit remains unchanged with its full-length Cushlon 2.0 foam carrier and forefoot Turbo unit, which should make this pair a lot more comfortable than its more than 30-year-old counterpart.

Watch on FN

James wore his LeBron 21 “Air DT Max ’96” in several colorways but it never released to the public. The two mashup sneakers come after Sanders’ rejoined Nike in 2023 following more than a decade away from the company and a promise that he would never work with it again. Prior to the reunion, the LeBron 15 borrowed the strap from the Air Diamond Turf in 2018.

With the LeBron 22 now the latest in James’ series, a new edition of his prior sneaker releasing comes as something of a rarity for Nike.

The Nike LeBron 21 “Prime ’93” will release in May through the Snkrs app and select third-party retailers. Pricing is set at $180.

Shop More Nike LeBron Styles

6.title: In Ocean Beige, Nike's Classic Air Max Brings Sand to Your Feet
6.snippet: Nike's Khaki Air Max 180 sneaker is a gradient beauty that might just take the Air Max 180 shoe to the top of the Air Max sneaker fandom.
6.content:
Nike is further expanding the stylistic allure of its classic Air Max 180 sneaker with a new oceanic colorway that's basically spring break for your feet.

Nike’s beachy "Light Khaki" Air Max 180 shoe sports a gradient color treatment that begins at its toe and fades across the sneaker, from a deep sandy tan that affects the suede paneling into a light ocean blue that hits the upper's mesh.

Fittingly, this Air Max 180 also has a sunny yellow outsole that keeps the coastal vibes above going with a splash of blue. Beachy, indeed.

Now, it's still early days but 2025 feels like the year of the Air Max 180. Or, at the very least, the year of the Air Max 180's rebrand.

Your Highsnobiety privacy settings have blocked this Instagram post. Enable All Media Manage consent Privacy policy

In January, Nike's Air Max 180 was struck by lightning with an electrifying new design courtesy of Kai Taylor, a patient at Doernbecher Children's Hospital who created his own Air Max 180 as a part of Nike's Doernbecher Freestyle collection.

Your Highsnobiety privacy settings have blocked this Instagram post. Enable All Media Manage consent Privacy policy

And earlier in March, London record label Apron Records released a texturally astonishing Air Max 180 complete with a furry tongue, suede underlays, and cozy-fied fuzzy laces that transformed the classic sneaker into a modern looker.

Clearly, Nike is ramping up for Air Max Day ahead of schedule (it's March 26, BTW, mark your calendars).

Compared to those two stellar stompers, the "Light Khaki" Air Max 180, available for $150 on Nike's website later this spring, is pretty demure.

But with its beautifully beachy colorway, the sneaker fits right in with this small but mighty lineup of Air Max 180 sneakers poised to take over the Air Max kingdom this year.

Your Highsnobiety privacy settings have blocked this Tiktok. Enable All Media Manage consent Privacy policy

Ok, so the competition might be a bit too stiff to make that happen right now, but it's not a reach to say the Air Max 180 is climbing up the ranks, or at least providing a nice beachy alternative.

8.title: Nike Drops Retro-Inspired Dri-FIT ADV MLB Jerseys Honoring Baseball Icons
8.snippet: Nike has just dropped a new collection of Men's Nike Dri-FIT ADV MLB Limited Jerseys, celebrating some of baseball's most legendary players with a mix of...
8.content:
Nike has just dropped a new collection of Men's Nike Dri-FIT ADV MLB Limited Jerseys, celebrating some of baseball’s most legendary players with a mix of classic Cooperstown designs and modern performance technology. The lineup pays tribute to some of the greatest names in MLB history, blending heritage aesthetics with Nike’s high-performance Dri-FIT ADV fabric to keep fans comfortable while repping their favorite icons.

This latest drop includes multiple jerseys, each honoring an all-time great:

Ken Griffey Jr. (Seattle Mariners) – Available in both classic blue and white, bringing back the iconic look of "The Kid" during his electrifying days in Seattle.

Darryl Strawberry (New York Mets) – A throwback to the Mets’ championship-winning era, representing one of the most feared hitters of the '80s.

Jackie Robinson (Brooklyn Dodgers) – Offered in both white and grey, celebrating the trailblazer who broke baseball’s color barrier and redefined the game.

Babe Ruth (New York Yankees) – A nod to the golden era of the Yankees and the legend who changed baseball forever.

Each jersey is designed with Nike’s Dri-FIT ADV technology, ensuring breathability and moisture-wicking comfort for all-day wear. The Vapor Premier chassis enhances mobility while maintaining the jersey’s vintage aesthetic. Sublimated recycled twill wordmarks and numbers complete the look, delivering an authentic game-worn feel.

The Nike Dri-FIT ADV MLB Limited Jerseys are available now on Nike.com. With a perfect blend of nostalgia and performance innovation, these throwback jerseys won’t last long—secure yours while they’re still in stock.

For more on the Swoosh, Nigel Sylvesters "Brick By Brick" Air Jordan 4 collection is releasing on March 14, 2025.

0.title: Nike and Bode Rec. Foster Timeless Sport Style with New Expressions of the Astrograbber
0.snippet: Nike and Bode Rec. are unveiling a new campaign rooted in their shared appreciation of sport heritage and mission to serve all athletes, refreshing the...
0.content:
Nike and Bode Rec. are unveiling a new campaign rooted in their shared appreciation of sport heritage and mission to serve all athletes, refreshing the iconic Nike and Bode Rec. Astrograbber silhouette in two head-turning colorways.

Nike athlete Ja’Marr Chase dons the revived turf shoe in a campaign awash in historic sport-style influence and tailored for contemporary resonance, representing an homage to both the silhouette’s football roots and its modern appeal.

Captured in New Orleans days ahead of the runway debut for both Chase and the new Astrograbber colorways, the campaign further cements the classic gridiron look as a contemporary sportswear staple.

“Bode Rec. is a line devoted to the history and evolution of athletic apparel, with a personal tie to football inspired by the time my dad spent playing the sport in high school and college,” says Emily Adams Bode Aujla, Bode founder and designer. “A lot of my inspiration for the restyled Astrograbber and new campaign is drawn from the anecdotal stories I learned when I visited Nike World Headquarters of Nike employee No. 1 Jeff Johnson and of Bill Bowerman, who created Nike’s famous waffle sole using his wife’s waffle iron, reminding of the handcrafted elements of early Nike footwear.”

The Bode Rec. take on the Astrograbber — which originally debuted in 1974 on the heels of Nike’s famed Waffle Trainer — upgrades the utilitarian turf shoe to a timeless look, with two new colorways celebrating the silhouette's enduring appeal.

A black, woven textile design is the perfect complement to any sport-style look, while a green, leather style takes inspiration from a pair of Bowerman’s homemade, hand-dyed waffle joggers that Bode Aujla spotted during her visit to the Department of Nike Archives.

Both looks sport metallic gold shoelace charms and come styled in custom packaging and branding that highlights the partnership between Nike and Bode Rec.

“Working with Nike to reimagine the Astrograbber means partnering with such a historic American brand, which really embodies the inspiration behind Bode Rec.,” says Bode Aujla. “Much like the Nike philosophy, I believe sport and recreation are vital to our growth as individuals, and that shines through in our new colorways and campaign.”

The campaign, shot by Eduardo Cerruti and Stephanie Draime, features antiques collected during Bode Aujla’s travels to Tokyo while launching the initial Nike and Bode Rec. campaign — calling to mind the universal appeal of the silhouette.

“The new Astrograbber colorways are timeless and easy to wear, giving the next generation new ways to add a throwback, vintage style to their look,” says Chase. “Nike and Bode Rec. hit all the right notes with their first collection last year, and these colorways take their partnership to another level.”

Both colorways will be available March 14 at bode.com, Bode retail locations in Los Angeles and New York City, and a new Bode boutique in Paris. The black colorway will be available on SNKRS and at select Nike and Bode Rec. retail partners March 21.

1.title: Phil Knight's Division Street Unveils Nike Air Max 95/97 Hybrid in Oregon Ducks Colors for Air Max Day 2025
1.snippet: Phil Knight's Division Street's Ducks of A Feather initiative has unveiled a Nike Air Max 95/97 hybrid design for the first time ever in honor of Air Max...
1.content:
For the uninformed, Division Street is an organization founded by Phil Knight and other members of the University of Oregon's community. It sets out to empower student-athletes at the school, facilitating deals relating to their Name, Image, and Likeness (NIL). To this end, the group raises money with limited-edition, Oregon Ducks-inspired Nike footwear. Last year's Air Max 1 emerged in a similar color palette and with nods to the Pacific Northwestern university all-throughout the shoe. Air Max Day 2025's offering does the same, but its vibrant green tones also fall in line with the Air Max 95's original 'Neon' look, which celebrates its 30th anniversary this year.

A representative of GOAT shared with House of Heatº that the three color schemes of the mish-mash design are 'Lightning,' 'Thunder,' and 'Storm.' Dutton unveiled the 'Storm' offering last week, whereas an official press release from the after-market platform shared detailed shots of the other two styles. The accompanying pairs feature similar Ducks of A Feather-appropriate details, and color palettes that breathe new life into the hybrid design. Glow-on-the-dark Airbags round out the trio.

The 'Lightning' pair will be available via raffle beginning on Saturday, March 15. In-store pick-up will be offered at Flight Club Tokyo starting Friday, March 21. Pairs will also be available via the GOAT app across the Asia-Pacific region beginning on Monday, March 24.

The Air Max 95/97 'Thunder' will be offered to Europe, Middle East, and Africa regions via the GOAT app on Friday, March 21.

Finally, the project's 'Storm' style will be available at Flight Club New York, Los Angeles, and Miami on Saturday, March 22. Pairs will become available globally via the GOAT app on Wednesday, March 26, in celebration of Air Max Day 2025.

For more from the Swoosh conglomerate, check out the Nigel Sylvester Jordan 4 'Brick by Brick' collection set to land on Friday, March 14.

2.title: Devin Booker Honors Another Past Suns Guard With The Nike Book 1 “Penny V”
2.snippet: Devin Booker's Nike Book 1 PE universe remains vast, pulling in inspiration from his surroundings in Arizona as well as the Phoenix Suns franchise history.
2.content:
This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. The opinions and information provided on this site are original editorial content of Sneaker News.

Devin Booker’s Nike Book 1 PE universe remains vast, pulling in inspiration from his surroundings in Arizona as well as the Phoenix Suns franchise history. Recently, he wore an homage to two-time MVP Steve Nash inspired by the Cradle Rock; now he turns his attention to another prominent member of the storied backcourt.

Although Penny Hardaway’s career didn’t live up to its potential due to injury, he’s had an immeasurable influence in sneaker culture through his signature line as well as his association with the Air Foamposite One. This PE, however, references his fifth signature shoe, the Air Penny V.

1 of 6

Dropping years after the signature athlete’s retirement, the Air Penny V model was unique in that it was designed as a basketball shoe, but mean for off-court wear. Dropping right at the center of Nike Basketball’s stranglehold on the sneaker game, the fifth Penny model released in a variety of trending colorways as well as nods to his past team affiliations. This version references his post-Orlando era when he formed one-half of the star-studded backcourt alongside Jason Kidd.

While there were several Air Penny colorways bearing the Suns thematic, the gradient pattern is the evidence we need to prove that these are in fact a spin off the 2012 release. Booker will be wearing this PE during the Suns/Mavs game this afternoon.

3.title: Corteiz Unveils Fourth Nike Air Max 95 Collaboration in "Honey Blacks"
3.snippet: Earlier today, Corteiz founder Clint419 took to Instagram to unveil an exclusive first look at the “Honey Blacks.” Taking cues from the bold contrast of a...
3.content:
Name: Corteiz x Nike Air Max 95 “Honey Black”

Colorway: “Black/Tour Yellow”

SKU: FB2709-003

MSRP: $190 USD

Release Date: April 2024

Where to Buy: Nike

Update: London-based streetwear powerhouse Corteiz has officially announced the fourth installment of its highly sought-after Nike Air Max 95 collaboration. Earlier today, Corteiz founder Clint419 took to Instagram to unveil an exclusive first look at the “Honey Blacks.” Taking cues from the bold contrast of a bumblebee, the sneaker showcases a sleek black leather upper accented with vibrant yellow details. Crafted with premium all-black leather, murdered-out soles and “Tour Yellow” highlights on the branding and Air supports, the design seamlessly merges streetwear aesthetics with high-performance functionality. Unlike previous versions, this iteration ditches patterned liners in favor of a sleek, minimalist black interior, elevating its refined appeal.

View this post on Instagram A post shared by LUNDUN. (@clint419)

1 of 9 2 of 9 3 of 9 4 of 9 5 of 9 6 of 9 7 of 9 8 of 9 9 of 9

Original Story (September 10, 2025): Looking back at 2023, Corteiz was responsible for several of the sneaker scene’s biggest moments. The brand filled the streets of cities around the world with people clamoring for one of its Nike Air Max 95 colorways. Now, while a collaboration involving the Nike Air Trainer Huarache was rumored to release this season, we suddenly have official imagery of a fourth Corteiz x Nike Air Max 95.

This take on the Air Max 95 involves an all-black build that is accented by “Tour Yellow” notes. This elevated take on the sneaker revisits the design of its predecessors, so you can look forward to its layered construction sporting yellow Corteiz branding at the lateral toe, heel, tongue and outsole. The pair also again features London’s coordinates at the heel, as well as a netting at the uppermost layer of the upper.

At the time of writing, neither Nike nor Corteiz have shared any release details regarding this “Tour Yellow” take on the Air Max 95. Stay tuned for updates from the duo as we currently expect this new pair to arrive on shelves by the end of the year via Corteiz and Nike SNKRS around the $190 USD price point that its predecessors had.

4.title: Capital Allocation Trends At NIKE (NYSE:NKE) Aren't Ideal
4.snippet: If we want to find a stock that could multiply over the long term, what are the underlying trends we should look for...
4.content:
If we want to find a stock that could multiply over the long term, what are the underlying trends we should look for? In a perfect world, we'd like to see a company investing more capital into its business and ideally the returns earned from that capital are also increasing. If you see this, it typically means it's a company with a great business model and plenty of profitable reinvestment opportunities. So while NIKE (NYSE:NKE) has a high ROCE right now, lets see what we can decipher from how returns are changing.

What Is Return On Capital Employed (ROCE)?

For those that aren't sure what ROCE is, it measures the amount of pre-tax profits a company can generate from the capital employed in its business. The formula for this calculation on NIKE is:

Return on Capital Employed = Earnings Before Interest and Tax (EBIT) ÷ (Total Assets - Current Liabilities)

0.22 = US$5.9b ÷ (US$38b - US$11b) (Based on the trailing twelve months to November 2024).

Thus, NIKE has an ROCE of 22%. That's a fantastic return and not only that, it outpaces the average of 13% earned by companies in a similar industry.

See our latest analysis for NIKE

NYSE:NKE Return on Capital Employed March 9th 2025

In the above chart we have measured NIKE's prior ROCE against its prior performance, but the future is arguably more important. If you'd like, you can check out the forecasts from the analysts covering NIKE for free.

What Can We Tell From NIKE's ROCE Trend?

In terms of NIKE's historical ROCE movements, the trend isn't fantastic. To be more specific, while the ROCE is still high, it's fallen from 29% where it was five years ago. On the other hand, the company has been employing more capital without a corresponding improvement in sales in the last year, which could suggest these investments are longer term plays. It's worth keeping an eye on the company's earnings from here on to see if these investments do end up contributing to the bottom line.

The Key Takeaway

To conclude, we've found that NIKE is reinvesting in the business, but returns have been falling. And investors may be recognizing these trends since the stock has only returned a total of 10% to shareholders over the last five years. As a result, if you're hunting for a multi-bagger, we think you'd have more luck elsewhere.

NIKE could be trading at an attractive price in other respects, so you might find our free intrinsic value estimation for NKE on our platform quite valuable.

If you'd like to see other companies earning high returns, check out our free list of companies earning high returns with solid balance sheets here.

5.title: Devin Booker debuts Penny Hardaway inspired colorway of Nike Book 1s
5.snippet: Devin Booker paid homage to Phoenix Suns legend Penny Hardaway with his newest Nike Book 1s colorway.
5.content:
Devin Booker is always one to pay homage to legends, and his newest colorway of his signature shoe sure does it again.

Booker rocked a Penny Hardaway inspired edition of his Nike Book 1s against the Dallas Mavericks Sunday in Dallas. The new edition, the Nike Book 1 “Penny V”, features the same logo that Hardaway used on his signature shoes on the tongue, and has the classic Suns colors that adorned the Air Penny V model across the midsole and outsole.

This new colorway in particular feels like a longtime coming, too.

When Booker’s signature shoe first dropped last year, his promotional video featured the iconic Lil’ Penny. Booker called the former Suns’ signature shoe campaign one of his favorites growing up in the early 2000s.

“It writes itself, no pun intended,” Booker said to Arizona Sports in Feb. 2024. “I think right when they told me that I’d be a signature athlete, I started thinking of all the guys’s names that have been one. And the one that sticks with me most is Penny (Hardaway). I always thought that the name Penny was the craziest as a signature athlete.”

Follow @Lance_Hartz

6.title: Nike SB's Killer AJ4 Hybrid Skate Sneaker Is Back In Beautiful Blue
6.snippet: Nike SB's beautifully blue Air Jordan 4 sneaker in "Summit White Navy" is a mix of all that's good in skateboarding & basketball.
6.content:
Nike's most-hyped skate shoe is adding a new crisp colorway to the party. Informed by streetwear’s core aesthetics of skateboarding and basketball, Nike's SB Jordan 4 sneaker was an instant sell-out when it first dropped in 2023 in a minty "Pine Green."

Earlier this year, the Nike SB family added the "Midnight Navy" SB Jordan 4 to its collection of wild combo shoes, and the brand is doubling down on giving us the blues with the new "Summit White Navy" sneaker colorway.

Like its Nike SB x AJ4 brethren, the chunky sneaker is predominately cut from white leather but is accented by a blue heel and midsole and gray suede on its toebox.

The Air Jordan 4 is one of the most celebrated silhouettes in the Jordan universe that I’d argue is only bested by the AJ1, and its low-top build and chunkier sole make it the perfect base model for an experimental skate shoe.

Your Highsnobiety privacy settings have blocked this Instagram post. Enable All Media Manage consent Privacy policy

But whereas the OG AJ4 was designed for on-court performance and adopted by style crusaders after the fact, the SB Jordan 4 needed a facelift in order to fit the unique demands of skateboarding.

Your Highsnobiety privacy settings have blocked this Tiktok. Enable All Media Manage consent Privacy policy

These updates take the form of a narrower toebox and comparatively less boxy build, but the overall shape is basically unchanged.

According to some sneakerheads, the shoe looks barely changed and thus still has the same sartorial prowess as the original AJ4.

As for its skateability, well, that’s your call.

Releasing on Nike's website March 18 for an estimated $225, the Nike SB x AJ4 "Summit White Navy" will not grant immediately the Nike SB AJ4 the same cultural weight as the classic AJ4.

Your Highsnobiety privacy settings have blocked this Reddit thread. Enable All Media Manage consent Privacy policy

Still, its star is quickly reaching supernova status and it has the sell-out stats to prove it.

7.title: Devin Booker’s Nike Book 1 PE Pays Homage To The Air Penny V "Suns"
7.snippet: Devin Booker blends Phoenix Suns history with his signature Nike Book 1 PE. His latest player-exclusive sneaker pays tribute to Penny Hardaway's Air Penny V...
7.content:
Devin Booker blends Phoenix Suns history with his signature Nike Book 1 PE. His latest player-exclusive sneaker pays tribute to Penny Hardaway’s Air Penny V “Suns” colorway. This design honors Hardaway’s influence on the court and in sneaker culture.

- Advertisement -

Although injuries shortened Hardaway’s career, his impact on basketball sneakers remains strong. He is best known for the Nike Air Foamposite One and his Air Penny signature line. The Air Penny V “Suns,” released in 2012, combined performance with street-ready aesthetics. Its bold colorway and sleek design made it a standout in sneaker history.

Booker unveiled his Nike Book 1 PE during a Phoenix Suns vs. Dallas Mavericks game. The shoe mirrors the gradient midsole of the Air Penny V “Suns,” transitioning from deep purple to vibrant orange, reflecting the Suns’ signature colors. The upper features black and grey tones with a Penny-style logo on the tongue, emphasizing the tribute.

Nike continues to blend past and present with Booker’s Book 1 PE collection. Hardaway’s Penny line was known for futuristic technology and sleek aesthetics, while Booker’s Nike Book 1 combines modern performance with vintage-inspired style. This balance keeps basketball heritage alive while appealing to today’s sneaker culture.

For Suns fans and sneaker enthusiasts, this player-exclusive edition represents both history and evolution. It honors Hardaway’s contributions to Phoenix while showcasing Booker’s growing influence in the NBA.

Though this exclusive sneaker will not hit retail shelves, it remains a significant piece of basketball sneaker history. Fans can only hope for future releases that capture this nostalgic yet fresh aesthetic.

0.title: Shoe Review: Nike Air Zoom Vapor 12
0.snippet: What's old is new with the Nike Air Zoom Vapor 12. The shoe brings back the adaptive lacing system that was a popular and effective feature of past models.
0.content:
Nike Air Zoom Vapor 12

Price: $170

Weight: 14.6 oz. (men’s 10.5); 11.9 oz. (women’s 8.5)

Size Run: 6-13, 14, 15 (men); 5-12 (women)

What’s New

What’s old is new with the Nike Air Zoom Vapor 12. The shoe brings back the adaptive lacing system that was a popular and effective feature of past models. Additionally, the midfoot plastic shank returns to give the shoe stability while lowering the weight. A reworked mesh upper and new rubber compound on the outsole also make the shoe lighter and more responsive without sacrificing durability. All the callbacks and additions are designed to rediscover more of the quickness and explosiveness the franchise is known for.

What Works

If a shoe is called the Vapor, it should conjure feelings of speed and fast footwork. And that’s primarily what this Nike line has established, and why it has been attractive to serious competitors. However, the outgoing Vapor 11 bucked that trend. It featured greater sturdiness and support, but was more truck than racecar. Its heavy-handed performance was a departure from the shoe’s past formula and it brought mixed results.

The new Vapor 12 taps back into the franchise’s core principles. It’s lighter, sleeker and more aerodynamic than the outgoing model. The profile and features are very much in step with past favorites such as the Vapor 9/9.5 and Vapor X. Fans of those and other speed shoes will be pleased that this one recaptures the traditional Vapor vibe.

1.title: First Look at the A Ma Maniére x Nike Air Max 95 "Hand Wash Cold"

A Ma Maniére is celebrating its 30th anniversary with a new exclusive Nike Air Max 95 collaboration. Refining the aesthetic of the shoe with premium luxe materials, founder James Whitner of A Ma Maniére sees the label “Hand Wash Cold” as more than just a set of instructions. 2.title: Where To Buy The Nike Air Max Uptempo “Mystic Teal”
2.snippet: The Nike Air Max Uptempo Mystic Teal is set to release on March 9th, 2025. Tap in to see official details + store list info.
2.content:
This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. The opinions and information provided on this site are original editorial content of Sneaker News.

A specific era of Nike Basketball is gaining momentum as of late, so there’s no better time for the Swoosh to bring back some of the most memorable hits of that time-frame. In addition to icons like the Air Foamposite One and Air Flightposite One, Nike is bringing back the Air Max Uptempo “Mystic Teal”, the debut colorway of the first basketball sneaker in Nike history to utilize a visible full-length Max Air unit.

Then, it was a technological marvel on a sneaker cushioning standpoint. Today, it exudes a nostalgic excellence. The bulky frame, simple white/black colorway, and pop of color on the cushioning system screams the mid-1990s-a time when Nike could not miss with any of their designs.

1 of 4

The “Mystic Teal” nor the model itself isn’t exactly tied to one athlete. Scottie Pippen is the first to come to mind when considering the Uptempo series, but in late 1995 and into 1996, everyone from the NBA ranks to middle school hoops wanted to rock these.

On March 9th, Nike is officially bringing back the Air Max Uptempo “Mystic Teal”; beneath the gallery of images is a comprehensive store list detailing exactly where you can buy them at 10 AM ET. MSRP is set at $165.

4.title: Nike Combined Two of Its Most Iconic Air Max Sneakers for New Oregon Ducks Shoes
4.snippet: University of Oregon NIL collective Division Street is teaming with Nike for a new Air Max 95/97 'Ducks of a Feather' sneaker collaboration.
4.content:
All products and services featured are independently chosen by editors. However, Footwear News may receive a commission on orders placed through its retail links, and the retailer may receive certain auditable data for accounting purposes.

After delivering two Air Max 1s and three “What the Duck” Dunk Lows in 2024, Nike and the University of Oregon’s Ducks of a Feather brand are teaming up yet again for Air Max Day 2025.

Timed to launch for Nike’s annual Air Max celebration in the month of March is a new Oregon Ducks-themed sneaker which combines two of the Beaverton, Ore.-based sportswear brand’s most iconic retro running shoes.

Watch on FN

Shared in imagery by @ad__sneaks is a previously unseen Division Street x Nike collaboration fusing the upper of the Air Max 97 with the midsole of the Air Max 95. The mash-up Nike Air Max 95/97 is coated in an iridescent sheen which contains shades of green, gold and yellow and a tinge of purple. Overall, it’s a look reminiscent of UK rapper Skepta’s Air Tuned Max-inspired Air Max 97 Ultra collaboration from 2017, but the upcoming Oregon pair opts for a more green-dominant color.

Division Street x Nike Air Max 95/97 ‘Ducks of a Feather’ (lateral). @ad__sneaks

While Nike has issued numerous Air Max hybrid sneakers throughout the years, this is the first time the upper of the Air Max 97 has been combined with the midsole of the Air Max 95. Perhaps most famously, the Air Max 97 upper was mixed with the midsole of the Air Max 1 in a 2018 collaboration with designer Sean Wotherspoon.

Oregon’s Ducks of a Feather is an apparel brand backed by the school’s NIL collective, Division Street. Led by Nike co-founder Phil Knight and other Oregon alumni, Division Street was founded in 2021 with an aim to help student athletes monetize their brands. In 2022, Division Street launched Ducks of a Feather, which has since released sneaker collaborations and apparel with Nike.

Despite the arrival of images, release details for the Division Street x Nike Air Max 95/97 remain uncertain. The pair is expected to coincide with Air Max Day on March 26, but it’s possible the sneakers could arrive on a different day this month. Similarly, retail pricing has not been confirmed, but like previous Division Street x Nikes, it’s likely the collaboration will be released through GOAT. This story will be updated once the release details are officially announced.

Nike is preparing for Air Max Day 2025 with an exclusive drop. The Division Street x Nike Air Max 95/97 “Ducks of a Feather” blends two iconic models into a fresh hybrid design. Backed by Division Street, an Oregon Ducks NIL collective, this release celebrates the university’s strong connection with Nike.

- Advertisement -

The sneaker features an Air Max 97 upper with black mesh and iridescent green leather overlays. It sits atop the Air Max 95 sole unit, creating a bold fusion. Neon green accents highlight the mini Swoosh, Air unit, and outsole traction zones. This color scheme pays tribute to the Ducks’ signature look.

Nike adds premium details throughout the design. Lenticular tongue badges display “DOAF” branding, while University of Oregon logos appear on the insoles and outsoles. “Ducks of a Feather” text decorates the heel pull tabs. Reflective and shimmering hues create a color-shifting effect, making the sneaker eye-catching.

Nike Air Max 95/97 Ducks of a Feather Release Date

The Division Street x Nike Air Max 95/97 “Ducks of a Feather” will release on March 26, 2025, for Air Max Day. Division Street’s past collaborations released via GOAT and Flight Club. A similar drop strategy is likely for this exclusive release. Stay tuned for official pricing and additional details as Air Max Day nears.

Nike continues to honor its deep ties with the University of Oregon. This collaboration merges innovation, school spirit, and sneaker culture into one standout design. Fans of Air Max and Oregon athletics won’t want to miss this drop. Keep an eye out for more updates as the launch date approaches.

0.title: The Nike Vaporfly 4 Is a Drastic Departure from the Vaporfly 3. Is That a Good Thing?
0.snippet: We review the Nike Vaporfly 4 for its fit, ride, and performance. Running in the shoe set to release March 1 revealed some surprising changes.
0.content:
New perk: Easily find new routes and hidden gems, upcoming running events, and more near you. Your weekly Local Running Newsletter has everything you need to lace up! Subscribe today.

It’s no exaggeration to say that the Nike Vaporfly 4% was one of the most groundbreaking running shoes ever created. When it debuted commercially in 2017, it stood apart from every other racing shoe on the market, making claims that it could increase running economy by 4% (which, lab results showed, turned out to be true). From its futuristic thick-soled design to the loud, almost obnoxious slapping sound it made with each stride, the Vaporfly 4% sent shockwaves through the running shoe industry.

Fast forward eight years, the Vaporfly has been through four main updates since its inception. Except for the first update, which only brought a new upper, each Vaporfly update has been a complete overhaul that, for better or worse, dramatically changed how the Vaporfly line felt.

The lack of consistency from model to model makes it difficult to know whether you’ll like the latest version enough to make the $260 investment. Fortunately, we received a pre-release sample of the Nike Vaporfly 4 and we’ve been testing its fit, ride, and performance. Before you go and drop your hard-earned cash on Nike’s latest super shoe, here’s what you need to know.

Nike Vaporfly 4 Review

(Photo: Cory Smith)

Weight: 5.9 oz (men’s 8.5/women’s 10)

Stack Heights: 35 mm (heel); 29 mm (forefoot)

Heel-to-toe Drop: 6 mm

Price: $260 (The Nike Vaporfly 4 release date is set for March 14, 2025, at Nike.com and select retailers)

Shop Men’s

Shop Women’s

At a Glance

Pros

Over an ounce lighter than the Vaporfly 3

Better ground sensitivity and responsiveness

Better-fitting upper

Cons

Less cushioned

Not ideal for beginners

No longer suitable for marathons for many runners

What’s New

Lightest Vaporfly yet, weighting 5.9 ounces for a men’s 8.5 and women’s 10

Slightly lower stack height at 35 mm in the heel and 29 mm in the forefoot

A redesigned carbon fiber plate that is three degrees steeper, designed to enhance propulsion and efficiency

Drop is reduced from 8 mm to 6 mm

New last designed to improve fit

New engineered mesh upper with stretchy sawtooth laces

Redesigned midsole geometry removes excess material and cuts weight

First Impressions

Given Nike’s history of significant updates to its premier racing shoes, I approached testing the Vaporfly 4 with an open mind. At first glance, it’s easy to tell this is a completely different shoe from its predecessor. Visually, it has a similar silhouette as the Alphafly 3 and Air Zoom 6.

Taking them out of the box, I was immediately struck by how light they were. Weighing in at a mere 5.9 ounces for a men’s size 8.5 or women’s 10, they are over an ounce lighter than the Vaporfly 3. This places them as the second-lightest carbon fiber super shoe we’ve tested, behind the Adidas Adizero Adios Pro Evo 1, which weighs 4.9 ounces for a men’s size 9.

(Photo: Cory Smith)

As I laced them up for my first test run, I noticed they had a much better fit than the Vaporfly 3. Nike built the Vaporfly 4 off a new last that’s more accommodating through the arch. The engineered mesh upper wrapped my medium-width foot perfectly.

This secure and comforting feeling only got better as I laced the stretchy sawtooth laces up. While stretchy laces can sometimes be frustrating, Nike nailed them. The ridged sawtooth design really provided the bite needed to counterbalance the stretchiness. The overall fit, security, and sense of being dialed into a shoe is Nike’s best execution yet and perhaps the best I’ve ever tested. I hope we see a similar system in future Nike racing shoes.

Heading out for my run, my first impression was that the Vaporfly 4 felt a lot like the original Vaporfly NEXT%. It didn’t have the deep, trampoline-like rebound or plush cushioning of the Vaporfly 3. That makes sense, as the Vaporfly 4 features the lowest stack height (35—29mm) of any Vaporfly to date.

After getting used to today’s trend of thicker, softer shoes, the reduced stack took some adjustment. However, as I picked up the pace and drove through my toes, I noticed a welcome connection with the ground, rather than the “soft-foam sinking feeling” as with most super shoes.

What the Vaporfly 4 lacked in cushioning, it more than made up for in responsiveness. With its sleek profile, ultra-lightweight design, and strategic use of Nike’s highest energy-returning ZoomX foam, it’s clear this shoe was built for speed—not marathon-paced speed (at least for mortals), but the kind of explosiveness needed for 5K to mile efforts.

Regaining the Vaporfly’s Unique Identity

While some may be disappointed by a less-cushioned Vaporfly, this move makes a lot of sense in relation to Nike’s racing shoe lineup. When the Vaporfly 3 became more cushioned, it lost some of its responsiveness, leanness, and raw speed. It became more of a half marathon and marathon shoe for most runners, encroaching on the already built-for-the-marathon Alphafly. This shift not only made the Vaporfly somewhat redundant, it also left a gap in Nike’s racing shoe lineup for shorter distance races ranging from the road mile to 10k. Those who wanted a more responsive shoe for shorter distances either had to opt for the carbon-fiberless Streakfly or deal with a rather bulky Vaporfly 3 or Alphafly 3.

As Nike continues to refine the Vaporfly, it evolves—not always in a predictable way, which can be frustrating. If you loved the original Vaporfly NEXT%, chances are you didn’t feel the same about the softer, more cushioned Vaporfly 3—evidenced by several Nike athletes still racing in the NEXT%. If you were a fan of the Vaporfly NEXT%, I think you’d like the Vaporfly 4.

Unfortunately for those who love the Vaporfly 3, the Vaporfly 4 shares very little in common. If you’re a fan of the Vaporfly 3, now’s the time to stock up.

The good news for most of us is that the Vaporfly is returning to its leaner, more responsive roots that earned it legend status. It’s lighter, lower to the ground, and less cushioned, making it ideal for shorter races ranging from the mile to the half marathon, and, for those that can handle a more responsive, less thick-soled cushioned shoe over the distance, the marathon. If the Streakfly had a carbon plate, this is what it would feel like.

Nike Vaporfly 4: Who Is It for?

I’ve been testing super shoes since they first entered the market and have run in every super shoe made since. One thing is clear—response rates vary widely between runners and shoes. A model that works wonders for one runner might offer little to no benefit for another (as we showed with our super shoe showdown). The Vaporfly 4 is no exception. It’s a tool designed for a very specific purpose, for a particular runner.

As a running coach who frequently recommends shoes to my clients, here’s what I’d tell them regarding the Vaporfly 4: For the average runner, this isn’t the ideal choice for a marathon—or even a half marathon; its lower stack doesn’t provide the bouncy, leg-saving cushioning as most of today’s super shoes. Instead, I’d strongly suggest the more cushioned and bouncy Alphafly 3. In fact, I’d probably recommend less-experienced runners use the Alphafly 3 for short-distance races.

However, for the more experienced runners with an efficient, powerful stride, the Nike Vaporfly 4 shines at distances from the road mile up to the 10K and, perhaps even the half marathon.

2.title: The Diamond Turf High Steps Onto The Nike LeBron 21 “Prime ’93”
2.snippet: The Nike LeBron 21 captures an ode to the Diamond Turf 93 and Prime Time footwear as a whole. Click in for release info.
2.content:
This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. The opinions and information provided on this site are original editorial content of Sneaker News.

LeBron James’ love for Deion Sanders’ work at Nike is no secret. While in 2024, the Air DT Max ’96 returned to shelves and James poured out some on-foot tributes in accordance, he chalked off a colorway of his LeBron 15 with homages to Deion, far before any cross-marketing opportunities were at hand. Cut to the current retro for the Air Diamond Turf and the King is issuing a public response, the Nike LeBron 21 “Prime ’93.”

You can still spot signature touches from the LeBron 21 proper intact, like the ridged midsole design and the overall shape, but the silhouette does a lot of remodeling for a precise tribute Deion Sanders shoes. The midfoot strap is the most significant new inclusion, keeping the translucent mesh at the quarter in accordance. However, new overlay panels stretch from the toe to the heel, culminating in the amoeba-like branding tag at the rear. It’s only fitting that the shoe’s most iconic colorway is also adapted, with the Falcons’ black, red, and white faithfully applied on the near-hybrid shoe.

1 of 5

Of course, the release for the Nike LeBron 21 “Prime ’93” does make for some unorthodox overlap between the King’s latest in the Nike LeBron 22 and the model that directly preceded it. As mentioned, however, many of his recent nods to Deion’s shoes have come on the LeBron 21 specifically, making this arguably the most sensible option in his catalog.

The Nike LeBron 21 “Diamond Turf” is expected to hit shelves in May 2025, carrying a $180 sticker price. Catch detailed retail images included below and keep an eye on our Sneaker Release Dates page for a more concrete date once it comes.

Additional Retailer Images

3.title: A Tiffany & Co.-Reminiscent 'Dusty Cactus' Animates the Nike Air Max TL 2.5
3.snippet: A Tiffany & Co. reminiscent 'Dusty Cactus' has landed on the Nike Air Max TL 2.5 ahead of Spring 2025. The pair is priced at $180.
3.content:
With the Swoosh's fictional Air Max Day celebration inching closer, the brand has prepared dozens of new styles within its visible Air lineup. The latest arrives in the form of an Air Max TL 2.5 animated by a Tiffany & Co.-reminiscent 'Dusty Cactus.'

While not an official collaboration by any means, the sneaker's latest bluish hue evokes imagery of the famed New York City label's signature hue. The aquatic tone breaks up the reserved nature of the pair's greyscale execution, while seemingly harkening back to the Air Max 93's debut look. The 'Dusty Cactus' tone takes on profile swooshes and the full-length Air Max unit underfoot. Sections across the reliable traction also indulge in the titular blue hue, falling in line with some of the brand's other retro running offerings.

The Air Max TL 2.5 is expected to land via Nike.com and other retailers before June for $180. In the meantime, enjoy detailed product shots courtesy of JD Sports below.

For more from the Swoosh conglomerate, check out the Nigel Sylvester Jordan 4 'Brick by Brick' collaboration landing on Friday, March 14.

4.title: Nike Drops New Air Jordan 4 Retro ‘Abundance’ Sneakers
4.snippet: New Nike Air Jordan 4 Retro throwback sneakers in Seafoam and Metallic Silver drops on Saturday, Mar. 8: Here's where to find and buy a pair online.
4.content:
If you purchase an independently reviewed product or service through a link on our website, Variety may receive an affiliate commission.

During his career in the NBA, Jordan made an impact on the basketball court, as one of the best players in the league. He also made an impact in pop culture with his signature shoes from Nike.

The sports apparel company is set to reintroduce the Air Jordan 4 sneakers — originally released in 1989 — in a new “abundance” colorway for a new generation of fans. The signature sneakers drop on Saturday, Mar. 8 at 10 a.m. ET/7 a.m. PT.

Priced at $215, the Nike Air Jordan 4 sneakers are designed from premium materials, such as a mixture of authentic and synthetic leather, as well as a luxurious and plush nubuck upper with a fresh look and clean feel that has a retro appeal, but with a modern twist.

In addition, the sneakers have the iconic “Jumpman” logo on their tongues, head-turning netting, the “Nike Air” logo on each heel, transparent air bubble in each midsole and prominent wings on the metallic silver collar. These sneakers have a classic look with loads of style that works just as well in 2025, as they did back in 1989.

Nike Nike Air Jordan 4 Retro ‘Abundance’ Release date: Mar. 8 at 10 a.m. ET/7 a.m. PT Buy Now at Nike.com $215

The Nike Air Jordan 4 Retro “Abundance” sneakers come in a seafoam, metallic silver and sail colorway that’s ideal for casual use.

Want more from Nike? A few weeks ago, Nike rereleased the Air Jordan 1 Retro “Black Toe” sneakers for the 40th anniversary of the original release of Michael Jordan‘s legendary signature sneakers. The shoes dropped during the 2025 NBA All-Star Weekend and sold out fast. Meanwhile, it’s likely that the new Nike Air Jordan 4 Retro “Abundance” sneakers would also sell out very quickly, so jump on them when you can.

Available starting on Saturday, Mar. 8 at 10 a.m. ET/7 a.m. PT, the new Nike Air Jordan 4 Retro “Abundance” sneakers come in unisex sizes and is priced at $215 at Nike.com. The sneakers come in little kid and toddler sizes too, starting at $85.

6.title: Bode x Nike Astrograbber “Black” Releases Spring 2025
6.snippet: Bode and Nike continue their Astrograbber series with the all-black colorway, releasing in Spring 2025 for $160 USD via bode.com and Nike.
6.content:
Bode and Nike are reviving the Astrograbber with fresh colorways for Spring 2025. Originally launched in 1974 as a football training shoe, this silhouette returns with a modern twist. Bode’s high-fashion influence elevates the design while preserving its vintage sports heritage.

- Advertisement -

The Bode x Nike Astrograbber “Black” brings a sleek, timeless look. Its upper features breathable black mesh, soft suede overlays, and a premium leather Swoosh. The tongue also comes in leather, enhancing the shoe’s elevated appeal. A gold football-shaped lace charm nods to the Astrograbber’s deep-rooted connection to the game. Meanwhile, Bode branding appears in cursive on the tongue, adding a refined touch.

Alongside the “Black” colorway, the Astrograbber will also release in “Chlorophyll.” First seen at Paris Fashion Week, this version features green leather for a bold, throwback aesthetic. While the black edition leans into understated luxury, the green pair embraces vintage sportswear vibes.

Both colorways maintain the Astrograbber’s signature sole unit, offering comfort and traction. The design blends nostalgia with premium materials, making it a must-have for collectors and fashion-forward sneakerheads.

Bode x Nike Astrograbber Black Release Date

The Bode x Nike Astrograbber “Black” is set to release in March 2025. It will be available via Bode.com, select retailers, and Nike.com. The retail price is $160 USD. Expect high demand for this refined yet retro collaboration.

Stay up to date with all upcoming sneaker releases from our Sneaker Release Dates page. Be sure to follow us on Twitter and Instagram.
