8.title: Is Nike a Buy, Sell, or Hold in 2025?
8.snippet: Long-time successful companies can hit roadblocks. It's tough to figure out whether it's a temporary setback or a more permanent situation.
8.content:
Long-time successful companies can hit roadblocks. It's tough to figure out whether it's a temporary setback or a more permanent situation. However, taking a step back to analyze the company's fundamentals can help you make that determination.

It's particularly challenging when it's a consumer discretionary company that relies on keeping up with customer tastes. Nike (NYSE: NKE) seemingly had the Midas touch for a long time. Once a high-flying company with booming sales and profit growth, it's fallen on more difficult days.

Where to invest $1,000 right now? Our analyst team just revealed what they believe are the 10 best stocks to buy right now. Learn More »

Can Nike regain its momentum? Or are the company's best days behind it?

Brand power fades

Nike had cool commercials and sports stars' endorsements. These included basketball megastar Michael Jordan. In fact, it seemed like every athlete wore Nike sneakers.

That added up to a powerful and popular brand. Footwear accounted for two-thirds of Nike's $23.9 billion in fiscal first-half revenue, which ended on Nov. 30, 2024. The company's offerings also include apparel and equipment/accessories (such as bags, balls, bats, and gloves).

The company produced high sales and profit growth for a long time. However, they've been faltering. Fiscal second-quarter sales dropped 9% after removing foreign-currency exchange translations, despite increasing marketing expenditures (demand creation expenses on the income statement) by 1%. Management cut overhead expenses, but diluted earnings per share still fell 24% to $0.78.

There have been several reasons for Nike's worsening revenue, including macroeconomic pressures, a lack of innovative new products, and intensifying competition. The last item is troubling as Deckers Outdoor's Hoka brand and On Holding, to name two, have grabbed market share from Nike.

Can it win back customers?

Recognizing the worsening situation, Nike brought back company veteran Elliott Hill as president and CEO last October. One of his strategies is to boost marketing and develop new products, particularly relying more on sports-related footwear and apparel than more fashionable merchandise.

The new CEO has also been pushing for better relationships with retailers while planning to de-emphasize Nike's own direct-to-consumer business. The return to Nike's roots sounds logical since that brought a lot of success in the past.

However, Hill admits that the turnaround will take time. Moreover, it will likely cost more as management invests in product innovation and marketing. In the meantime, there's no guarantee Nike can win back customers that it will need to drive sales growth. In fact, it figures to be a major challenge.

Making the decision

Investors have recognized the challenges facing Nike. The stock has dropped nearly 32% over the past year. During this time, the S&P 500 gained about 21%. The stock's valuation has gotten less expensive. It trades at a price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 22, down from over 30 a year ago. Large-cap stocks, measured by the S&P 500, have a P/E multiple of 30.

But long-term investors should be wary. While the valuation may seem tempting, remember, the stock sells at a discount for a reason. In this case, it's worsening results in the face of strong competition.

Hill may succeed, and sales and earnings may get back on track. However, that's a risky bet. I'd advise investors to avoid the stock for now, but keep track of the company. If you see sales improve in tandem with a better gross margin, you'll know the company's going in the right direction.

Until then, I'd stay away from the shares.

Don’t miss this second chance at a potentially lucrative opportunity

Ever feel like you missed the boat in buying the most successful stocks? Then you’ll want to hear this.

On rare occasions, our expert team of analysts issues a “Double Down” stock recommendation for companies that they think are about to pop. If you’re worried you’ve already missed your chance to invest, now is the best time to buy before it’s too late. And the numbers speak for themselves:

Nvidia: if you invested $1,000 when we doubled down in 2009, you’d have $360,040 !*

if you invested $1,000 when we doubled down in 2009, !* Apple: if you invested $1,000 when we doubled down in 2008, you’d have $46,374 !*

1.title: Our favorite golf shoes for 2025 from Nike, Adidas, FootJoy and a whole lot more
1.snippet: Looking for new golf shoes in 2025? These are Golfweek's favorite golf shoes from brands like Nike, Adidas, FootJoy, New Balance, Jordan and more.
1.content:
Our favorite golf shoes for 2025 from Nike, Adidas, FootJoy and a whole lot more

The 2025 golf season is right around the corner — man, that feels good to say — and it's that time of year to make sure you have everything you need to have a successful season.

Over the next few months, we'll be releasing dozens of lists covering every inch of the apparel game so you can load up with your favorite items.

In this list, we've searched the internet for our favorite pairs of golf shoes from brands like Skechers, Nike, Adidas, Air Jordan, New Balance, and more.

G/FORE - LTD Release Gallivan2r Split Toe Golf Shoe

Price: $175

Why you'll love it: These shoes from G/FORE are as classy as classy gets. The tan and white coloring is easy to match to a lot of outfits and they're built with comfort in mind. Upgrade your on-course style with G/FORE's recent release.

Shop G/FORE LTD Release Gallivan2r Split Toe Golf Shoe

Skechers - Slip-ins: GO GOLF Prestige

Price: $150

Why you'll love it: The Go Golf Prestige shoes from Skechers are the perfect blend of classic look and comfort. These bad boys will keep you comfortable for 18 holes without a problem.

Shop Skechers Slip-ins: GO GOLF Prestige

Nike - Air Max 90 G Golf Shoes

Price: $140

Why you'll love it: Nike's Air Max shoes are incredibly popular off the course, and now you can wear them on it. The Air Max 90 G Golf Shoes are available in four colorways.

Shop Nike Air Max 90 G Golf Shoes

Pluto Golf - Pluto 1 Taxi

Price: $159

Why you'll love it: If you love casual golf shoes, you're gonna love Pluto Golf. The brand's shoes are the perfect combination of low-key style and performance. These shoes are great for on and off the course and they're available in seven colors.

Shop Pluto Golf Pluto 1 Taxi

FootJoy - Traditions Blucher

Price: $149.99

Why you'll love it: We don't think we have to sell you on these too much, they speak for themselves. Seriously, have you ever seen a better looking pair of shoes?

Shop FootJoy Traditions Blucher

Adidas - Adizero ZG Spikeless Golf Shoes

Price: $179.99

Why you'll love it: Adidas' Adizero ZG Spikeless Golf Shoes are one of the brand's newest releases and you can expect to see these on pro tours in 2025. Their waterproof construction will keep your feet dry and they're built with comfort in mind.

Shop Adidas Adizero ZG Spikeless Golf Shoes

New Balance - 997 SL Golf Shoes

Price: $109.99

Why you'll love it: New Balance offers a variety of styles of golf shoes, and this one is one of our favorites. They offer a casual look, but they're comfortable, waterproof and as stable as any other shoe on the market.

Shop New Balance 997 SL Golf Shoes

Sun Day Red - Pioneer Cypress Golf Shoes

Price: $250

Why you'll love it: These are one of the pairs of shoes Tiger Woods wears. Do we need to say anything else? If you grab a pair of Pioneer Cypress shoes, all your buddies will be jealous. They're available in five colorways.

Shop Sun Day Red Pioneer Cypress Golf Shoes

Malbon Golf x FootJoy - Traditions

Price: $198

Why you'll love it: These shoes are from a collaboration between Malbon Golf and FootJoy, and they're the perfect addition to your wardrobe if you're looking for a shoe that will match most of your outfits.

Shop Malbon Golf x FootJoy Traditions

Nike - Air Jordan 1 Low G Golf Shoe

Price: $150

Why you'll love it: Air Jordans are starting to become more and more popular in golf, as they've been worn by Tony Finau on the PGA Tour and Nelly Korda on the LPGA. Grab yourself a pair, and upgrade your style.

Shop Nike Air Jordan 1 Low G Golf Shoe

True linkswear - True All Day Knit III

Price: $99 (down from $169)

Why you'll love it: If you prefer a more athletic golf shoe, this is the perfect pair for you. True linkswear's All Day Knit III shoes can be worn on and off the course and are built to keep you comfortable whether you're playing 18 or 36.

True linkswear True All Day Knit III

G/FORE - G/18 Golf Shoes

Price: $250

Why you'll love it: The G/18 Golf Shoes are one of G/FORE's more recent additions, and they're the perfect pair if you prefer a more athletic golf shoe.

Shop G/FORE G/18 Golf Shoes

2.title: Official Looks at the Nike Total 90 III "Bordeaux"
2.snippet: The iconic Nike Total 90 III indoor shoe is set to return in a number of lifestyle retros throughout 2025 – including a 'Sail/Light Orewood Brown/Light...
2.content:
Nike’s Total 90 III revival wouldn’t be complete without a proper nod to its original colorways , and the upcoming "Metallic Silver" edition does exactly that. Drawing inspiration from the iconic 2007 model , this release stays true to the pair worn by some of football’s greatest names , including Wayne Rooney, Luis Figo, and Roberto Carlos .

The upper arrives in a bold metallic silver finish, instantly recognizable to fans of the original boot. As a direct homage to the legendary era of Total 90 football, the oversized "90" motif on the medial side is drenched in striking red, mirroring the unforgettable detail seen on the pairs that graced the pitch almost two decades ago. A white midsole keeps the design crisp, while a black rubber outsole retains the durability and traction that defined the performance-oriented silhouette in its past life.

Pairs will be released via Nike SNRKS on March 1st, 2025.

In other retro news from Nike, the Air Max 95 "Neon" is set for a comeback in March.

3.title: A Reflective Silver Upper Graces the Nike Air Max Sunder
3.snippet: Name: Nike Air Max Sunder “Silver” Colorway: Silver/White/Anthracite/Black SKU: HF1199-001. MSRP: $200 USD Release Date: February 26. Where to Buy: Nike.
3.content:
Name: Nike Air Max Sunder “Silver”

Colorway: Silver/White/Anthracite/Black

SKU: HF1199-001

MSRP: $200 USD

Release Date: February 26

Where to Buy: Nike

After dropping its COMME des GARÇONS HOMME PLUS collaboration in 2022, it was only a matter of time until Nike brought back the Air Max Sunder for all to enjoy. However, it wasn’t until mid 2024 that the shoe would return. Since then, the Swoosh has kept the silhouette in constant rotation, carrying over into 2025. Now, yet another fresh take on the sneaker has been assembled and is due to drop later this month.

Appearing in a women’s-exclusive “Silver,” the Air Max Sunder shines bright with reflective detailing present across its uppermost gray layer. From there, black appears across the mudguard and heel while its signature geometric overlays favor a dark gray finish. A visible Air unit is present at the heel and is surrounded by white at the midsole and black at the outsole to complete this new rendition of the sneaker from ‘99.

For those looking to pick up a pair, the Nike Air Max Sunder “Silver” is set to drop in women’s sizes on February 26 via Nike SNKRS and select retailers at a starting price of $200 USD. Stay tuned for the reveal of additional colorways as the model continues its comeback run.

4.title: Nike Reveals the G.T. Future Basketball Shoe at NBA All-Star Weekend
4.snippet: Nike NIL athlete AJ Dybantsa debuted the G.T. Future basketball shoe on the court, and it was also spotted on the feet of rapper Wale.
4.content:
Nike is adding another sneaker to its acclaimed G.T. basketball shoe series.

As part of its NBA All-Star Weekend festivities, Nike hosted its Future Game experience in Oakland. During the game, AJ Dybantsa — who signed a name, image and likeness (NIL) deal with the brand in January 2024 — debuted the Nike G.T. Future. The hooper, who is ranked No. 1 in the class of 2025 by ESPN, hit the court in an all black pair.

The sneaker was also spotted on the feet of rapper Wale in another colorway.

AJ Dybantsa in the Nike G.T. Future basketball shoe. Courtesy of Emily Johnson

Though little information of the shoe is available, in a statement sent to FN, the brand said “the Nike G.T. Future is geared for those players who use their bounce to take over the game, like AJ.”

Watch on FN

Nike also confirmed with FN that the shoe is slated for a holiday 2025 release. No additional release information was provided.

Nike revealed its G.T. series — which stands for “Greater Than” — in 2021. The basketball shoe series, the brand explained at the time, was created to “focus on a specific aspect of the game” in order to give players “a performance boost where they need it most.” Current Nike G.T. basketball shoe models that can be purchased via Nike.com include the G.T. Cut 3 and the G.T. Cut Academy, the G.T. Hustle 3, the G.T. Jump 2 and the G.T. Jump Academy.

About the Author

Peter Verry is the Senior News and Features Editor for Athletic and Outdoor at Footwear News. He oversees coverage of the two fast-paced and ultracompetitive markets, which includes conducting in-depth interviews with industry leaders and writing stories on sneakers and outdoor shoes. He is a lifelong sneaker addict (and shares his newest purchases via @peterverry on Instagram) and spends most of his free time on a trail. He holds an M.A. in journalism from Hofstra University and can be reached at peter.verry@footwearnews.com.

5.title: Wale Debuts The Nike GT Future At NBA All-Star 2025
5.snippet: Wale debuts the Nike GT Future at the 2025 NBA All-Star Weekend. The new model blends Zoom Hyperflight and Foamposite elements.
5.content:
Wale continues his tradition of unveiling exclusive basketball sneakers, this time debuting the Nike GT Future at the Nike Future Game during NBA All-Star 2025 in Oakland. Known for championing early Foamposite releases, Wale now shifts focus to Nike’s latest Greater Than (GT) series innovation.

- Advertisement -

The GT Future draws inspiration from early 2000s basketball sneakers, featuring a one-piece molded upper similar to the Foamposite line. The sleek ankle collar, reminiscent of the Zoom Hyperflight, adds a futuristic touch. This design merges heritage aesthetics with modern performance enhancements, making it a standout in Nike’s basketball lineup. The red-orange reflective upper, worn by Wale, creates a bold statement, glowing under direct light.

Designed under the creative direction of Nike Basketball veteran Frank Cooke, the GT Future incorporates cutting-edge materials to redefine high-performance basketball footwear. The shoe is engineered for speed, support, and durability, catering to today’s elite athletes.

Nike GT Future Release Date

The Nike GT Future will launch in Fall 2025 at select Nike Basketball retailers, online, and on Nike.com. The retail price is set at $190 USD.

With Wale’s early co-sign and its futuristic design, the GT Future is set to make waves in the basketball and sneaker communities. Stay tuned for more updates on this highly anticipated release!

Stay up to date with all upcoming sneaker releases from our Sneaker Release Dates page. Be sure to follow us on Twitter and Instagram.

Nike GT Future

Release Date: 2025

Price: $190

6.title: 11 indicted in Arizona train robbery for stealing nearly $5M worth of Nike shoes. What we know
6.snippet: In the latest modern Western train robbery, 11 suspects were indicted in the theft of $440000 worth of Nike shoes in northern Arizona.
6.content:
11 indicted in Arizona train robbery for stealing nearly $5M worth of Nike shoes. What we know

Show Caption Hide Caption Light rail crosses into south Phoenix for the first time Trains crossed over the Salt River Bridge for the first time on Jan. 30, 2025, as testing expanded south toward the end of the line at Baseline Road.

Eleven individuals have been indicted for stealing over $440,000 worth of Nike shoes from a BNSF train traveling through northern Arizona, according to the U.S. Attorney's Office in Arizona.

Court records state that on Jan. 13, Noe Cecena-Castro, a Mexican national, and 10 others were arrested for involvement in the Nike train robbery. Authorities believe they were working together to pack and transport about 1,900 pairs of unreleased Nike shoes.

About 11 a.m., a BNSF train was stopped in Perrin, Arizona. Shortly after, a BNSF police officer spotted several cases of Nike shoes beside the stationary train.

Law enforcement later found a U-Haul truck and a privately owned Ford Econoline truck nearby, both seen near the site where the Nike shoes were stolen. Several individuals were observed loading the Nike cases into the U-Haul.

Both trucks were searched by law enforcement and found to contain 1,985 pairs of unreleased Nike shoes, worth over $440,000. The rest of the crew were transported in a nearby Chevy Tahoe, which had also been seen in the area.

Train heist uptick

This follows a string of train thefts from northern Arizona and California over the past 15 years with a notable uptick in the last two years.

The U.S. Homeland Security Department reports that the suspects are often part of transnational theft organizations originating in Sinaloa, Mexico, and operating out of California and Arizona.

In October 2024, two individuals were arrested after a Yavapai County Sheriff’s Office deputy responded to a train burglary report and chased four vehicles for miles along Interstate 40.

In December of the same year, a passing BNSF train spotted several Nike sneaker cases piled next to the tracks near Yampai, west of Williams along Route 66. Four U.S. citizens were charged with possession of stolen goods after the boxes were seized.

On Jan. 13, a BNSF police officer noticed Nike sneakers alongside the tracks, leading to the latest case.

The heists typically involve cutting air hoses to control where trains carrying valuable cargo stop. Criminal organizations specializing in train theft have used this dangerous method to derail cargo trains, some traveling at speeds of up to 70 mph.

This method involves multiple steps and separate crews to pull off a train theft. Once the train is stopped at a predetermined location, one crew breaks into specific container cars and unloads the cargo onto the ground next to the tracks.

Another crew then drives box trucks or other cargo vehicles to the scene, loading up the stolen goods for transport to California, where they are sold online.

Nine of the 11 defendants tied to the most recent indictment are Mexican nationals. Along with charges of possessing stolen goods, the grand jury also returned charges for three defendants for Re-entry of Removed Alien and six defendants for Improper Entry by Alien.

All 11 defendants are in federal custody pending trial. The defendants will be arraigned on the charges on Feb. 19.

Republic reporter Lane Sainty contributed to this article.

7.title: Nike SB's Wildest Hybrid, the Skate-Ready Jordan 4, Is Suddenly Back
7.snippet: Finally, the Nike SB Jordan 4 sneaker releasing again. But now, the skate-basketball shoe is dropping navy blue, distinct from the OG Military Blue.
7.content:
Finally, the Nike SB Jordan 4 is set to return. And this time, it's got a new "Midnight Navy" makeover.

Two years after Nike SB whipped the sneaker community into a frenzy with the Jordan 4 Pine Green, an instant sell-out that had people queueing around the block outside skate stores, a follow-up colorway is coming.

The skate sneaker is set to get its second release and it has adopted navy blue paneling for the occasion. It’s not quite the original Military Blue AJ4, but it looks mighty similar.

And the similarities between this shoe and the OG Jordan 4 from 1989 go beyond just the colorway: it’s also in the shape of the shoe. Nike SB and Jordan tweaked the AJ4 design so that the shape around the toe box was more aligned with that of the original ‘89 model.

Your Highsnobiety privacy settings have blocked this Twitter post. Enable All Media Manage consent Privacy policy

This update wasn’t made purely for aesthetic reasons (although, sneakerheads are notorious for moaning that the new-shape models don’t look as good), it’s to help the bubble-soled basketball shoe skate better. The new (well, old) toebox makes for a better flick according to Nike.

Your Highsnobiety privacy settings have blocked this YouTube video. Enable All Media Manage consent Privacy policy Subscribe to Highsnobiety on YouTube

Other updates from Nike SB, the American sportswear giant’s skateboarding division, include flexible plastic detailing to make them more supple, zonal gum rubber on the outsole, and thicker materials.

"Skate and basketball may have lived in two parallel universes when the AJ4 first came on the scene, but the spirit of rebellion and style that MJ brought to the game is inherent to the DNA of skateboarding,” said James Arizumi, Global Senior Design Director, Jordan Brand Special Projects, when the first pair of Nike SB Jordan 4s were released.

Your Highsnobiety privacy settings have blocked this Twitter post. Enable All Media Manage consent Privacy policy

Since they debuted in 2023, talk of a follow-up skateable AJ4 has been rife (including rumors of a possible Varsity Red release). But confirmation of a second Nike SB AJ4 colorway has now arrived via the Virginia-based retailer Skate Supply.

Your Highsnobiety privacy settings have blocked this Instagram post. Enable All Media Manage consent Privacy policy

Unfortunately, the store hasn’t yet provided an official release date but through an early February Instagram post, Skate Supply did confirmed that the navy blue-colored shoe is coming soon.

While we’ve seen the Jordan 4 mimic the shape of a skate shoe in recent years, this one is the real thing: it's a fully engineered skate shoe direct from the skate specialists at Nike SB.

8.title: Nike Has Wale Debuting Sneaker Samples Again
8.snippet: Update: Nike has reached out to Sneaker News to share some info: the model is the Nike GT Future and it will release sometime later this year.
8.content:
This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. The opinions and information provided on this site are original editorial content of Sneaker News.

Update: Nike has reached out to Sneaker News to share some info: the model is the Nike GT Future and it will release sometime later this year.

Wale revealing an unreleased Nike sample? We’re turning the clock back to the early 2010s when the DMV-based rap artist was the go-to individual to bring energy to a pair of sneakers. Wale Folarin’s feet were basically billboards for the Swoosh, and that fact that he wore the sample size 9 made it easier for this seemingly under-the-table partnership to continue. Whenever Wale wore a pair of upcoming Foamposites, it was front page news.

Rumors of a Wale x Nike collaboration were in perpetual circulation throughout the first half of the 2010s decade, but no such project ever happened (although he may have had involvement in the short-lived I-95 Posite Max Boot). The channel of sample products gradually slowed to a full stop as well as Nike went into the “influencer” route, choosing the likes of Bella Hadid instead of partnering with people who, you know, actually care about the brand. It wasn’t until the DMV Foamposite launch in 2024 that Nike actually worked with the artist on an official level. Better late than never.

During Friday night’s Nike Future Game, Wale was spotted wearing a never-before-seen Nike sample-a throwback to the era of Wale providing first/early looks at Nike footwear coming down the pipeline. The photos were shared by @higherlxng as well as Frank Cooker on Instagram.

1 of 3

Not much is known about this model, but it appears to be some type of molded upper with the distinct ankle collar shape of the Zoom Hyperflight. It’s got a bit of that early 2000s Nike Basketball energy championed by Eric Avar and Aaron Cooper. It is indeed confirmed to be a Nike Basketball product.

Nike is an all out fight to reclaim the energy it once held onto throughout the 2010s. It’ll require the right combination of product, partnerships, pricing, and people-pleasing, a formula they’re still trying to figure out in the post John Donahoe era. Good-looking performance product like the Pegasus Premium and teaming with actual sneaker fanatics like Wale will help right a lot of the missteps.

9.title: Nike Drops New Air Jordan 1 Retro ‘Black Toe’ Sneakers: Here’s Where to Get A Pair Online
9.snippet: The New Nike Air Jordan 1 Retro throwback sneakers come in White, Varsity Red, Sail and Black — here's where to find and buy a pair online.
9.content:
If you purchase an independently reviewed product or service through a link on our website, Variety may receive an affiliate commission.

Michael Jordan is an icon. Not just on the basketball court, but in pop culture too — even after retiring from the NBA more than 20 years ago. In fact, even his sneakers are iconic.

And now in unisex sizes for adults and kids, Nike re-releases the classic Air Jordan 1 “Black Toe” sneakers with a classic colorway, while they drop on Saturday, Feb. 15 at 10 a.m. ET/7 a.m. PT at nike.com.

Made with premium and synthetic leather, the Nike Air Jordan 1 Retro sneakers have a foam midsole for lightweight cushioning and solid rubber outsoles for traction — all with Nike’s design silhouette that’s eye-catching and a fan-favorite.

These sneakers come in a white, varsity red, sail and black colorway (Chicago Bulls colors) that offers an instantly classic and stylish look. However, instead of the classic “Air Jordan” logo on their outer collars, there’s the modern and minimalist logo.

Nike Nike Air Jordan 1 Retro High OG ‘Black Toe’ Release date: Feb. 15 at 10 a.m. ET/7 a.m. PT Buy Now at Nike.com $180

These are the shoes that Michael Jordan during most of his rookie season with the Chicago Bulls in 1984-85, while Nike started selling the Nike Air Jordan 1 sneakers in only a handful of test markets, such as New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Philadelphia, Detroit, and Raleigh-Durham, North Carolina, in April 1985 — before expanding nationwide.

Meanwhile, Nike is gearing up to drop more Air Jordan sneakers in various colorways during the signature shoes’ 40th anniversary. These shoes are become such an iconic piece of pop culture that there was a movie made about them titled “Air” in 2023.

Now available for $180, the Nike Air Jordan 1 Retro “Black Toe” sneakers come in men’s and women’s sizes, while the shoes also come in sizes for big kids, little kids and babies & toddlers with prices starting at $70 at nike.com.

0.title: Introducing the Converse SHAI 001: NBA All-Star Shai Gilgeous-Alexander’s First Signature Shoe
0.snippet: The Converse SHAI 001, co-created with Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, is a culmination of his desire to redefine performance basketball footwear,...
0.content:
Shai Gilgeous-Alexander’s game is a symphony of contrasts — tough and elegant, powerful and precise. Like its namesake, the new SHAI 001 signature shoe harmonizes comfort, containment, durability and style in a performance silhouette that delivers an exceptional experience on and off the court.

Since becoming creative director of Converse Basketball in 2024, Gilgeous-Alexander has been instrumental in designing every facet of his signature logo and shoe, imbuing the project with his artistic vision and creative sensibility. From the outset, he shared several hand-drawn sketches with the Converse product and design teams that ultimately inspired the final design of the SHAI 001, his first signature shoe.

“We gave Shai creative control over the design of the shoe in a way only Converse can. Then we went to work leveraging the resources of Converse and all the innovation of NIKE, Inc. to proudly deliver the SHAI 001,” says Jared Carver, Converse CEO and President. “Converse invented the first basketball shoe, and we have been there for so many of the sport’s beloved moments over the last hundred years. We are confident the SHAI 001 will help inspire and inform the next wave of basketball footwear and return Converse to its rightful place at the heart of the game.”

The SHAI 001 is engineered to deliver elite-level performance on and off the court, leveraging the full resources and innovation of Converse and NIKE, Inc.

The silhouette showcases Gilgeous-Alexander’s approach to design, blending worlds to create a signature model that’s entirely original and uniquely him. Every detail has been meticulously crafted and curated to create a shoe as versatile as Gilgeous-Alexander himself — from materials and colors to a locking zipper that allows for multiple styling options.

“I poured my heart and soul into the SHAI 001, and I’m proud to share it with the world,” says Gilgeous-Alexander. “From performance to design, every aspect of this shoe reflects my passion for the game and my commitment to pushing its boundaries. We made the SHAI 001 a versatile shoe for everyone — from the athlete who’s in the gym three times a day to the kids who just want to express themselves on or off the court.”

That expression shines through Gilgeous-Alexander’s personalized design details, beginning with his signature logo, which serves as a symbol of his duality as an athlete and creative, including a nod to his jersey number.

It also extends to the silhouette’s zipper: a bold statement of customization that allows for multiple wear options. The zipper works in tandem with an inner bootie, webbing and ghillie lacing system to provide containment and adjustability that’s equally suited for the hardwood and everyday life.

A puffed upper features a winged shroud that adds dimension and volume to the silhouette, while additional padding in the tongue helps ensure a snug and comfortable fit.

A unibody molded design offers a futuristic vibe, and a forefoot Nike Zoom Air unit provides spring with every step, ensuring peak court feel and connectivity. Meanwhile, a radial traction pattern is designed to deliver quick cuts, allowing for seamless changes in direction and explosive movement on the court.

The silhouette will debut at NBA All-Star Weekend in the Butter colorway and will be available in a limited global release at select retailers in fall 2025. Follow @Converse, @ConverseHoops and @Shai for more information — and keep your eyes locked on Gilgeous-Alexander’s feet as the NBA season continues.

1.title: The Nike Book 1 'Black Label' Releases Feb.14
1.snippet: Nike is elevating Devin Booker's signature line with the Nike Book 1 "Black Label," a premium, highly limited edition of his debut silhouette.
1.content:
Nike is elevating Devin Booker’s signature line with the Nike Book 1 "Black Label," a premium, highly limited edition of his debut silhouette. As part of Nike Basketball’s exclusive "Black Label" collection, this release is restricted to just 1,996 pairs—a nod to Booker’s birth year—making it one of the most coveted drops in the series.

The Book 1 "Black Label" arrives in an all-black denim construction, giving the shoe a refined, textured look while maintaining its signature off-court appeal. Special Black Label branding appears across the insole, tongue, hang tag, and left insole, reinforcing its elevated status within Nike’s basketball lineup. A red Nike Swoosh on the outsole provides the only bold contrast, while subtle red detailing and "BOOK" branding are tucked away on the back side of the tongue, adding a discreet personal touch.

Set to release on February 14 for $170, the Nike Book 1 "Black Label" will be available in extremely limited quantities, making it a must-have for collectors and fans of Booker’s growing signature line. Expect pairs to drop via Nike.com and select retailers.

Make sure to keep your eyes locked onto our official twitter for further updates.

2.title: Nike Rekindles Tom Sachs Collaboration, Two Years After They Dropped Him
2.snippet: Nike is working with Tom Sachs again, despite allegations of abuse, and will release the artist's Mars Yard 3.0 sneakers in September.
2.content:
Less than two years after former studio staff made damning allegations against Tom Sachs of a toxic workplace rife with sexual harassment and bullying, the artist has announced a September release date for his Mars Yard 3.0 sneakers with Nike.

The best of Artnet News in your inbox. Sign up for our daily newsletter. The best of Artnet News in your inbox. Sign up for our daily newsletter. Please enter a valid email address Signup failed. Please try again later. Thank you! You have successfully subscribed to Artnet News.

The company unveiled the first Mars Yard shoes in 2012, and followed with 2.0 in 2017. Sachs’s most recent release with Nike was the more affordable General Purpose Shoe introduced in 2022—but then the company appeared to end the partnership.

The best of Artnet News in your inbox. Sign up for our daily newsletter. The best of Artnet News in your inbox. Sign up for our daily newsletter. Please enter a valid email address Signup failed. Please try again later. Thank you! You have successfully subscribed to Artnet News.

The first rumble of trouble for Sachs came with, of all things, an anonymous job posting for an assistant position to an “high-profile art world family” that would be responsible for everything from childcare to “dog systems” and “closet systems”—language that tipped off Sachs staffers that the listing came from him and his wife, former Gagosian director Sarah Hoover.

The demanding job and its relatively meager pay of just $65,000 to $95,000 met with ridicule. It also sent former staffers crawling out of the woodwork, eager to share—albeit anonymously—their negative experiences working for the couple.

View this post on Instagram A post shared by Tom Sachs (@tomsachs)

The complaints, first published in Curbed and then in an article by this reporter, were serious, and Nike quickly took notice. One complaint was about Sachs wearing only his underwear in a Zoom meeting with Nike. (The branding Sachs used for Nike hinted at issues with the kind of work environment he maintained, such as the phrase “work like a slave” initially appearing on the Mars Yard 2.0 box.)

A guerrilla campaign on the streets of New York from artist Corey Escoto had encouraged the brand to “Just Drop Him,” a play on the Nike slogan written in Sachs-like lettering beneath a roughly drawn Nike swoosh.

Before the accusations, the Mars Yard 3.0 had been rumored for release over the 2023 holidays. But Nike expressed “concern” about the reports and two months later confirmed that “we are not working with Tom’s studio at this time and have no release dates planned.”

At first, Sachs categorically denied the accusations against him. But after his Nike deal blew up, he expressed “regret” and promised to “professionalize our operations” with a formal HR—while insisting “I have never harassed anyone.”

Sachs did not respond to my inquiries about whether he had learned anything from the complaints against him, or what changes he had implemented. But his track record with the company as a consumer favorite likely went a long way toward smoothing over any concerns about his behavior: Complex noted that the Mars Yard 2.0 “is heralded as one of Nike’s best models from the 2010s and unworn pairs can fetch thousands of dollars on the secondary market.”

View this post on Instagram A post shared by HYPEBEAST (@hypebeast)

Just 18 months after the allegations first surfaced, last September, the company announced plans to once again work with Sachs, issuing a statement that “Tom has demonstrated and recommitted to fostering a culture of respect and inclusivity. We can confirm that our work with Tom will continue and this next chapter of NikeCraft will uphold our shared passion for team, product, and storytelling excellence.”

Two years on, Sachs and Hoover have clearly bounced back from the bad press. Hoover kept her book deal, and published The Motherload: Episodes From the Brink of Motherhood, about her struggles with postpartum depression (and a warts-and-all account of her marriage), in January. (The couple had a second child, a daughter, last year.)

Without directly addressing the way she and Sachs have treated their staff, Hoover recently spoke about hiring caretakers for her children to the New York Times, saying “Isn’t spending money to give someone a job and help make parenting more of a delight the whole point of working hard?”

The resumption of the Nike partnership, and the glossing over of all the allegations of bullying, abuse, and harassment, feels like something of a sign of the times. In the year 2025, are there any repercussions for anything, ever, anymore?

3.title: Bay FC Debuts Spring Nike Headwear Collection Ahead of 2025 Season
3.snippet: Bay FC dropped the Spring 2025 Bay FC Nike headwear collection just in time for fans to gear up in advance of the Club's second season.
3.content:
Bay FC fans can also enjoy free shipping for Valentine’s Day and new markdowns on BayFC.com

SAN FRANCISCO (February 14, 2025) – Bay FC, the professional soccer franchise representing the Bay Area in the National Women’s Soccer League (NWSL), dropped its Spring 2025 Bay FC Nike headwear collection just in time for fans to gear up in advance of the Club’s second season. The new gear marks the first opportunity for Bay FC Nike headwear since the club’s inaugural season. The seven-item collection is available to the general public at BayFC.com beginning today, Friday, February 14, 2025.

In addition to new headwear, Bay FC fans can purchase something for their loved ones and enjoy free shipping for orders over $100 with the Club’s special Valentine’s Day offer, valid today through Monday, February 17. The Club is also promoting markdowns on various items site-wide on BayFC.com including sweatshirts, T-shirts and pants from 20 percent to 50 percent off original price.

The Spring 2025 Bay FC Nike Headwear Collection includes:

Bay FC Nike Apex White Bucket Hat ($45)

Bay FC Grey Nike Pro Flat Bill Cap ($45)

Bay FC Navy Nike Rise Flex-Fit Cap ($45)

Bay FC Navy Nike Rise Trucker Hat ($40)

Bay FC White Nike Club Cap ($38)

Bay FC Nike Navy Striped Beanie ($35)

Bay FC Youth Navy Nike Club Cap ($30)

The 2025 Bay FC season kicks off March 15 when the club travels to face the Utah Royals. The home schedule begins March 22 as Bay FC hosts Racing Louisville at 7 p.m. PT. Tickets for Bay FC’s 2025 season at PayPal Park in San Jose are now available for purchase at BayFC.com. Fans can also follow @wearebayfc on social channels for more exciting announcements to come.

About Bay Football Club

Bay Football Club (Bay FC) is the professional soccer franchise representing the Bay Area and the 14th team to join the National Women’s Soccer League (NWSL). Bay FC was established in April 2023 and co-founded by USWNT legends Brandi Chastain, Leslie Osborne, Danielle Slaton, and Aly Wagner in partnership with global investment firm Sixth Street and an investor group of leading tech, business and sports executives. Sixth Street’s investment is the largest institutional investment to date in a women’s professional sports franchise. Bay FC is changing the face of women’s soccer as we know it. The Club began play in the 2024 season. Tickets are now on sale for Bay FC at bayfc.com and fans can follow Bay FC’s social channels (@wearebayfc) for the latest news, merchandise, and events.

5.title: The Nike Air Force 1 Low Cops “Doraemon” Colors
5.snippet: Doraemon, both the character and the series he comes from, remains among Japan's most influential cultural icons. This legacy spawned multiple reboots and...
5.content:
This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. The opinions and information provided on this site are original editorial content of Sneaker News.

Doraemon, both the character and the series he comes from, remains among Japan’s most influential cultural icons. This legacy spawned multiple reboots and elevated positions like “ambassadorship” at the 2020 Olympics. Though not an official collaboration with the franchise, drawing up an Air Force 1 in “Doraemon” is a no-brainer in tapping into that widespread appeal, set to land for Spring 2025.

Of course, it’s the light blue and deep red shades gracing the uppermost sections of the shoe that plant this connection in our heads. Simply on a sneaker level, the mix of leather Swoosh/heel cap and suede overlays adds an additional layer of depth to the ever-present silhouette. Underneath, a heavy dose of cream leather brings some earthy contrast, balancing out the vivid shades above.

As a true GR, expect the Nike Air Force 1 Low “Doraemon” to crop up on Nike.com and partnering retailers in the coming weeks. A $125 retail price is expected. Catch close looks included below, and keep an eye on our Sneaker Release Dates page for further info as it comes.

6.title: Jaylen Brown opens up about Nike controversy, 'shoe politics' in basketball. What he said
6.snippet: Boston Celtics star Jaylen Brown opened up more about his public feud with Nike in a new interview.
6.content:
Jaylen Brown opens up about Nike controversy, 'shoe politics' in basketball. What he said

Show Caption Hide Caption Picking the best basketball moments of 2024 The FTH crew picks their favorite moments from across the basketball world of 2024! What do you think of these picks? Lots of Olympic action here!

Jaylen Brown told Sports Illustrated he thinks his issues with Nike "for sure" cost him a spot on last year's Olympic team.

Brown's feud with Nike dates back to 2022, when he called out the brand's ethics on social media.

Brown said his conflict with Nike is intertwined with bigger issues he has with the sneaker industry and "shoe politics."

Boston Celtics star Jaylen Brown shared more insight into his public feud with Nike in a new interview released this week.

In an interview with Sports Illustrated's Chris Mannix, Brown said he thinks his issues with the brand "for sure" cost him a spot on last year's Olympic team.

The NBA Finals MVP said his conflict with Nike is intertwined with bigger issues he has with the sneaker industry and "shoe politics."

"I think sneaker industries, and I’ve said this before, have way too much control over the basketball foundation," he said.

What did Jaylen Brown say about Nike feud, Olympics snub?

When asked if he thinks issues with Nike cost him a spot on the Olympic team, Brown said "for sure."

"(Players) should just be working on developing their basketball skills. Instead, we’re focusing more on shoe politics, and I think that is why the rest of the world has caught up. And if we don’t do something about it, the next Olympics and the next global outings are going to look a lot different," Brown said.

He went on to speak about his issues with athletes' sneaker brand deals with companies like Nike and Adidas.

"The fact that those are the only options and they kind of dominate the market is a part of the frustration that has grown among players because these are the options that you have and they all kind of stick together," he said. "They all give you the same kind of deal, and you have to accept it or not. O.K., if it doesn’t work for you, then what? What do you do?"

Brown recently launched his own performance brand, 741, which sells apparel and footwear,

Jaylen Brown's Nike feud explained

Brown's feud with Nike dates back to 2022, when he called out the brand's ethics on social media.

In response to Nike cutting ties with NBA player Kyrie Irving over him sharing an antisemitic film (Irving denied being antisemitic), Brown wrote on X, formerly Twitter, "Since when did Nike care about ethics?"

Then, when Brown was left off last year's Olympic basketball team, he blamed Nike for the snub on social media, saying in a post on X, "@nike this what we doing ?"

"Im not afraid of you or your resources," he wrote in a subsequent post.

USA Basketball men’s managing director Grant Hill denied at the time that Brown was left off the team because of his issues with Nike.

Melina Khan is a trending reporter for the USA TODAY Network - New England, which serves more than a dozen affiliated news organizations across New England. She can be reached at MKhan@gannett.com.

7.title: Nike Team Camp - by Caleb Olson - Chasing Trail
7.snippet: Looking out the airplane window right now, it's dumping snow. Portland doesn't often get storms like this, it's been wreaking havoc on the city. The Nike...
7.content:
Looking out the airplane window right now, it’s dumping snow. Portland doesn’t often get storms like this, it’s been wreaking havoc on the city. The Nike campus was closed yesterday as the icy snow covered the streets, so we had to adjust plans for our final day of the Nike Trail Team summit. I’m en route to my first race of the year on the island of Gran Canaria, but I’ve been in Portland for the past five days.

This is the first time in recent years that I’m aware of that the whole Nike Trail Team has converged on campus to meet together, and certainly my first time seeing everyone on the team in one place. I hadn’t met everyone on the team yet, and one of the highlights was connecting with each member of the trail team and getting to know them beyond a quick hello at races. It’s been action-packed, fun and productive, inspiring and tiring.

Without getting into all the specifics, here’s what our days looked like. We’d start the day off with a quick breakfast at the hotel before heading over to Forest Park or the Nike campus gym for a run or cross training. Media people were out and about in the forest getting pictures and videos as we ran. Some days we’d toss on a pair of shoes we’d talked about with product teams the previous afternoon to take them for a test loop. During those miles we’d be focused on how the shoe fit, how the foam felt, if our steps felt stable and our feet secure, any feedback we might want to report back.

A morning run through Forest Park with teammates Christian Allen and Anthony Costales.

Our next stop would usually be the campus locker rooms for showers and then the Lebron innovation building for lunch. The Lebron building is insane. It’s where some of Nike’s brightest minds are spinning up new ideas and experimenting with what you may see athletes wearing in the future. Seriously so cool seeing some of what’s being considered and iterated on that could be huge for trail running, it got me very excited about being able to use it when it’s ready.

The rest of the afternoons were usually filled with meetings and labs. Product teams came prepared with discussion questions and samples for us to wear, jog around in, pick apart, and brainstorm about. I felt like our feedback was truly valued and was helping shape these products that will be released. In addition to collecting our thoughts and feelings about these products, for several of them they’d have us hop on treadmills in various controlled environments where they could capture quantitative data. Sensors and cameras everywhere. How much did our efficiency change in these shoes vs those shoes, in this apparel vs what we’d been using previously? Curiosity took over and I’d ask questions about the rationale behind certain tests, and they’d break it down for me and talk me through the data they’d later analyze from my lab, giving me a live preview. I had never realized the amount of real science going on behind the scenes during the innovation and testing process, but it was intense.

Fashion is completely lost on me, but the past few days have also given me more of an appreciation for design. Nike has a dedicated color expert, and design is discussed frequently. I’m learning that colors and designs are used strategically to highlight special features and technologies within shoes and apparel. Colors evoke feelings, and getting to know an athlete’s mindset while training and racing shapes the feelings that are targeted in those designs.

Clearly Nike’s got some experience having athletes around, because they knew we’d want constant access to food and drinks. Healthy fresh juices, snacks, and frequent catered meals kept us happy and got us through to the evening, when we’d go out for an activity and dinner with one of the Nike teams. We all watched the Super Bowl together, got some great Peruvian food with leadership teams, had pizza and got our competitive juices flowing racing Go Carts with the innovation teams, etc.

On our final full day in Portland, a snowstorm closed down campus and product teams came to our hotel instead. We commandeered the main floor with discussions of the Nike trail shoe lineup and more brainstorming. By then, I’d started thinking about the next leg of this adventure—the trip out to race Transgrancanaria. So that brings me to now, sitting on the tarmac while this flight is delayed, hoping that it can get de-iced and take off in time to make my connecting flight in New York. I’ll be lining up a week from today for an epic cross-island showdown. Stay tuned for a little surprise dropping as the race starts…

9.title: Nike unveils giant Caitlin Clark billboard in Chicago near Chicago Sky arena
9.snippet: There is no one like Caitlin Clark. She continues to set herself apart and ascend women's basketball to the next level with her presence.
9.content:
She's everywhere. She's on TV, she's on social media, and now she is front and center in downtown Chicago. Caitlin Clark, as if it needs to be said anymore, is a certified worldwide superstar.

The latest Caitlin Clark movement is in Chicago, just blocks from the Chicago Sky's arena where Angel Reese plays, by way of a giant billboard unveiled by Nike.

Nike unleashed the billboard in Chicago featuring Caitlin Clark, one of their top athlete sponsors simply stating, "You can't win. So win."

Nike unveils Caitlin Clark billboard in ‘enemy territory’ https://t.co/1OP3f8XT53 pic.twitter.com/tNnMKuHOGF — New York Post (@nypost) February 14, 2025

This massive new billboard comes on the heels of Caitlin Clark dominating the sports world recently by seeing her famous No. 22 jersey hung up inside Carver-Hawkeye Arena after the Iowa Hawkeyes upset the USC Trojans with her in attendance.

As Caitlin Clark gets ready to build on her historic rookie season in the WNBA, her presence in the sports world is only continuing to grow globally and is taking over markets all across America.

2.title: A Nostalgic 'Blink' Look Lands on the Nike P-6000
2.snippet: The women's Nike P-6000 retro style has surfaced in a bold 'Black/Hyper Pink' (Blink) colorway ahead of Summer 2025.
2.content:
Over the last decade, the Nike P-6000 has faded in and out of the spotlight. Ahead of summer, the retro running-inspired design has built up a sizable roster of colorways to ensure it stays in rotation. The latest example arrives in a 'Blink' makeover.

Reminiscent of the recently-surfaced 'Black/Pink' Vomero 5, the upcoming women's offering also features a two-tone color combination across its performance-informed build. The busy upper – inspired by models from the Nike Pegasus series – favors a pitch-dark finish that allows for the slightest contrast to revel in the spotlight. Vibrant 'Hyper Pink,' then, animates panels near the tongue, as well as ribbed components at the forefoot and heel. A matte 'Metallic Silver' also joins the mix via branding on the pair, but the P-6000's star is unquestionably the 'Black/Hyper Pink' duo.

RIDELINER-assisted cushioning underfoot also indulges in a near-fluorescent shade of the titular rosy hue, further cementing the style as a fashionable option. The two-tone color scheme has no association with the original Air Yeezy from April 2009, but it's equally-worthy of the 'Blink' nickname.

Enjoy official photos of the 'Black/Hyper Pink' P-6000 ahead. Pairs should land quietly to Nike.com and other retailers by June for $110.

For more women's sneakers from the Swoosh family, check out the Nike A'One, A'ja Wilson's first signature model.

4.title: Nike settles sex discrimination lawsuit
4.snippet: Less than a month before an expected trial, a “sweeping sex discrimination lawsuit” against Nike has “tentatively settled, likely ending a fierce and...
4.content:
Less than a month before an expected trial, a “sweeping sex discrimination lawsuit” against Nike has “tentatively settled, likely ending a fierce and yearslong legal fight about the company’s treatment of women,” according to Matthew Kish of the Portland OREGONIAN. The settlement includes agreements with the four remaining plaintiffs “as well as an unspecified class of plaintiffs,” seemingly “a win for plaintiffs’ lawyers who have continued to fight for making the lawsuit a class action.” Paul Hastings lawyer-- who represents Nike-- Felicia Davis said: “We still need to reduce that agreement to a final written agreement.” Davis said that the agreement “can probably be finalized in a couple of weeks.” Lawyer James Kan-- whom represents the plaintiffs-- said that the agreement also “includes a proposed class settlement.” He did not provide the court specifics about the size of the class. Kan noted that it will “take significantly more time to finish the class settlement.” The proposed class “will need to be notified.” Then there will be a hearing, and “it will need the court’s approval” (Portland OREGONIAN, 2/12).

LET THE PEOPLE KNOW: Kish in a separate piece noted lawyers for Nike and The Oregonian/Oregon Live “argued for nearly an hour” yesterday in a S.F. federal courtroom about the news organization’s ongoing efforts to make more information public in a “high-profile sex discrimination lawsuit against the company.” A panel of three judges at the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals heard Nike’s arguments to overturn two previous rulings in favor of The Oregonian/OregonLive and its media partners. At the appellate hearing, Nike “challenged a district court ruling” in favor of The Oregonian/OregonLive, Business Insider and the Portland Business Journal. The news organizations had “successfully argued that more information about the case should be made public.” That resulted in the court unsealing about 5,000 pages of documents, including records that “allege inappropriate sexual conduct, workplace bullying and a lack of faith in Nike’s willingness to address the problems.” The news organizations subsequently asked the court to unseal additional information, “including the names of Nike employees who are alleged to have behaved inappropriately.” Two federal judges ruled in favor of unsealing the additional information. Nike “appealed the rulings.” Yesterday’s hearing also “took up separate arguments” on Nike’s challenge to a district court ruling that said that The Oregonian/OregonLive “can report on records it independently obtained through its newsgathering” (Portland OREGONIAN, 2/12).

5.title: Charles Barkley’s Original ’90s ‘Godzilla’ Nike Sneakers Are Coming Back
5.snippet: Details on the return of the iconic Nike Air CB 34.
5.content:
The return of one of NBA Hall of Famer Charles Barkley’s most popular Nike signature shoes is carrying on as expected after reports of a “Triple White” Nike Air CB 34 retro surfaced in November.

In addition to the all-white colorway, the sneaker’s original Phoenix Suns-inspired style is also expected to be rereleased. First shared by Sneaker News, the Nike Air CB 34’s black-based “Godzilla” colorway is set for a 2025 come back — 30 years since it first appeared.

More from Footwear News

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement

Originally released in 1995, the “Godzilla” look was one of just two original colorways worn by Barkley on the court, although it was the only one that was released to the public.

Nike Air CB 34 ‘Godzilla’ (pair). Nike

The mostly black sneaker uses a mid-top cut that is noticeably lower than some of Barkley’s other shoes and features a contrasting white “tooth” pattern across the midsole along with purple accents that reference the Suns. At the bottom of the shoe, graffiti-style lettering spells out “Sir” on the left side and “Charles” on the right, a clever callback to one of Barkley’s many nicknames.

An early 1990s ad by longtime Nike partner Wieden+Kennedy which pitted Barkley against the fictional monster served as inspiration for the shoe’s fierce design and eventual “Godzilla” nickname.

The model was Barkley’s third signature sneaker, following the comparably aggressive Air Force Max CB and Air Max 2 CB 94 models. The Air CB 34 was designed by the legendary Wilson Smith III, who is widely recognized as the first Black designer in athletic footwear. Along with Barkley’s Air CB 34, Smith was responsible for iconic sneakers including the Air More Uptempo, Air Jordan 16 and Air Jordan 17, among others.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement

Like the “Triple White” colorway, the “Godzilla” Nike Air CB 34 is expected to be released during the second half of ’25 with a SKU of 316940-001 and a holiday-timed launch expected. Images of the latest reissue have yet to surface, but the pair is expected to resemble previous retros. The sneaker’s 2016 iteration is pictured here.

7.title: Garment Workers Are Taking on Nike, Americans Should Join Them
7.snippet: Absent in the raging debate over trade policy and tariffs is a truth about the economy that those of us in poorer countries know all too well: U.S....
7.content:
Absent in the raging debate over trade policy and tariffs is a truth about the economy that those of us in poorer countries know all too well: U.S. corporations and their billionaire owners profit from massive supply chains that exploit low-wage workers in the Global South.

For decades these unregulated supply chains have been praised as “development.” But in reality, they entrench low pay and disastrous working conditions, fostering a “race to the bottom” for workers globally as well as in the United States.

Perhaps no company is a more influential offender than Nike.

Nearly 30 years ago, the anti-sweatshop movement forced Nike to end its use of child labor. But since then, Nike has actually figured out how to pay an even smaller portion of its retail sticker price to the workers who make its products.

In 2022, Nike authorized $18 billion in stock buybacks, which primarily benefit wealthy investors, while garment workers — the vast majority of whom are women in the Global South — faced massive wage losses and wage theft during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Leni, a member of the Indonesian union Gabungan Serikat Buruh Indonesia (GSBI), makes Nike shoes in a factory with thousands of workers, most of them women like her.

“I want the world to understand the truth of workers’ lives behind these products,” Leni told me recently. “I had a baby and another small child when COVID hit in 2020. The factory slashed our wages and offered no support. We couldn’t even put basic food on our families’ tables. As we learned that Nike made record profits during the pandemic but offered us no relief, we were furious. There is no Nike and no profits without us.”

“My factory has not even paid the mandated minimum wage increases in my region,” she continued. “We have had enough! We demand that Nike end wage theft in its supply chain and pay us what we deserve.”

Leni is part of a group of union activists from Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Cambodia, Bangladesh, and India with a plan to fight back. These brave workers have committed to speak publicly despite the risks of retaliation.

The Asia Floor Wage Alliance (AFWA) has brought together unions across our region. We are organizing across borders in a transformative fight for living wages and human rights protections. The “Fight the Heist” campaign — coordinated by AFWA andGlobal Labor Justice (GLJ) — has focused its demands on Nike, with its supply chain of over 1 million garment workers.

Our support in the U.S. labor movement has grown too. In July 2024, the Coalition of Labor Union Women and the Communications Workers of America Women’s Committee joined GLJ to organize actions in eight cities across the United States. We’re so excited to see allies in the U.S. relate to our fight against corporate greed and for the value of women’s work.

At the end of 2024, the Fight the Heist worker activists ran hundreds of organizing meetings with their coworkers. They discussed the gross inequalities of Nike’s supply chain — for instance, Nike’s CEO got paid more than 24,000 times more than a worker in Sri Lanka making Nike’s clothing in 2023.

At the end of those conversations, activists challenged their coworkers to join a public photo petition. Through the petition, workers are demanding that Nike recognize their essential work and provide the pay they deserve.

Now, over 1,000 workers across the region have decided to stand up together. On March 21, their photos will go public as allies across the world share the petition and demand that Nike’s executives look them in the eye.

These abusive practices only make it easier for corporations to lower wages in working standards in the United States as well. So will you join us?

Take the “One Thousand Photos — One Thousand Shares” pledge at ActionNetwork.org, share it widely, and support the union activists leading the fight to transform garment supply chains.

0.title: I Tried the Nike 24.7 Collection Worn by Serena Williams During Super Bowl 2025
0.snippet: In this review, Associate Editor Aiyana Ishmael tries out the latest Nike 24.7 Collection to see how comfortable and versatile it is.
0.content:
I am always on the hunt for the perfect pieces that match my lifestyle, which is why I've had my eyes on the Nike 24.7 collection ever since it was announced.

As a fashion editor, I spend a lot of my time at work, and because of that, I’ve made it my life’s mission to diversify my free time with workouts, dance classes, and my indoor volleyball league. That means I usually spend most of my time running between dinners and games and always lack the perfect post-activity outfit. This past week, I left my volleyball game wearing a hodgepodge of clothing items: The sweaty T-shirt I wore during the game, a pair of patterned comfy pants I pulled out of my closet for my 45-minute subway ride, shiny silver western boots, and a burgundy faux fur coat — pieces originally part of my NYFW outfit from earlier in the day.

This rather embarrassing outfit cocktail made me realize that I needed better, relaxed pieces that could work at any time of the day. So when I learned about the Nike 24.7 collection, worn by Serena Williams herself during Super Bowl LIX, I knew I had to try it. (What can I say? As a distinguished hater myself, born on the same day as Kendrick Lamar, I just couldn't resist seeing her skirt swishing through the wind as she crip walked while staring directly at the camera!)

Serena Williams wearing the Nike 24.7 Collection while performing onstage during Apple Music Super Bowl LIX Halftime Show at Caesars Superdome on February 09, 2025 in New Orleans, Louisiana. Emilee Chinn/Getty Images

I opted for a tan sweater and matching pants because, again, I sadly am in the frigid winter in New York City, and skirts sans tights are just not on my list of things to wear right now. I decided to try out these pieces in the gym to see their durability and sweat levels. And then I wore it again to work, snazzy-ing it up to see if I could convince my bosses that sweats are, in fact, appropriate workwear.

Aiyana Ishmael for Teen Vogue Aiyana Ishmael for Teen Vogue

The Nike 24.7 collection is meant to support an athlete's complete lifestyle with an elevated and polished look — from sport to life, mindset to movement, daily grind to daily comfort. “Nike Training is dedicated to supporting all athletes to be better — whether for sport or life,” says Jaclyn Safley, GM of global Nike training women's. “The Nike 24.7 collection embodies this commitment, delivering unmatched innovation with performance materials, ultimate comfort, and an elevated fit thoughtfully crafted for every body and every move.”

Nike 24.7 unveiled two new technical materials that pair with the brand’s industry-leading Dri-FIT technology to offer a new standard of comfort in elevated, polished athletic style. ImpossiblySoft is a refined, Spacer-knit fabric with a four-way stretch that offers everyday comfort with a luxurious feel. The material is featured in the Nike 24.7 collection’s women’s and men’s half-zip and crew-neck silhouettes, as well as a women’s jogger and men’s pants. PerfectStretch is a tailored, four-way stretch fabric that delivers effortless comfort and a polished look and feel. The material is featured in the pleated skirt, wide-leg pants and woven shirt for women, and chino and five-pocket pants for men.

Aiyana Ishmael for Teen Vogue Aiyana Ishmael for Teen Vogue

I’m wearing the Women's Dri-FIT High-Waisted Loose Wide-Leg Pants and the Women's Dri-FIT Oversized 1/2-Zip Top in an XL in these pics. And while I couldn't tell you how exactly the clothes are engineered, I can tell you that the fit is great and very comfortable. They are also winter-approved. I layered a long-sleeved shirt underneath and wore a Canada Goose coat on top, and it was rather warm during my commute, which was a pleasant surprise. I received two sets, one in an XL and XXL, and both were comfortable with a relaxed fit. The material is uber soft and warm, and though I've yet to wash them, they withstood my busy days without any hurdles or smells.

Aiyana Ishmael for Teen Vogue Aiyana Ishmael for Teen Vogue

While I paired my picks with sneakers, which definitely toned down the look (sorry, it was snowing outside!), their design actually resembles very comfortable slacks, so with the right top and shoes, you can easily wear these as office pants as well. As someone who will always choose comfort first when getting dressed, these pieces will surely become my go-to moving forward.

1.title: Nike gender discrimination lawsuit moves toward settlement
1.snippet: PORTLAND Ore. (KPTV) -...
1.content:
PORTLAND Ore. (KPTV) - A gender discrimination lawsuit filed against Nike in 2018 may soon be resolved.

All parties held a status conference Tuesday, and now plan to settle.

The suit claims that the women involved were paid less than men, despite being equally qualified and doing the same amount of work, and says harassment or discrimination claims were handled or ignored by human resources.

The settlement is pending a judge’s approval.

If an agreement had not been reached the trial would have started on March 10.

In the early 1990’s, Nike’s genius advertising department pitted Charles Barkley against the one-and-only Godzilla, the colossal prehistoric lizard monster, as part of the campaign for his line of footwear. Now, the Nike Barkleys bearing that nickname, the Air Max CB 34, is due out for Holiday 2025.

Sneaker News confirms that the Air Max CB 34 “Godzilla” is indeed set to release again during the final quarter of the year with an MSRP of $150. The original colorway of black/white/purple is expected, with new styles and retros to follow.

Nike last released the Air Max CB 34 in 2016; they were met with huge fanfare among early 1990s era Nike Basketball fans, and given Barkley’s ongoing relevance within the game of basketball and the larger picture of pop culture, there’s never a wrong time to bring back some Nike Barkley shoes.

4.title: Nike settles sweeping sex discrimination lawsuit
4.snippet: Less than a month before an expected trial, a sweeping sex discrimination lawsuit against Nike has tentatively settled, likely ending a fierce and yearslong...
4.content:
Less than a month before an expected trial, a sweeping sex discrimination lawsuit against Nike has tentatively settled, likely ending a fierce and yearslong legal fight about the company’s treatment of women.

The settlement includes agreements with the four remaining plaintiffs as well as an unspecified class of plaintiffs, seemingly a win for plaintiffs’ lawyers who have continued to fight for making the lawsuit a class action.

5.title: 11 indicted in Arizona train heist; $200K+ of stolen Nike shoes seized
5.snippet: Eleven people have...
5.content:
PHOENIX (AZFamily) — Nearly a dozen people have been indicted in connection to a train heist that occurred in Northern Arizona.

Federal documents obtained by Arizona’s Family Investigates reveal most of those people were in the United States illegally, and several of them had previously been removed from the country.

How they were caught

Authorities say that on Jan. 13, a BNSF train reported a cut air hose near Perrin, Arizona, about 20 miles northwest of Williams. That alerted authorities because they say it’s known that criminals often do it to force the train into an emergency stop.

Federal agents say it’s so the crooks can control when the train is stopped to steal the cargo, but it’s dangerous because it can cause the train to derail.

A short time later, a BNSF police officer drives by and notices about 200 to 250 “master cases” of Nike shoes next to the railroad. Agents say each master case contains six pairs of shoes of an unreleased style with a suggested retail price of $225 per pair.

About eight miles away, a white Ford box truck marked with the word “Eddie’s” was seen with a temporary license plate registered out of Peoria. Arizona’s Family spoke with the business owner with markings on the truck who said that he sold the truck in November. Later in the day, a blue Toyota Camry was spotted near where the truck was. Williams police conducted a traffic stop and identified the driver and the passenger.

Four trackers had been placed within the Nike shoes. Later that evening, the Ford truck was seen headed toward the shoes, and not much later, a U-Haul was spotted speeding off in the same direction.

Court documents say the U-Haul was spotted near the shoes’ site, and when law enforcement arrived again, only six boxes were left. Agents say one of the trackers matched the truck’s location, and the other truckers matched the U-Haul’s location.

Authorities maintained surveillance until state troopers pulled over the drivers of the Ford truck on Interstate 40 near Kingman, Arizona. At that location, the driver and his passenger got out of the truck, and the driver tried to run away, jumping over a barb-wired fence and hiding in a tree structure, but he was ultimately found injured by law enforcement.

What charges do they face

During the search, the agent found 150 master cases of the unreleased pair of shoes, with an estimated retail value of $202,500.

Authorities later found the U-Haul truck abandoned, but investigators were able to trace a large SUV traveling in the same area as the U-Haul. Coconino County sheriff deputies conducted a traffic stop that night in Williams, where Nunez-Mares was detained and identified as the driver with eight passengers.

Court papers say Nunez-Mares rented the U-Haul in Williams and was due to return it in Cudahy, California, near Los Angeles a few days after the heist.

Ten of the 11 people arrested were in the U.S. illegally, and four were previously removed from the country. All are facing possession of stolen goods from an interstate shipment and their respective immigration-related charges.

Arizona’s Family previously reported about how bandits in December made off nearly $50,000 worth of Nike shoes bound for Dick’s Sporting Goods.
