2.title: Can Nike Stock Reach $100 in 2025?
2.snippet: Nike shares have tanked an alarming 26% in the past five years. The market has completely soured on the company and its prospects.
2.content:
Nike (NKE -1.35%) is proving that even some of the most dominant and well-known businesses can hit a rough patch. The S&P 500 is in record territory, but that's not the case for this stock.

Shares of the sportswear giant last traded in the three-figure club in March 2024, but they've been in a downward trend since. They currently sell at 58% below their peak from November 2021 (as of Dec. 30, 2024).

Can this consumer discretionary stock reverse course, rise 33% from its current $75 price tag, and get to $100 in 2025?

A winning business

Nike controls 16.4% of the global sportswear market, according to data from Euromonitor. Adidas is in second place with a 9% share, showcasing Nike's commanding lead of the industry.

This kind of positioning doesn't happen overnight. Since its founding in 1964, Nike has risen up the ranks to become a household name with massive name recognition. The company's brand, supported by excellence in marketing and storytelling, has kept Nike relevant for decades.

Nike's brand has been a key contributor to its financial success. Revenue in fiscal 2024 (ended May 31) totaled $51.4 billion, 85% higher than in the same period 10 years earlier. Net income during this stretch soared 112%.

Thanks to consistent profitability, Nike has been able to return lots of capital to shareholders. The current dividend yield of 2.14% is certainly healthy. But it's worth pointing out that the payout has climbed 186% in the past decade.

Share buybacks are also critical. Nike repurchased $4.3 billion of outstanding stock in fiscal 2024.

On a losing streak

Things haven't been going smoothly for Nike in recent years. With the benefit of hindsight, I believe there are two blunders that have led to the company's challenges.

The first was Nike's relentless push to boost its direct-to-consumer and digital sales. Not long after the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, Nike's leadership team set a goal to achieve 50% of its revenue from the online channel. So, it decided to cut ties with key wholesale accounts.

After the pandemic's worst days had passed, consumer behavior normalized, and people went back to shopping in person. But Nike had bet that this wouldn't be the case. It gave up valuable shelf space to rivals, especially in the critical running category.

As a consumer brand, Nike must excel in product innovation, developing the right merchandise to drive interest. The company also has to ensure it doesn't create too much supply, which would undermine its brand image.

Here's the other area where Nike failed, as it relied too heavily on classic footwear lines that lost their cool factor due to excess supply. At the same time, the business hasn't prioritized releasing new styles and designs. "The result is we've become far too promotional," CEO Elliott Hill said on the second-quarter 2025 earnings call.

These negative trends led to 8% and 26% sales and net income drops, respectively, in Q2 2025 compared to the same year-ago period.

Exceeding low expectations

Nike shares have tanked an alarming 26% in the past five years. The market has completely soured on the company and its prospects. That pessimistic perspective is warranted.

However, the current valuation might be too hard to ignore. As of this writing, the stock trades at a price-to-earnings ratio of 23.1, representing a 42% discount to its trailing five-year average.

To turn things around, the business needs to stabilize its revenue and earnings declines, which will be helped by reducing promotional activity and focusing on product innovation. All this must happen while Nike wins back customers around the globe.

Even small progress can boost investor sentiment. If the stock rises 33% in the next 12 months, I would not be surprised. But to be clear, this depends solely on Nike's ability to improve its financial performance and reveal that it's a business heading in the right direction.

4.title: Arizona boys basketball teams featured in Nike Tournament of Champions event
4.snippet: The biggest showcase will be held at Gilbert Highland High School, where 22 Hoophall West teams will be featured, led by Gilbert Perry (11-0), the No.1 team in...
4.content:
Arizona boys basketball teams featured in Nike Tournament of Champions event

Show Caption Hide Caption Koa Peat discusses Perry basketball dynasty, his family legacy Koa Peat explains the trust he has in Perry coach Sam Duane Jr., and closeness of his teammates

Many Arizona boys high school basketball teams hope to make a splash during the Nike Tournament of Champions featuring Hoophall West showcase this week.

The event will be held at various gyms in the Southeast Valley Thursday through Saturday.

This is the in-season version of June's Section 7, where top teams from across the country, mostly from Southern California, come to play along with most of the top Arizona teams.

There are 14 divisions, 13 of those featuring eight teams each.

The biggest showcase will be held at Gilbert Highland High School, where 22 Hoophall West teams will be featured, led by Gilbert Perry (11-0), the No.1 team in Arizona and ranked No. 5 nationally by MaxPreps. This is where the elites will meet.

Perry, which has won three consecutive state championships, are led by 6-foot-8 5-star recruit senior Koa Peat, who has yet to make his college decision. Peat is surrounded by talented players with 6-5 wing D'Andre Harrison and 5-10 point guard NoNo Brown, both among the best in the state at their positions.

Perry's 9 p.m., Thursday draw — the last game of the first day — features the Pumas against national power Harvard-Westlake (15-1) out of Southern California, a team the Pumas lost twice to last season. Harvard-Westlake is led by the triple threat of Nik Khamenia, Isaiah Carroll and Amir Jones.

"It is a tremendous opportunity for us to be a part of such an elite field of teams in Hoophall West," said Perry coach Same Duane Jr. "I think bracket play will be great for the event. We are excited for the daily challenges against some of the best teams and players in the nation. We will find out where we are as a team."

Games run from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m.

Perry is guaranteed three games, playing in a bracket that includes Christ the King (New York), Chaminade College Prep (Missouri), Duncanville (Texas), De La Salle (California), Phoenix Sunnsylope and Gonzaga College (Washington, D.C.).

There is also a section for prep academies. Chandler AZ Compass Prep and features twin guards Kaden and Kalek House plays at 6 on Thursday night against another prep academy out of Utah, Wasatch.

Following that game, second-ranked Sunnyslope (8-5) takes on Gonzaga College, which takes a 10-1 record into the showcase. That team features 6-foot-10, 250-pound center Christian Gurdak, who has signed with Virginia Tech.

Sunnyslope's only in-state loss was to Perry, 61-52, on Dec. 13. Sophomore big man Darius Wabbington (6-10, 245), will see how he stacks up against Gurdak.

The winner takes on the Perry-Harvard-Westlake winner on Friday at 9 p.m. The championship game is Saturday at 9 p.m.

At noon on Thursday at Highland, No. 3-ranked Phoenix Sandra Day O'Connor takes on California's St. John Bosco, which is 14-1, coming off its first loss to Roosevelt (California), 56-55, in overtime. SDO (10-3), which lost to Sunnyslope 67-55 earlier this year, is led by 6-8 forward Michael Simcoe and point guard TayVion Wilson.

Roosevelt starts Thursday at 9 a.m. at Highland against Nevada's Coronado.

"Seeing the platform that the girls Nike TOC is, the thought of having that available to our student-athletes is huge," said Phoenix Mountain Pointe coach Kaimarr Price, whose team is playing in the Trailblazer Division. "Add in Section 7, and you now have the major scholastic summer event and in-season event in your own backyard.

"It all gives AZ schools a chance to play against schools from other states and go prove our talent and abilities as a basketball state,'' he added. "Mountain Pointe is treating this as such. Our players want acknowledgment and recognition, so here is another chance to show what you can do."

Find a full schedule for all the games here.

Richard Obert has been covering high school sports since the 1980s for The Arizona Republic. He also covers Grand Canyon University athletics and the Arizona Rattlers. To suggest human-interest story ideas and other news, reach Obert at richard.obert@arizonarepublic.com or 602-316-8827. Follow him on X, formerly Twitter:@azc_obert

Meanwhile, bright yellow and black colors deck out the Waffle lugs on the outsole, bringing even more attention to the iconic traction detail — as if it didn't stand out enough as one of Nike's craziest innovations of all time.

6.title: Nike Air Foamposite Pro "Pearl" Returns Holiday 2025
6.snippet: Nike Air Foamposite Pro Pearl 2025 HF0794-200 Release Date: Holiday 2025 Price: $230 Where to Buy: Nike.com. Discover more details.
6.content:
The Nike Air Foamposite Pro “Pearl” is making a triumphant return during the Holiday 2025 season. A cult classic in Nike’s Foamposite lineage, this sneaker holds a special place in sneaker and pop culture history.

- Advertisement -

What sets the Foamposite Pro “Pearl” apart is not just its innovative design but its rich legacy. Originally released in 1997, this silhouette took the sneaker world by storm with its futuristic design and unparalleled performance on the court. However, its cultural status skyrocketed when Ray Allen famously wore the shoe in Spike Lee’s iconic 1998 film, He Got Game. Playing the character of Jesus Shuttlesworth, Allen’s effortless style and undeniable skill brought the “Pearl” to the forefront, cementing its place in sneaker history.

The 2024 iteration stays true to its roots, featuring a pearlized Foamposite upper paired with sleek black accents and a glossy black Swoosh. The icy translucent outsole adds a touch of modern flair, while details like the red pull tab stitching hint at its rich basketball heritage. The durable construction and futuristic aesthetic remain a testament to the innovative spirit of Nike during the late ’90s.

Nike Air Foamposite Pro Pearl 2025 Release Date

The Nike Air Foamposite Pro “Pearl” will release in Holiday 2025 at select Nike Sportswear retailers in-store, online and Nike.com. The retail price tag is set at $230 USD.

Whether you’re a longtime fan or new to the Foamposite scene, this release is a must-have for any sneaker enthusiast. Mark your calendars for this holiday season and prepare to relive the magic of the “Pearl” as it graces shelves once more. Don’t miss your chance to own a piece of sneaker history that blends style, performance, and cinematic lore.

Stay up to date with all upcoming sneaker releases from our Sneaker Release Dates page. Be sure to follow us on Twitter and Instagram.

0.title: Top Stories of 2024: Lessons from Nike’s layoffs and employee change comms
0.snippet: Top Stories of 2024: Lessons from Nike's layoffs and employee change comms. The employee response to Nike's exec comms around its layoffs offer reminders about...
0.content:
This story was originally published on April 25, 2024. We’re republishing it as part of our countdown of top stories of the year.

When you think of mainstay American brands, Nike is probably close to the top of the list. Long known as an innovator in the world of sports apparel and equipment, there’s a certain air of gravitas that comes with owning an item branded with the Nike logo. But all might not be well in Nikeland, with recent layoffs, a pushback against leadership, and a rethink on internal culture prompting the iconic brand to make changes.

According to the Wall Street Journal, after Nike laid off 1,600 employees earlier this year, CEO John Donahoe said in a meeting with over 20,000 employees that he held himself accountable for the company’s recent struggles amid a pivot away from brick-and-mortar sales amid a perceived e-commerce boom that didn’t fully materialize.

Spoiler: It didn’t go over well.

“Accountability: I do not think that word means what you think it means,” an employee wrote. “If this is cost cutting, how about a CEO salary cut?” another wrote. Soon a cascade of laughing emojis filled the screen. Some colleagues warned others that their posts weren’t anonymous and the chat might be monitored. The attacks went on for several minutes. “I hope Phil is watching and reading this,” an employee wrote, referencing the retired Nike co-founder Phil Knight. The virtual protest illustrated the depths of the dissatisfaction within the sneaker giant and concern for its strategy. “How did we actually get here?” wrote one product manager.

This pushback from Nike’s own employees amid the rethink needed to help right the ship exposes a flash point for the organization’s operational strategy. What goes on behind closed doors in a company can greatly affect external perceptions of that same brand. But with a smart and well-executed change strategy, internal shifts can double as cultural cornerstones that drive external successes.

How internal affairs impact external perception

When the seas of change begin to make waves, it’s time for communicators to take notice and determine how to proceed with the company’s mission and values at the top of the list of priorities. At Nike, creativity has long been one of the brand’s biggest identifiers. The WSJ report claims that the company spent far too much in the way of time and resources looking back at the brand’s history of accomplishments rather than focusing on new breakthroughs. It’s no stretch to understand how that loss of creativity may well have impacted Nike’s less-than-stellar business outlook, leading to the layoffs and internal consternation.

According to Antonio Stephens, director of DE&I communications and global employer brand at Levi Strauss and Co., emphasized how these internal changes can change perceptions among not just the general marketplace, but also among potential recruits.

“Internal changes within any organization can lead to shifts in external perceptions among key stakeholders and talent prospects.”

Communicators can help serve as a stabilizing force during these times. But they need to work hand-in-hand with leadership to ensure everyone is on the same page.

“During times of change, communicators play a crucial role in proactively working with leaders to control the narrative,” continued Stephens. “This involves maintaining visibility among employees through open and transparent communication platforms, ensuring consistent messaging is cascaded effectively by change agents.”

Employee experience and brand impacts

It’s also important to consider the impact that external pressures can have on employee culture and morale within a company. Looking at the level of dissent apparent in the messages firing back at Nike’s CEO in the town hall meeting, it’s clear that some of Nike’s employees are feeling the heat.

Communicators aren’t a fix-it method for every problem a company faces, but they serve as critical advisors in avoiding moments like these. For instance, internal communicators should always be in the ear of leaders and provide counsel so they can avoid stepping on verbal landmines in front of employees and stakeholders like Donahoe did. It’s far easier to prevent culture issues internally as opposed to fixing them once the public finds out about them.

Measurement in times of change

A good communicator knows how to tell the story of the situation around them, often through data. That’s especially critical during times of change. At Ragan’s Employee Communications and Culture Conference last week in Chicago, we learned that you can’t just assume everyone is at the same stage of understanding the story you’re trying to tell. In such moments, measurement can help you define distinct employee personas that segment the delivery channels, cadence and language your change messaging to preserve employee culture during rocky times.

In addition, if communicators can talk about the stories within their metrics in a transparent way, it can fundamentally change how other stakeholders share information both inside and outside the company. By measuring attrition metrics after a major change announcement and comparing it to qualitative data from a pulse survey, for example, a story emerges about what went wong or right and why.

Nike is still one of the most recognizable brands in the world, make no mistake. But this is a case study in the fact that no matter how big or popular your organization is, comms are still important in maintaining a positive culture internally that can then beget a positive external perception.

Sean Devlin is an editor at Ragan Communications. In his spare time he enjoys Philly sports and hosting trivia.

COMMENT

1.title: Here’s What The Nike “Year Of The Snake” Collection Looks Like
1.snippet: Nike plans to release four sneakers for the "Year Of The Snake" in Spring 2025. Tap to read our full breakdown.
1.content:
This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. The opinions and information provided on this site are original editorial content of Sneaker News.

Lunar New Year releases have only become more and more prevalent since Nike came out with its first zodiac-inspired shoe in 2002, with all the biggest brands now consistently dressing their most popular models in YOTx makeup at the start of every new year. As we approach the “Year Of The Snake” on January 29th, we’ve put together full breakdowns on all the Jordan, adidas, and now Nike shoes on tap.

Here we have two Dunks and two Air Force 1s; one each for men and women. Relying on snakeskin material would have been easy enough, but the collection as a whole keeps the reptilian texture to a minimum. All four pairs come with red and gold snakeskin tongue labels, complemented by Zhongguo Jie knots symbolizing luck, harmony, reunion, and love.

Both “Year Of The Snake” Dunks feature quilted, snake-inspired satin lining, differing when is comes to their color and other add-ons. The women’s pair features maroon overlays and pops of gold on the tongue and Swoosh, packaged with rope and flat laces as well as a metallic gold snake dubrae. The men’s pair keeps things a touch simpler, taken in white and sage green with just one set of standard white laces.

As for the Air Force 1, which was the canvas for Nike’s first ever Lunar New Year release back in ’02, the women’s pair spruces up in white/gold while the men’s strikes a more conservative note in almost all-white. The snake-inspired pattern seen on the Dunks appears on the backtab of the women’s colorway and heel panel of the men’s, with both looks coming with the same aforementioned gold dubraes.

Importantly, this only sums up the totality of Nike’s lifestyle “Year Of The Snake” shoes. The Nike Basketball banner will see the release of “Year Of The Mamba” Kobe 5 Protros in honor of the holiday, not to mention a GT Cut 3 (which is available now).

Release dates for the four shoes previewed here have yet to be announced, but those eager to cop can expect Nike’s “Year Of The Snake” collection to land before or around January 29th, 2025. See detailed images of all four pairs below and stick with us for further updates.

Photos via atmos.

5.title: Fund Opposing DEI-Hiring Goals Targets Nike, Kraft and Autodesk
5.snippet: Fund Opposing DEI-Hiring Goals Targets Nike, Kraft and Autodesk ... A new investment fund that plans to oppose corporate DEI hiring goals is taking aim at Nike...
5.content:
A new investment fund that plans to oppose corporate DEI hiring goals is taking aim at Nike Inc., Kraft Heinz Co. and Autodesk Inc.

Azoria Partners’ fund says it will avoid S&P 500 companies with specific diversity, equity and inclusion hiring objectives when it opens in March. Nike, Kraft Heinz and Autodesk fall into this category, according to an internal memo from the fund seen by Bloomberg News.

Co-founder James Fishback said earlier this month during Azoria’s launch at President-elect Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago resort that he has already spoken with Starbucks Corp. about their DEI targets.

Black, indigenous, people of color and Hispanic Americans “are plenty qualified on their own,” Fishback, 29, said in an interview, adding that his mother is Hispanic. “They don’t need handouts. They don’t need shortcuts.”

Under pressure from conservative activists, investors and lawyers, companies have started to roll back their DEI efforts. A federal appeals court struck down a Nasdaq rule last week that compelled companies to include more women, people of color and LGBTQ+ directors on their boards — or explain why they hadn’t.

Related: Death of Nasdaq Diversity Rule Signals More Trouble for DEI

Robby Starbuck, the music-video-director-turned-right-wing-provocateur, is among the most vocal opponents of the DEI movement. He has pushed more than a dozen companies, including Walmart Inc., Toyota Motor Corp. and Harley-Davidson Inc., to change their DEI programs in the past year.

Related: Walmart’s DEI Compromise Holds Lessons for Corporate America

Now, Fishback is joining the fray. He previously worked at Greenlight Capital Inc., the hedge fund run by David Einhorn. He left the firm last year and he’s now in a legal dispute with Greenlight over various allegations.

Fishback’s exchange-traded fund, Azoria 500 Meritocracy, will exclude three dozen companies from the S&P 500 that have gender and racial hiring targets. Fishback said those companies will be made public when the fund launches. He has previously mentioned Best Buy Co. as another company that he’s targeting.

Best Buy declined to comment, while Autodesk, Kraft Heinz and Nike haven’t responded to requests for comment.

Starbucks said in a statement that aspirational goals for gender, racial and ethnic diversity that it set in 2020 expired in October. The company’s current goal is to promote from within for 90% of its retail leadership roles.

Fishback said he plans to travel to the UK to meet with members of Parliament and discuss policies related to meritocracy and DEI. At this point, he said his only plans for the ETF are in the US.

Fishback’s fund is the latest to be started by right-wing investors that are pushing back on corporate DEI and environmental, social and governance strategies. “Anti-woke” investor Vivek Ramaswamy, who’s now working with Elon Musk on Trump’s “government efficiency” initiative, started Strive Asset Management two years ago in a bid to counter ESG strategies.

Cathie Wood, who runs Ark Investment Management, attended the launch of Fishback’s firm at Mar-a-Lago. Her firm says on its website that it’s focused on gender equality and supports groups combating social and economic injustices including the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund. Kevin Roberts, who runs Heritage Foundation — the conservative group behind Project 2025, which provided policy recommendations for the incoming Trump administration — also was at the Mar-a-Lago event.

7.title: Nike's Air Force 1 Low "All-Star" is Business in the Front and Party in the Back
7.snippet: Nike's Air Force 1 Low “All-Star” reimagines the classic silhouette with expressive metallic silver panels and hidden reflective accents.
7.content:
Name: Nike Air Force 1 Low “All-Star”

Colorway: Black and Metallic Silver

SKU: HF2885-001

MSRP: $130 USD

Release Date: January 16, 2025

Where to Buy: Nike

In honor of NBA’s 2025 All-Star Weekend set to take place on February 16 in San Fransisco, Nike’s Air Force 1 Low “All-Star” reimagines the classic silhouette with expressive metallic silver panels and hidden reflective accents.

Like a bright star in the sky the Air Force 1 Low “All-Star” shines both in the light and the dark. With a base of mostly black leather uppers and soles, the new variant shows the signature swoosh and back panels clad in metallic silver. Additionally, a special star-shaped logo charm appears at the end of the lacing system.

When exposed to direct light in the dark, the pair also reveals reflective silver designs across the black leather panels. The eyestays and toe box reveal abstract patterns resembling hand-drawn strokes that are practically invisible in normal lighting.

The upgraded design offers a flattering face-lift to the ubiquitous model and its rather infamous all-black colorway. It seems that as 2025 approaches, Nike’s signature silhouette thrives in subtlety. The recently unveiled Supreme x Nike Air Force 1 Low “White/Black” and “Black/White” appear with almost zero design changes aside from the miniature Supreme emblem on the lateral panel. Elsewhere, the Valentines Day 2025 Rose pack offers completely monochromatic Air Force 1s with pared-back rose embossing.

Nike’s Air Force 1 Low “All-Star” is set for release on January 16, 2025, via the brand’s web store.

As stated earlier, the shoes haven’t been gathering dust for long; Nike re-released the shoes in September of 2022 for $130. However, the demand still exists as brand new pairs are still in movement on secondary marketplaces, leading Nike to move strategically with this release.

9.content:
The Nike Air Force 1 Low “All-Star” edition is a standout release celebrating the NBA All-Star Weekend. With its unique split design, this sneaker offers a stylish mix of textures and finishes. The forefoot features sleek black leather, while the heel, quarter panel, and Swoosh showcase a shiny chrome finish. These details create a fresh and eye-catching look.

For a touch of nostalgia, classic Nike Air branding is featured on the heel, giving the design a retro vibe. This combination of modern and classic elements makes the sneaker perfect for the celebratory atmosphere of the NBA All-Star Weekend.

The Nike Air Force 1 Low “All-Star” is set to drop on January 16, 2025. Fans can find this edition at select Nike Sportswear retailers, online, and on Nike.com for $130 USD. The release aligns with the excitement surrounding NBA All-Star events, making it a must-have for sneaker enthusiasts and basketball fans alike.

In conclusion, the Nike Air Force 1 Low “All-Star” brings together premium materials, reflective details, and a bold design that fits the excitement of the NBA All-Star Weekend. Keep an eye out for this special release in February 2025, as it’s sure to be a popular choice among collectors and fans.

0.title: Nike Unveils the Air Max 1 "Light Bone/Psychic Blue" for Spring 2025
0.snippet: Scheduled to arrive in Spring 2025, this release is set to become a staple for those chasing a balance of earthy tones and vibrant accents.
0.content:
As the snow begins to melt and the days grow longer, sneaker enthusiasts know it’s time to prep for spring’s hottest drops. Nike is gearing up to ease the seasonal transition with a fresh rendition of the classic Air Max 1 in a clean “Light Bone/Psychic Blue” colorway. Scheduled to arrive in Spring 2025, this release is set to become a staple for those chasing a balance of earthy tones and vibrant accents.

A Neutral Base with a Pop of Blue

The Air Max 1 “Light Bone/Psychic Blue” exudes a sense of understated sophistication with its earth-inspired tones. The sneaker’s upper is anchored by a “Sanddrift” mesh, providing a breathable yet textured foundation. This muted shade is complemented by “Light Bone” suede overlays on the midfoot, heel, and above the toebox, creating a harmonious blend of neutral hues.

Adding depth to the design is a khaki leather mudguard, offering a rich contrast to the softer suede elements. While these tones might suggest a subdued vibe, Nike flips the script with the addition of “Psychic Blue.” This eye-catching cerulean hue appears on the midfoot Swoosh and peeks out from the signature exposed Air unit in the heel, injecting a bold, spring-ready energy into the design.

Designed for Warm Days and Cool Vibes

The Air Max 1 is no stranger to being a seasonal favorite, and this latest colorway continues that tradition. Its breathable mesh construction and lightweight materials make it perfect for warmer days, while the pops of color keep it fresh and stylish for any occasion. Whether you’re heading to a festival, brunch, or just enjoying a sunny afternoon, this pair is designed to complement your spring wardrobe seamlessly.

Nike’s commitment to blending functionality with aesthetic appeal shines through in the “Light Bone/Psychic Blue.” The cushioned Air Max sole ensures all-day comfort, while the sleek silhouette maintains the timeless appeal that’s made the Air Max 1 a go-to choice for decades.

A Spring Essential for Sneaker Enthusiasts

This release isn’t just about style—it’s about versatility. The neutral tones allow for effortless pairing with a variety of outfits, from casual denim and tees to athleisure fits. Meanwhile, the “Psychic Blue” accents provide just the right amount of flair to turn heads.

Nike continues to master the art of creating sneakers that cater to both minimalist tastes and those who appreciate a pop of color. The “Light Bone/Psychic Blue” strikes that balance perfectly, making it a must-have for sneaker enthusiasts looking to refresh their collection for the new season.

The Price Tag and Release Details

Priced at $140 USD, the Air Max 1 “Light Bone/Psychic Blue” delivers premium craftsmanship and timeless style at an accessible price point. Sneakerheads can expect this spring-ready pair to drop on Nike’s official webstore sometime in early 2025. While an exact date has yet to be confirmed, the buzz around this release suggests it won’t sit on shelves for long.

Those hoping to secure a pair should keep an eye on Nike’s online store and app for updates. With its universal appeal and seasonally appropriate design, the “Light Bone/Psychic Blue” is poised to become a fast favorite.

Nike’s Air Max 1 “Light Bone/Psychic Blue” embodies everything that makes the Air Max line iconic: clean design, innovative technology, and the ability to stay fresh season after season. This colorway manages to feel both modern and nostalgic, tapping into the current love for earthy palettes while delivering a vibrant accent that screams spring.

For those looking to kick off the warmer months with a standout pair, the “Light Bone/Psychic Blue” is an easy choice. Mark your calendars, check your notifications, and get ready to step into spring in style.

3.title: Nike Unveils the 10 Most Popular SNKRS Releases of 2024
3.snippet: Nike has published its list of the most popular SNKRS drops of 2024. The brand previously posted lists for 2022 and 2023, with Travis Scott's Air Jordan 1 Low...
3.content:
As the year comes to a close, Nike has published its list of the most popular SNKRS drops of 2024. The brand previously posted lists for 2022 and 2023, with Travis Scott’s Air Jordan 1 Low OG collaborations claiming the top spot in both years. This time around, Scott has not only taken first place, but claimed four out of the top five positions.

Hot off of the release of the Kids of Immigrants x Nike Air Max Sunder “Sunrise,” we have a complete rundown of what sneakers drove the most traffic to SNKRS this year. Per usual, Travis Scott’s AJ1 Low OGs drew in the masses, taking first, second and fifth. His Jordan CJ1 T-Rexx “Sail” landed in fourth, just behind the Air Jordan 4 “Bred Reimagined.” The AJ4 also found itself in sixth with its “Industrial Blue” colorway. The only two non-Jordan Brand drops in the top 10 came in seventh and eighth place with the Kobe 6 Protro “Italian Camo” and Futura x Nike SB Dunk Low respectively. From there, Trophy Room’s AJ1 Low OG “Rookie Card – Away” and J Balvin’s Air Jordan 3 “Rio” rounded out the top release list.

Key takeaways from the data includes both Scott and the AJ1 present across 40% of the entries. The AJ4 was the only non-collab pair from Jordan Brand to make the list, appearing in two colorways. Low-tops performed best with six featured in the lineup and Nike only found itself holding 20% of the spots, down from 50% the past two years. Check out the full list below, including the original articles for each pair.

Did you end up copping any of these 10 pairs from SNKRS this year? Either way, here’s to hoping there’s better luck in store for all of us in 2025.

4.title: The Nike Field General Snakeskin Pack Releases Spring 2025
4.snippet: Nike's Field General is getting three snakeskin-laden colorways in Spring 2025 to honor the Year of the Snake. Find images and details here.
4.content:
Nike Field General Snakeskin Pack

Nike and much of the sneaker industry delved deep into its archives throughout 2024. Included in this was the reintroduction of the Nike Field General, a sneaker initially built for the gridiron in the ‘80s and worn by iconic NFL quarterbacks like Archie Manning, Dan Marino, and many more. We’ve seen the sneaker come forth in various new renditions, but 2025 will mark its first foray into Lunar New Year celebrations with the upcoming Snakeskin Pack.

Although not directly tied to Nike’s overarching Lunar New Year Collection, celebrating the Year of the Snake, the three colorways pictured here are obvious homages to the zodiac. All three pairs come with a tonal color palette across the upper, one in Dark Grey, another in Light British Tan, and finally, a Sail rendition. The three colors also share the same placement of snakeskin details, as the Swoosh comes in different colored faux snakeskin on each pair, and the color of the leather heel tab takes on a sail finish.

Nike Field General Snakeskin Pack

Aside from the snakeskin Swoosh, everything else remains standard for the model, with a smooth leather finish on the toebox and midfoot panel. At the same time, the suede hits the mudguard, vamp, eyestays, and heel overlay. A canvas material is used for the tongue’s construction, which is done in a tonal look to match most of the sneaker. Underfoot, all three pairs come with a tonal rubber midsole and outsole.

The Nike Field General Snakeskin Pack will release in Spring 2025 through Nike and select retailers online and in-store. Available in men’s sizing, the retail price is $110. 5.title: NIKE, Inc. (NKE): Is This Sporting Goods Stock A Good Buy Now?
5.snippet: We recently compiled a list of the 10 Best Sporting Goods Stocks To Invest In Now. In this article, we are going to take a look at where NIKE,...
5.content:
We recently compiled a list of the 10 Best Sporting Goods Stocks To Invest In Now. In this article, we are going to take a look at where NIKE, Inc. (NYSE:NKE) stands against the other sporting goods stocks.

The sports industry typically generates millions of dollars through events, promotions, and endorsements. It is one of the few sectors that continued to prosper, even during the pandemic. The global sporting and athletic goods market is projected to grow significantly, driven by consumer health awareness and rising demand for fitness products. The market value reached $52.02 billion in 2023 and is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 3.2% through 2032, due to innovation in sporting technology and materials. Sports stocks have climbed more than 10% year-to-date, pushing the sports index of the broader market to its highest level since July of last year.

The market has experienced a sudden increase in demand as it recovers from the pandemic. The pandemic initially disrupted the market with postponed events like the Olympics and supply chain challenges. However, increased consumer awareness around fitness and health post-pandemic has further fueled the global demand for sports and sporting goods.

This growth in demand has varied across regions. Western Europe and Asia Pacific have been at the forefront of the sales recovery, while Latin America has maintained its impressive growth momentum. North America also achieved steady progress, building on its previous year's performance. Looking ahead, Latin America and Southeast Asia show the greatest potential, with growth rates of 22% and 11%, respectively, in 2023. Meanwhile, although China rebounded after a challenging 2022, analysts remain cautious about future growth due to ongoing economic difficulties.

Global economic challenges, such as high inflation and uncertainty, are shaping consumer behavior. Rising prices are a top concern for consumers worldwide, affecting purchasing power and brand loyalty. Despite these challenges, sports participation is increasing in some regions, particularly in activities that are accessible, social, and less time-consuming. For instance, customer preference for pickleball and paddle tennis has increased by 159% since the pandemic. As consumer preferences evolve, companies are adapting their strategies to cater to different demographics, particularly the expanding older population.

Rising Demand for Sustainable Sporting Goods

One of the key trends in this industry is the increasing preference for sustainable sporting goods. Despite economic pressures, many consumers are willing to pay 9.7% more on average for products that have a positive environmental impact. Legislation is also playing a big role in driving sustainability. Laws like the U.S. Inflation Reduction Act and the EU Green Deal are pushing investments in green energy and sustainable solutions, including in sporting goods. The EU’s Ecodesign for Sustainable Products Regulation and Waste Framework Directive are setting stricter standards for product design, recyclability, and end-of-life management. Moreover, regulations like the EU Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive are increasing the pressure on companies to be transparent about their environmental and social impacts.

8.title: Up Close With The Nike SB Air Jordan 4 “Midnight Navy”
8.snippet: The Nike SB Air Jordan 4 will usher its second edition two years later, spinning off the gum-soled edition of the AJ4 in Navy.
8.content:
This post contains references to products from one or more of our advertisers. We may receive compensation when you click on links to those products. The opinions and information provided on this site are original editorial content of Sneaker News.

Updated February 11th, 2025: An updated look at the upcoming Air Jordan 4 SB “Midnight Navy” has surfaced, showcasing the Nike SB logo on the heel. Earlier in December 2024, images of the upcoming release were revealed, while mock-ups of shoes were fairly accurate with the final product.

The below article was originally published on December 30th, 2024.

“Sneaker of the Year” conversations for 2024 are all but finished, yet one of the most highly-anticipated shoes of the new year reaches back even further. Reviving what was widely recognized as the defining colorway of ’23, the Nike SB Air Jordan 4 will usher its second edition two years later, spinning off the gum-soled edition of the AJ4 in Navy.

In these first-look images, we get confirmation of the mock-up shots formulated for this shoe’s initial announcement. The flashes of gum brown on the outsole at the forefoot and heel provide aesthetic confirmation of the skate tooling that defines the shoe compositionally. Ironically, these shots come just hours after news that the Jordan 4 SB “Varsity Red” was removed from the release calendar, leaving this as the sole sequel for the seminal 2023 collab.

While we’ll need to wait for in-hand dissections to confirm the hardware, the increased padding, rubber detailing are all expected to accompany the Nike SB branding on the heel. Finally, the biggest divergence on this shoe, the flares of navy where “Pine Green” once took hold, allows this edition to carry the OG sensibility of peers like the “Military Blue” and “Columbia.”

It’s yet to be seen whether the AJ4 in general will hold onto its top status in the Jumpman catalog for 2025, but there’s a slew of colorways already queued up that make it very likely, including this shoe, the “Black Cat” 4s and Air Jordan 4 “White Cement.” Though we don’t have a concrete release date for this shoe, we expect it to hit shelves in March 2025, retailing at $225.

Keep an eye on our Jordan Release Dates page in the coming weeks for additional info on this shoe and other major releases like the Black Cat 3s.

9.title: Nike Reveals The Top 10 Nike SNKRS Releases of 2024
9.snippet: The list is dominated by hype collaborations, Nike Kobes, OG Jordans, and, of course, Travis Scott releases.
9.content:
Top five Nike SNKRS Releases in 2024

Year-end lists in the sneaker world are typically filled with subjective opinions that vary from person to person. Some prefer to look at sneakers that personally spoke to them, impacted the culture, or broke necks with new designs and color schemes. However, Nike has provided us with a list that, just like Sole Retriever’s most popular sneakers list from 2024, looks at data to showcase what the sneaker community went after the most.

Unsurprising to many, the list is dominated by hype collaborations, Nike Kobes, OG Jordans, and, of course, Travis Scott releases. Sneaking in the top ten are two Air Jordan collaborations, J. Balvin’s AJ3 Rio and Trophy Room’s Air Jordan 1 Low OG, both of which were some of the most hyped-up drops of the year's first half. Futura’s Nike SB Dunk Low, Kobe Bryant’s Nike Kobe 8 Protro Italian Camo, and the return of the Air Jordan 4 Military Blue follow suit.

Number ten through six of the Top 10 SNKRS releases in 2024

In the top five, Travis Scott dominates as the Houston native and global superstar has four entries. Number five is his homage to his high school, Elkins High, which ended up being Sole Retriever’s most popular sneaker based on data we have collected over the last 12 months. Following this is Scott’s debut signature sneaker, the Jordan Jumpman Jack in Sail Dark Mocha, and the Jordan 4 Bred Reimagined, coming in at number three. Finally, the top two releases are Travis AJ1 Lows, number two being the recently-released Velvet Brown colorway, and number one being the Reverse Olive pair.

Below, we’ve highlighted each pair in the order Nike had on its top ten SNKRS releases.

J. Balvin x Air Jordan 3 Retro Rio

Trophy Room x Air Jordan 1 Retro Low OG Away

Futura Laboratories x Nike SB Dunk Low

Nike Kobe 6 Protro Italian Camo

Air Jordan 4 Retro Military Blue

Travis Scott x Air Jordan 1 Retro Low OG Canary (W)

Travis Scott x Jordan Jumpman Jack Sail Dark Mocha

Air Jordan 4 Retro Bred Reimagined

Travis Scott x Air Jordan 1 Retro Low OG Velvet Brown

Travis Scott x Air Jordan 1 Retro Low OG Reverse Olive
